They provide some quite inventive shots, as there's a lot of movement going on in the panning and frame shots. The chilling but underplayed piano score knows when to make the sudden whispers turn into quick rush of terror and the sound effects played a big part by chiming with preciseness to make you feel hellishly uneasy. Even when it's dead silent with only the ruffling winds it still succeeds in stamping a terrifying mark. It's clearly a dynamic catalyst of the genre! A truly stark and quite stylish horror film that gets under your skin by suffocating you with a heavy blanket of menace. Highly recommended!

Review title: I'm dreaming of a... well, it's a nightmare, actually.
Review_body: Considered by many to be the first true 'slasher' (although 'Peeping Tom (1960)', 'Psycho (1960)', 'A Bay Of Blood (1971)' and 'The Texas Chain Saw Massacre (1974)' preceded it), 'Black Christmas (1974)' certainly provided plenty of inspiration for genre filmmakers (including John Carpenter) in the years following its release. For the most part, the movie plays out as a mystery with elements of a psychological thriller. It sees the members of a sorority house harassed with obscene phone calls and picked off one by one by an unseen killer. The film is really good at getting you to engage with its enigma, trying to guess who the killer may be while wondering when he is going to strike again. This is a large part of why the picture is as successful as it is, even if it is relatively slow between its more intense sequences. It's genuinely rather suspenseful at times and its madman's maniacal screaming is actually somewhat upsetting. It all builds to a brilliantly ambiguous finale that really does get under your skin, leaving you craving closure and callously refusing to provide even an ounce of it. It's a fantastic way to end the experience. Overall, the movie is engaging and typically entertaining. Its restrained use of violence is surprisingly effective and one of its most shocking images - a manic eye peering out from the shadows - is still burned in my memory. It's a rock-solid early entry in its genre. 7/10

Here is a film that is not usually present in Christmas day-time programs although its action happens around Christmas and has even a scene with a choir of children singing carols. Filmed in 1974 in Canada Black Christmas is a combination of seasonal movies and horror, more precisely one of the first films of the 'slash' sub-genre.Film director Bob Clark is author and this is one of the first in a career that will still includes some successes of the genre, and even a second film (A Christmas Story) with the theme of Christmas. Clark demonstrates that by 1974 he already mastered many of the secrets of the trade and assimilated the lessons of the masters of the previous generations and especially Hitchcock. The film takes place in one of those American sorority houses. Thrill is induced at the beginning by mysterious and threatening phone calls, because shortly afterward the home tenants begin to disappear one by one, and the bodies to accumulate. I will not tell more so that I do not take away the pleasure of watching for those who still are interested to see the film.'Black Christmas' deserves to be viewed primarily by enthusiasts of the genre, but not only them. I can not say it is a film that time has not made ​​its mark , but interestingly good as its parts are now more visible. At launch it was almost 'destroyed' by some critics, for example that of New York Times. Although some of the critic's objections are deserved (acting seemed pretty sketchy to me), I believe he lost sight of the exact build-up of the atmosphere, using the enclosed space to create the feeling of claustrophobia and daring approach to social topics such as the right of women to decide about abortion (in general it can be said that this is a feminist film). Of course, the 1974-75 critic could not have anticipated that the film will open the way to other horror films that take place in the student environment such as the series 'Scream' and 'I Know What You Did Last Summer' . But there are at least two scenes close to masterpiece that he should not have missed. In one of them a girl's father and the mother of another girl - both disappeared - search their daughters at night in a frozen park. A body is found. To whom it belongs? The whole scene is rendered in its profound horror just filming two parents, there not need to see any body to understand whose death has been confirmed. Groovy and psychologically excellent. The second great scene is the final and I will not tell anything about it, so that I do not deprive anybody of the pleasure of a viewing which I recommend.

Review title: Perfect for a Friday the 13th in December
Review_body: A Friday the 13th in December seemed like the perfect time to watch Black Christmas. As one of the few holiday horror movies out there, as well as being one of the first slasher flicks, it holds a special place in film history. And despite the predictable plot, one-dimensional characters and over-the-top killer, this film has a couple good scares that made it worth the watch.

Review_body: I've seen this on Christmas Eve and I honestly thought it was gonna be a good movie. However, I felt disappointed when we still didn't get to see the killer caught and yet, the audience like myself knew who done it. If they ever thought about a Christmas horror film, at least give it a proper ending and not be messing it up like as if we'll leave it at that! Hello, I was getting interested in seeing one of the girls boyfriend get caught. I wish I had something more to say about this film, its just it left a bad question mark for me and thats why Im giving this a 6/10 rating instead of 8/10.........

The sound of winds, random other sounds and disturbing nature of everything is wide and glorious! So effective and nerve wracking vibes of suspenseful mastery. There's so much madness about destruction whether it's death or objects, excitingly awesome and fun. I think I enjoy Black Christmas more than most horror in the last 50 years.

My expectations for "Black Christmas" were high, but somehow the film just doesn't deliver. The atmosphere is creepy and builds tension, the characters are developed, there is even a marginal attempt at humor, but ultimately I was disappointed. My biggest objection is the unresolved ending. I realize this begs for a sequel, but the story is so simple, that a second film really has nowhere to go. Another problem is the movie is very claustrophobic, with the camera constantly tracking the unseen killer throughout the sorority house. John Saxon seems wasted and his screen time insufficient. "Black Christmas" would make a superior short, but at 98 minutes, it is way too long for such slight material. - MERK

Review title: Black Christmas decorates traditional festivities with blood, suffocation and disturbing phone calls.
Review_body: Ho! Ho! Ho! Merry Christmas! And have a slashin' good time! The slasher sub-genre was most proficient during the mid-to-late 70s, with 'Texas Chainsaw Massacre', 'Halloween' and a plethora of spicy Argento features to add a worldly aesthetic. However, one film that innovated the tropes and traits commonly found in the aforementioned titles, was Bob Clark's Black Christmas. A horror "slasher" (if you can classify it as that...) where an anonymous serial killer remains secluded in a sorority house, gradually picking off the girls one by one. Just in time for Santa to come down that warmly lit chimney and deliver them coffins wrapped up in cute little bows.To say that Black Christmas was revolutionary and a blooded sprout for the blossoming sub-genre to come, would be an understatement. A nameless unknown killer that exhumes mental instability? Check. An expendable cast of characters that stupidly investigate ominous sounds by themselves? Check. Excruciating tension with every camera movement? Absolutely! Surprisingly, now that I've witnessed various films during the conception of a horror movement, it's incredibly easy to see how influential Black Christmas is. Not for its innovative concept, as other simpler thrillers utilise slashing techniques with efficiency ('Psycho'), but rather for its technical proficiency.Clark's direction, whilst unpolished, is solid throughout. Taut camera pans to explore the darkened hallways of the sorority house. Minimal sound editing to heighten the suspense. Excellent use of shadows to illustrate the antagonist's anonymity. Sublime POV perspective to place the viewer in the shoes of the killer. And a ramped up conclusive act that will have anyone watching perched on the edge of their seats eagerly anticipating to unwrap the plot twist, even if that narrative turn was predictable from the offset. The camera can be visible on specific occasions, mostly through reflections in picture frames as it glides through hallways. Emphasising that unrefined quality of Clark's novice-like direction. It does give the feature some flavour, perhaps not the jolly festivities one was yearning for. More egg nog than champagne.Yet what really injected some holiday spirit into the story, were the characters. Uniquely all acquiring a distinguishable personality that made them different and relatable. The shady drunk friend or the intellectual gal who has all the common sense (that is until she goes wandering by herself...!). The point is, they were all memorable, and that's a rare achievement in slashers. The second act, where the campus police become involved, does stagnate the overall pace with minimal storytelling momentum. Fortunately the third act immediately picks it back up for an explosive bauble of...slashing.So despite the lack of actual slashing, overall unrefined quality and inconsistent pacing, it's an extremely enjoyable horror flick that takes a gentle holiday season and turns it into a crazy murder-sesh. Perhaps my new annual Christmas film? We'll see...! I am sadistic after all!
If you like the genre this one is just made for you. Black Christmas is one of those early examples of the genre and still good, maybe even an essential watch for the lover of the art of horror.
This film gives the viewer nothing. Boring story, lack of horror, lack of kills...its just bland.I was excited to see it based on the ratings it has but it was such a let down.Save your time :(

Review title: Chestnuts Roasting on an Open Fire
Review_body: This is definitely one of the best of its type; a crazed killer stalks a coed in a sorority house and unmercifully butchers her closest friends and any passersby that just happen to get in his way. What separates this from the typical slasher fare is an above-average script, above-average acting, and really good direction. Director Bob Clark, the director of such films like Children Shouldn't Play with Dead Things and Murder by Decree, seemingly does everything right in this one and makes all the right choices(well, most of the time at least). His flair for creating hauntingly eerie scenes that stay with you is first-rate. Take the first murdered girl(happens in first ten minutes). We never see the killer but just his eyes. The girl is saran-wrapped in a dress bag and set in a rocking chair with an old doll. Her presence is filmed in such a stark manner as to really set the mood of this whole film. Clark then effectively builds tension by the girl's father looking for her - as no body is found - the coed, played by the beautiful Olivia Hussey, consistently receiving phone calls from what is some sick sex pervert on the outside, the police are then brought into the mix, and finally some red herrings that throw the viewer off track a bit at the very least. All this goes on with snow, caroling, decorations, and Christmas atmosphere like one might expect in a small college town of a similar ilk. The first death scene is for my money the most effective shot and running scene in the entire film, but there are other equally brilliant shots that Clark uses to shock and create suspense. One scene in particular has Margot Kidder getting acquainted with the man with the creepy eyes with cuts(no pun intended) to children singing mellifluous carols at front door for Hussey. The acting all around is pretty good. Hussey is adequate. Kidder is too. Andrea Martin is along as well. The main policeman is John Saxon. He is pretty good and seems to flourish in roles like this in the seventies. Many films have tried to create the same effect as Black Christmas, but so few have come close at all to reaching the level of this - at least in this genre. An impressively shot film with good locations and a very effective ending.

Review title: Much ahead of its time but found it to b dull.
Review_body: I first saw this on a VHS in the late 80s. Revisited it recently on a DVD. Plot - A group of sorority sisters are receiving threatening phone calls, they r stalked and murdered during the holiday season by a deranged murderer. Black Christmas was a bit ahead of its time by using the subject of abortion as one of the main stories in the film. Also a lot of the killers movements are filmed in a point of view style. It was also a first horror film to have its villain use phone calls as a way to terrorize its victims. This movie also has an open ending without revealing or pondering much bah the killer. Also it is notable for "the calls r coming from the house" revelation. Now coming to the flaws, the movie is very slow paced. The editing n cinematography is  not upto the mark. The kills r minimum n most of it r lousy n not at all scary. The tension was lacking. On the contrary the remake had some brutal death scenes.

Black Christmas is brilliantly simple: a stalker terrorizes a sorority house. That simplicity allows it to really dig into the disturbia more specifically and vividly. The intensely unnerving phone calls. The repeated imagery of the plastic-wrapped suffocation. The blur of Christmas lights punctuating the dark scenery. It's brutal '70s horror, but not without some nice splashes of levity to keep everything fresh (the dumb cop is classic).

Review title: There ain't no room for Christmas miracles or presents.
Review_body: "Black Christmas" is an important movie for the Horror genre because it generates opinions of all kinds. People might love it or might not find the greatness about it. Many other people haven't even watched it. But something for sure is that the movie is one of the most important moments in Horror history. A killer on the loose terrorizes an all girl Sorority House with obscene/disturbing phone calls. Little do they know that the deranged killer is hiding in the attic. The believed prank calls take another twist when the caller threatens to death one of the girls. To make things worse, a local young girl is raped and murdered by a killer on the loose. Could it be that it's the same man that is making the calls? The first phone call presumes that a girl has been raped because the caller uses obscene language towards a girl's intimate parts and later makes sounds involving a choking. This all happens on Christmas eve! To make things worse, the hider manages to get down the attic and murder one of the sorority girls. This is where hell breaks loose. Then, one by one these girls and their housemother find terrible fates at the hands of the deranged intruder. The calls continue but each time get nastier and scarier. Police traces the calls and find the shocking truth: the calls are coming from inside the house. It seems that the housemother had two different lines in the house. One of the extensions was in the attic, where nobody would ever enter. The attic is filled with old, dusty toys and old furniture. Also, there are photographs that may be from the killer's family. It seems that the killer lived there before it was used as a Sorority House. The atmosphere surrounding Christmas is more than tense. First, the missing girl that later is found dead, then the missing sorority house girl that seems to have vanished from earth but nobody knows that her dead body is wrapped in plastic, sitting on a rocking chair in the attic!. The prime suspect is Peter, the boyfriend of one of the sorority girls. Many clues lead to believe that he's doing the phone calls but nothing is sure. Meanwhile people wonder what's going on, 7 people have been murdered by a mysterious lunatic. A series of events lead to a confrontation with Jesse and the hider from the attic (who's name is believed to be Billy). Will police come before Billy kills Jesse? How will things end in this mysterious situation? Who really is Billy? Watch "Black Christmas"'s ending to make your own conclusions. Your brain will have a hard time trying to figure out a satisfactory conclusion. What a fantastic suspenseful, mysterious Horror movie this is. The events are displayed in a suspenseful way that increases the scare factor. There are very tense moments that carry the whole movie. The highlight is the infamous, classic moment of the "eye in the closet". That's one of the most frightening moments in Horror history; not because of what's visually displayed, but because what it means for the movie. Also, the phone calls are incredibly disturbing, nerve tensing, and can scare the audience without showing anything. The voices are chilling plus the obscene dialog and yells add more tension to the situations. This is a sui generis movie that has been copied over the years. The acting is perfect. Olivia Hussey delivers a believable, tender, strong, performance as Jesse. She knows really how to scream and how to deal with a maniac. I totally bought it. She was perfect enough to carry the whole film. Special mention for Margot Kidder as the drunk, rebel Babs. She was the comedic part of the movie. Too bad she found such a terrible fate. Keir Dullea plays really good his part as Peter, the paranoid but aggressive boyfriend. The man's acting is powerful. And John Saxon did his all time role perfectly. He can't do wrong. The rest of the cast is great. Marian Waldman and Andrea Martin play supporting roles at perfection. You really feel bad for the characters as you get to know them and generate feelings towards them. The death scenes are perfectly done. There's minimal gore but the scenes are very effective. The glass unicorn death scene is a classic scary moment. As many people know and recognize, BC set the standards for the slasher genre. John Carpenter's "Halloween" is obviously inspired on BC. The killer's POV, the score, the Holiday setting, the situations, etc. Carpenter centered his movie on the killer, giving him a personality while Bob Clark used the killer as an element to increase the tense atmosphere. Black Christmas is a perfect Horror movie. First of all (and most important) it is scary, tense, suspenseful and dark. There ain't no room for Christmas miracles or presents. The killer is as menacing as you can get. Probably the most deranged villain on these kind of movies. I wanted though to know more about him but that's what makes this movie great: that you can figure out whatever you want. Your imagination may create a creepier situation that the real one. The ending is great. It leaves too much for your imagination and still is scary. Watch this gem and give it the credit that it deserves because it's one of the most important, influential Horror movies of all time. No room for Christmas songs or Santa Claus, "Black Christmas" will send up shivers up your funny bone. Believe all the hype towards it.

Not gonna lie i was pretty excited to see this film ,i mean how little slasher films are based around christmas holidays, but and the end i was left dissapointed black christmas end up being film with bunch of phone calls and nothing more only towards end it started to show what we love in slashers but by then it was already to late to satify me

Olivia Hussey, Margot Kidder, Keir Dullea, Andrea Martin and John Saxon star in this 1974 horror film. This takes place during Christmas time where a mysterious psychopath who calls himself, Billy sneaks into a sorority house and stalks the residents. Hussey (Romeo and Juliet) plays Jess, a young girl who begins getting unsettling phone calls from him and is also having trouble with her boyfriend, Peter (Dullea). Kidder (Superman) plays Barb, her alcoholic friend, Martin plays her other friend, Phyl and Saxon (A Nightmare on Elm Street) plays police Lieutenant, Fuller. This is a good horror/slasher flick with a decent cast, ominous score and it's one of the only films where the killer's identity is never revealed. I recommend this to any horror fan.

Review title: Gives birth to other slasher films!
Review_body:
Before "Halloween", before "Friday the 13th", before "A Nightmare on Elm Street", there's "Black Christmas". It's the holidays, and a group of sororities are either staying over, or going home for the holidays. They would get a obscene phone call, and all they could hear are grunts and moans. And a few explicit words from the caller. They would notify the police about the calls, but one of the sorority members goes missing. What is even worse, that a young girl was killed nearby the house.
Not only is it the earlier slasher movie, but it also gives birth to "When a Stranger Calls" a few years later. This is one movie, no one needs to forget.
4 out of 5 stars

Yet another overrated but this time decent little serial killer flick surrounding girls in a sorority. Margot Kidder is great and this production features "Audra" from Stephen King's made For TV movie, "IT." While this is somewhat entertaining, the direction was horrible, and it is easily one of the most clichéd horrors I've seen.It was not scary, and while it tries to build suspense, the liquor-filled sorority house mother relieved any suspense built, by her antics. There are some really creepy (and humorous) elements in this one, making it better than some, but frankly, I don't see why this film is considered to be a benchmark of the horror genre. It really is not anything special. It is just a mediocre thriller, nothing more. I honestly thought Scream was better. *LOL*3.8/10 from...the Fiend :.

Chirstmas time is my favorite season, it's hard to say why may'be because it something that brings togetherness which to me is it's true spirit. It's also a time where we believe we are the safest, however as an old saying goes s... happens, it doesn't matter what time of year it is. This is one of my favorite horror/Chirstmas films of all time if you can believe that.This film was not just one of the first slasher films but also one's set in a season. The fact that this was set up in the Christmas time was a risky move and I felt it was a good risk, who'd of thought Christmas in the horror genre could be a great combo. Let alone the fact this was the late great Bob Clark's first Christmas film where his second is of course my favorite Christmas film of all time "A Christmas Story" so two in a row isn't bad.The production value is great, it was made on a low or modest budget and I really felt they used it well and right. The setting was in a neighborhood and a Sorority House that looked like any house and neighborhood I'd pass by which gives the film a sense of familiarity; let alone most of the film takes place in the Sorority House.The cast is good Margot Kidder as Barb is a character you love to dislike because she is practically a dirtbag on wheels, but she just has some really funny spitfire lines. John Saxton is good as the level headed Lt. Fuller, tirelessly hunting down the elusive killer.But I mainly really like Olivia Hussey as Jess. This is one of those underrated actresses I really like (and on a sidenote "Romeo and Juliet" one of my favorite movies). I'll level with you sometimes I like actors and actresses that are under the radar a lot more than ones that are in the limelight way too long.Anyway back to the jist of things, the character Jess I really like she's good protagonist that is fraking gorgeous with the warm persona to boot, smart, has desires/ambitions, but most importantly is a person that can hold her own whether it be standing up to her blowhole boyfriend (Jess deserves someone better). I like that little drama with her character which made her sympathetic in my book, she has this dilemma and she chooses to deal with it a certain way but of course her boyfriend disagrees and is a complete dirtbag to her just spouting horsecrap to her. I'll admit at that moment I wanted to punch him and yell "Frak You" because I always believe a good significant other should always respect and understand the others feelings in certain matters no matter what. But most importantly hold her own physically against the killer.But what makes this film great and hold up is in it's suspense and creepy, moody atmosphere it invokes which I'll admit gave me the chills. The music is great I really like as the killer first enters there's some sort of eerie tone, as well as the end credit some of Silent Night which has a dark tone to it.I really like the plot it's a simple but it feels plausible, whose to say something like this can't happen; it also made me concerned as to how safe our secure our neighborhoods and homes are. Like in most suspense thriller has always been in being one step ahead of the protagonist. Throughout the film at the moments when nothing really happens yet, we always have that looming fact in our head that the killer in the house and up there, and he's about to do something any minute. In moments like that I'm always thinking "Don't go up to that attic." or "Cmon get the frak out of house, don't spend another night." We just constantly feel unsafe and hope the protagonist can find out this fact on time before it's too late.It's true we never really see what the killer looks like but this is a great think because this gives the killer the element of enigma, the crazed killer is simply who he is evil that's all we need to know. The cinematography is great I love the point of view shots which are great, where we are literally seeing the perspective of the killer. This really adds to the suspense because it adds to the step ahead element, from just some actions or even those noises he makes like in those creepy phone call scenes, it really gives you an idea how truly crazy and psychotic the antagonist is.And I like the feeling of isolation, from the fact most of this film takes place in the nighttime, the snow, the cold, and moments when a character or certain character is alone. Once again you feel unsafe because in times like that you know that the killer could possibly make his move and usually does. But it's also a time where all the chips are down for the protagonist and we hope he/she can successful fight back and survive.Black Christmas will make your skin crawl.Rating: 4 stars

Review title: The best Christmas horror movie ever
Review_body:
An unknown, crazed killer stalks girls at a sorority house at Christmas. He also subjects them to multiple obscene 'phone calls, with much use if the c word, they really are quite shocking. Black Christmas really set the template for the slasher movie: sorority girls, high body count, red herrings, point of view shots, brutal murders, etc. Though
to be fair some of these elements were to be found in Italian giallo movies prior. Incredibly creepy and tense throughout, some humour is to be found in the antics of the drunken housemother and of one of the girls, who plays a funny prank at the police station. Great cast, including one of my favourite actors, John Saxon. This is a masterpiece of horror that really needs to be seen at Xmas. Essential viewing on my calendar, ho ho ho!

Review title: A Black & Blue & Bloody Christmas To You Too!
Review_body: Like, am I the only one who thinks that Black Christmas is nothing more than just an over-rated piece of 'Slasher Trash'? At best, I'd say that this particular Horror film is only marginally better than the rest of the junk that's out there.And, yes, I know that Black Christmas can, in a sense, be considered the "original" Slasher flick, since it proceeds both Halloween and Friday The 13th by years - But I honestly don't give a damn about that sort of thing - 'Cause I still don't think it's all that good, anyways.And, besides that - I still can't figure out how the heck the psycho-killer was able to make those insane phone calls of his from the attic inside the Sorority House. Like, that would've meant that he would've had to have had his own private line up there. And I sure don't recall seeing this nut making any sort of arrangements about this special 'obscene-calls only' service with the phone company, or anything like that.And speaking about those ghastly, irksome phone calls in Black Christmas - According to Director Bob Clark - 5 people (both men and women) were apparently responsible for talking all that gross gibberish stuff over the phone, including Clark, himself. I think it's kind of interesting to note how little profanity was actually used in the things that this wacko said.And, in conclusion - I can't begin to tell you how glad I am that Black Christmas was not followed by a bloody sequel. With the utterly dissatisfactory way in which this film ended, it was sure ripe for one.

Not the kind of Christmas you want to dream about, unless you're a sadist. This little slasher movie that could kind of/sort of kicked off the genre. And it's Canadian! And almost exclusively set in a sorority house. The movie features performances by Margot Kidder, Keir Dullea (2001: A Space Odyssey), Olivia Hussey (Romeo and Juliet), Andrea Martin (SCTV), and crusty cop John Savage. Although it provides a blueprint for many lesser films to follow, Black Christmas also succeeds because it never once explains why people are being killed. Nothing about motive or rationale, just plain old death. Well shot, too - there are numerous long tracking shots, of which I'm definitely a fan. Was almost called Silent Night, Evil Night because producers were worried people would think it was actually a blaxploitation movie. I enjoyed pretty much every aspect of this Bob Clark feature - between his Children Shouldn't Play with Dead Things and A Christmas Story, and come to think of it, it's kind of a cross between those two.

Review title: I strongly recommend watching this classic
Review_body: Black Christmas (1974) is currently available for free on Tubi and the storyline focuses on a sorority house missing a few ladies and a few of the sisters and parents waiting for them to return...as the killer continues to pluck them off. This movie is directed by Bob Clark (A Christmas Story and Porkys) and stars Olivia Hussey (Death on the Nile), Margot Kidder (The Amityville Horror), John Saxon (A Nightmare on Elm Street), Keir Dullea (2001: A Space Odyssey) and Marian Waldman (Phobia). First thing I'll say is these characters love to drink. There's a scene a woman brushes her teeth then gargles with liquor afterwards. This is still an extremely fun movie with some great kill scenes and intensity. The ending reminded me of "When a Stranger Calls" and makes the movie come together well. I loved the final fade out sequence too. This has an eerie feel throughout and a great conclusion. I strongly recommend watching this classic if you never have. I'd score this a solid 8/10.

Now this is what a slasher flick should be. Four years before the unprecedented success of John Carpenter's landmark American horror film "Halloween" in 1978, there was this little gem from Canada called "Black Christmas," directed in 1974 by the late Bob Clark ("A Christmas Story," my #4 favorite film of all time and Clark's possible anti-thesis to this film), and was arguably the first true slasher film (1974 was also the same year that American filmmaker Tobe Hooper directed the landmark "The Texas Chainsaw Massacre")."Black Christmas" is an expertly directed horror film, there's no question about that. The story is incredibly simple, yet stylishly executed. It's deliberately and excellently paced by Bob Clark, who skillfully injects the film with a wicked sense of dread from the get-go, undercut with some slickly timed dark humor (a lot of which is actually quite hilarious). Said humor is appropriately biting and deserves some well-placed laughs but unlike most movies to mix comedy and horror, "Black Christmas" doesn't sacrifice one for the other. In other words, what starts out as a serious thriller doesn't devolve into a mindless, gore-filled slapstick comedy (like "Evil Dead II," which I love by the way). First and foremost, this is a horror film - a seriously effective and scary one at that.Upon having watched "Black Christmas," there's no doubt in my mind that John Carpenter and company watched this film at least once (and took some very, very good notes) and it most definitely played a hand in influencing the directorial style of "Halloween" (although it's widely known that Alfred Hitchcock's landmark 1960 thriller "Psycho" had the most influence on "Halloween"). (Even though I've never uncovered any information pertaining to this claim, anyone who watches "Black Christmas" and then re-watches "Halloween" will see some of the elements that undoubtedly influenced the latter film. I love "Halloween," by the way, and having this information on-hand makes me appreciate both films even more as seriously scary horror flicks.)What makes "Black Christmas" such an important staple in the horror genre is that a lot of the slasher movie elements that most likely first appeared in this film were later used, and popularized, by "Halloween" just four years later down the road. Most importantly, is the fact that many times throughout the picture, the film is shown from the point-of-view of an unseen killer. We many times see his actions as he goes about the prowl for potential victims, in this case the residents of the Pi Kappa Sig sorority house. We also hear his breathes as he stalks the house sisters, and he is always that unseen-but-always-felt presence in the room, like something horrible is lurking just out of sight in the shadows.The women of the Pi Kappa Sig house are preparing to leave for the Christmas holidays, but a few - Jess (Olivia Hussey), Barb (Margot Kidder), Phyl (Andrea Martin), and house mother Mrs. Mac (Marian Waldman) - decide to stay behind. However, someone has been making obscene phone calls to the house and scaring the living daylights out of the women. And it isn't long before the unseen presence begins to systematically eliminate the women in some particularly gruesome and creative ways. It's up to the police, led by Lt. Fuller (John Saxon), to try to find this psycho before he kills anyone else.Even though "Black Christmas" does feature some particularly gruesome and shocking scenes of murder and mayhem, it actually contains very little gore (it's possible that it, like "Halloween," took a few cues from "Psycho"), the film still works largely through the power of suggestion - like what you don't see is far more terrifying because your mind allows you to fill in the gaps. Additionally, there's also a very low body count.It's entirely possible that Olivia Hussey was probably the original scream queen, although, like the actress has said herself in interviews included on the 2006 special edition DVD, she actually doesn't do any screaming in the movie. All the characters in this film are three-dimensional and likable, especially Margot Kidder's drunken party-girl Barb. She was probably my favorite character. Kidder, who is probably most famous in the cinematic world for her work as Lois Lane in the "Superman" series films - "Superman II" (1980) saw her at her best, in my opinion - gets some of this film's best lines and also provides some of the best comedic moments. This is another aspect of "Black Christmas" that I find so ingenious: to create so many likable characters so it's much more tragic when the Unseen Killer begins offing them. It's just a shame that its many, many like-minded imitators (or even its 2006 remake) over the years didn't follow the same pattern."Black Christmas" is a film that I've wanted to see for a long time. All the good things I've heard about it are true. This is one scary fright flick that helped give birth to a new sub-genre of horror, and later influenced "Halloween," "Friday the 13th" (1980) and my favorite slasher flick of all time, "A Nightmare on Elm Street" (1984). It's also pretty funny, which admittedly, I was unprepared for, and made my appreciation for this film even greater. But make no mistake, the first order of business in "Black Christmas" is horror, and scaring the living daylights out of you, which it does in spades with suspense, easily identifiable and memorable characters (especially Margot Kidder - go, Margot!), Bob Clark's sharp direction, and minimal gore. So don't let its imitators fool you. "Black Christmas" is one holiday-themed horror film that has you re-thinking those yuletide celebrations.I dare you to watch it alone.10/10

Review title: It's won't make you jump but it still will creepy you out!
Review_body: Black Christmas (1974) re-watch as one of the earliness slasher movies, even few years before big know slasher movie Halloween. I am little shocked that it did not get a sequel and I a, clad it didn't.If you are looking for slasher to make you Jump, this movie won't do it at all, there no real scare scenes to make you jump however, this movie dose not try to scare you at all in that way,Some may find this movie little out dated now and s tad boring if have already seen other slasher movies, like Friday and Halloween movies. However I found this to me very intense, they did, add some dark humour intothe mix, which was nice and didn't feel campy at all, worked really well with the rest of the movie. At Christmas, at the sorority house, girl are unaware that stranger, who making phone calls as broken into the house. We don't get to see who that person is at all, that makes little bit more creepy, as you have no idea who or why, his in this house for most of the movie, you do get to see parts of him in the movie. The deaths in this movie are not gory or anything but there are really good death scenes , which I think are way before there time. I love the final scenes of the movie, how is pans around the whole house and still mangers to keep tension until very last second of the movie. The acting was really good from everyone in whole cast, there maybe one or two that acted a bit over the top, it didn't bother to much. 9 out of 10

Review title: A Moody, Efficient Time Capsule of Holiday Horror
Review_body: Plagued by dirty phone calls, a houseful of rowdy sorority girls barks back at the perpetrator and prepares for the holiday break, unaware that a psychotic killer looms in the attic. When one sister goes missing, local police don't give the case much thought until it's almost too late.Written and directed by Bob Clark (who would, amusingly, go on to direct the perennial holiday classic A Christmas Story almost a decade later), Black Christmas is an efficient, low budget proto-slasher with a nice blend of character moments, tension-breaking humor and moody suspense. Rather than observing in fist-balled terror from a distance, the audience takes a direct, active role in the murders thanks to an persistent hand-held, killer's-eye perspective during the bloodiest scenes. While an obvious gimmick, this approach does add a unique dimension to the screen and lends the killings an intimate, face-to-face quality that feels different to its many peers and imitators.The cast is surprisingly human and relatable for the genre, from the most experienced players (Margot Kidder as a wise-cracking, foul-mouthed lush) to the relative rookies (first-timer Lynne Griffin, whose last suffocated gasp is pictured on all the promo materials), and tackles a number of social taboos between all the stabbings. The creepy phone calls still hold their own, too, a powerful reminder of just how invasive and personal an intimidating voice could feel in the days before voicemail or caller ID.

Review title: I loved this morbid BLACK CHRISTMAS .
Review_body:
Lonely sorority sisters who are having a Christmas party in their sorority house during the Christmas break.
Peter (Keir Dullea) is a mad-killer who terrorizes the women by making threatening telephone calls. As the body count mounts.Directed by the director of A Christmas Story. So he made an excellent Christmas horror/slasher flick 9 years before A Christmas Story Awesome And the movie is excellent as well. Kidder's performance of the drunken, outspoken Barb is fantastic, followed closely by Romeo & Juliet's Olivia Hussey, who is truly beautiful in this movie. The camera work and direction is first rate, the first person perspective, heavy breathing effect. There were times that I felt the tension of the girls and I wondered what would happen next. I was genuinely uneasy. Creepy AF . I loved this morbid BLACK CHRISTMAS .

Hussey and various other girls are living in a gorgeous snow covered sorority house getting reading to leave college for Christmas. One of them goes missing and it is soon clear that a killer is on the loose.Predating the more famous Halloween by 4 years, this is generally now acknowledged to be the first slasher movie and a cracking one, worthy of Hitchcock himself. The humour is wonderful and dark, the killer is a really nasty piece of work, the cast - Kidder, Dullea, Hindle and particularly the great John Saxon are on fine form. Above all this is a genuinely nerve tingling and a good police thriller that maintains a strong pervasive sense of fear and evil at Christmas - whilst still oddly feeling very Christmassy. Watch it on Christmas Eve.

Not a bad slasher film (though there is precious little slashing shown). Director Bob Clark creates an occasionally eerie film starring Olivia Hussey as a college girl whose sorority sisters are being bumped off by a lunatic. The crazed killer enjoys making increasingly bizarre crank calls after each slaying. Needless to say, Hussey (nor anyone else) catches on to what's happening. It's creepy, features a lot of haunting images and Hussey is terrific. Among those playing sorority girls are 26-year old Margot Kidder & 27-year old Andrea Martin. Kidder is the foul-mouthed drunkard while a pre-SCTV Martin is the Earth mother. Keir Dullea & John Saxon are in it too as is Marian Waldman, who adds a lot of kick as the soused house mother.

Sorority sisters are terrorized by obscene phone calls in their sorority house at Christmas. Eventually, there is a murder. "Black Christmas" is a whodunit but with a twist ending that I find mildly dissatisfying.Much of the plot consists of routine chitchat and the comings and goings of the girls. So viewers will need to find one or more characters entertaining in some way to maintain interest in the plot. The elderly house mom who likes to sneak a drink from a cleverly hidden bottle provides comic relief. What these people don't know, but we viewers do, is that the killer is somewhere inside the large multistory house, watching and stalking them.Many scenes take place at night, and most are dimly lit, with spooky side lighting. The usual Christmas carols, peaceful and reassuring, are punctuated by the discordant sounds of piano strings that signal that the killer is nearby and/or active in some way. Adding to the tension and terror are sound effects, including the whistling of wind through the trees, footsteps of the killer, and his hesitant breathing. Several scenes are photographed from the killer's POV. Casting and acting are generally acceptable.The subplot about the outdoor search party seemed distracting and irrelevant to me; it could have been left out. Scenes at the police station also detract from the appropriately claustrophobic atmosphere of the sorority house.Despite an unsatisfying ending, the excellent color photography, music, and sound effects throughout the plot magnify suspense and mystery. Which renders "Black Christmas" a must-see for Horror genre viewers. And the film inaugurates a script formula that was so successful that it has been copied many times by other movies since this film first appeared some forty years ago, to render it a must-see for film historians.

25 Days Of Christmas Cheer: Day 13Before John Carpenter's Halloween, there was Black Christmas, and no it's not a Tyler Perry holiday special. It's a slick little slasher set in a 1970's sorority house during Christmas break, when many of the girls have gone home. Suddenly mysterious phone calls start to plague the ones still there, and one by one a murderous, unseen prowler starts to murder them. The phone calls themselves aren't overly threatening, but instead sound like the nonsensical babbling of someone who is a couple reindeer short of a sleigh, making them all the scarier. I remember watching this years ago and being far more creeped out at the phone calls rather than the actual murders. That is a perfect example of using atmosphere to get under your audience's skin rather than straight up gore, and a testament to the fright films of the 70's and 80's, which really seemed to have all the atmosphere vs. gore dials in the right positions. This positively drips with tension and ambiance. The silences in between screams are almost deafening in their vacuous anticipation of terror to come, and strange as it sounds, there's actually a nice Christmas-y feeling in places where the fear hasn't yet struck, despite it being a horror movie. Olivia Hussey plays Jess, the main target of the killer with appropriate wide eyed intensity, Margot Kidder is briefly seen as the house mother, and horror regular John Saxon shows up as a suspicious Police Chief as well. I'd say this one achieves a state of suspense and atmosphere that can step up to the same plate as Halloween any day, it's just a little overlooked I suppose. The house they are in is the perfect setting, a sprawling Yuletide manor of creaky hallways, desolated basements, dark, dingy attic space and an uneasy thrum of awaiting gloom that gives the words Silent Night a new meaning. The poor girls just never know when a shrill telephone ring will slice through the eerie corridors, forcing them to answer it and hear an unnerving voice warble out "It's me, Billy" on the other end. PS: avoid the remake at all costs. It takes everything that was creepy and restrained about this classic and turns it into a disgusting nightmare.

Review title: As Chilling And Somber As A Cold Winter's Night.
Review_body: I watched this film during the holiday season a few years back, and have come to the conclusion that "Black Christmas" is a neglected classic, and (in my opinion) is the first and best slasher film ever made. Guaranteed, fans of John Carpenter's "Halloween" will love this film, some may find they love it even more than "Halloween". And even though I thought I'd never say that, after viewing "Black Christmas" a few times, I found myself enjoying it much more."Black Christmas" starts off with a Christmas party at a sorority house. While the festivities are taking place, a stranger is breaking into the attic upstairs, while the unknowing sorority sisters are enjoying themselves. The phone rings, and we are introduced to Jessica (Olivia Hussey), our main character. A strange person on the phone makes obscene comments, speaking in different voices while the sorority sisters listen in disgust. As the sisters flood out, all leaving to visit family and friends and whatnot, only a few are left at the sorority house, among them are - Jessica, Barb (Margot Kidder), and Phyl (Andrea Martin). Clare (Lynne Griffin), a fellow sorority sister, has gone missing, and Clare's father comes to investigate along with the help of law enforcement and her friends. The strange phone calls continue, and get more and more disturbing as time goes by, until Jessica is forced to call the police. Could it be her boyfriend, Peter (Keir Dullea), playing some sort of sick joke? Or is someone watching the helpless girls from within the house? As the holiday nears, the psychotic killer sets in motion his bloody agenda, while the local police try and track him down before more murders are committed.Before Bob Clark went on to direct the family holiday classic "A Christmas Story", he took a darker look at the holiday season with this hidden gem. "Black Christmas" is a masterpiece horror film, and surprisingly predates the classics by many years, such as "Halloween" and "Friday the 13th", which get most of the credit for "creating" the slasher genre, when in fact this little Canadian chiller started it all. The plot was very original at the time, and contains some very scary moments - the scenes in the attic with the killer are among the scariest and strangest scenes I've ever watched, and the phone calls are flat out bizarre. The movie reeks a very dark, foreboding atmosphere (despite it taking place during the holidays) that never lets up throughout the film's entirety, as it slowly builds suspense before reaching the climax. It takes place during Christmastime, which honestly doesn't matter to the plot (it could've taken place at any time of the year), but the fact that it's set during such a joyous, festive season gives it a little more of a sinister quality, and makes it a perfect holiday horror movie.The acting in this film was excellent. Olivia Hussey is our lead, and she plays her character with vulnerability and innocence, putting the audience on her side the whole way. Margot Kidder plays the loudmouth, drunk sorority girl, and is also excellent in her performance, being a boisterous yet a likable character at the same time. Her character is probably the most memorable of the bunch. Andrea Martin plays Phyl, the quiet but friendly girl, and is also very good in her role. And Keir Dullea plays Jess's suspicious boyfriend well - the audience isn't sure if they should consider him a suspect or not, and he plays that perfectly. The rest of the cast includes numerous Canadian performers, all whom turn in convincing performances. There is even a little comedy thrown into the mix, an example being the alcoholic sorority housemother, Mrs. Mac., and her witty one-liners. The humor is subtle and is easily overlooked by the movie's grim demeanor, but it's in there for sure. The movie also contains some very creative death scenes (especially Barb's glass unicorn death, and the plastic attack in the closet), but even though these are present, it's really not a gory film, we mostly see the aftermath. The deaths aren't very bloody, tending to rely much more on sound, which is equally effective. One of the major things I admire about this movie is that the audience never knows who the killer is - he's kept a mystery, even at the shocking conclusion - the audience ever really gets a resolution and we aren't given any answers, something that I find to be very effective. I like the fact that we are given so little information on the villain, because it makes his presence much more terrifying. The tricky camera-work prevents us from ever seeing his face, in fact all we really see is his body shape, hair style, and his hands. We hear his voice though, as he harasses the sorority girls over the phone, muttering vulgar and disturbing phrases and making death threats (which were very well done, I might add). Even scarier, is the fact that he's hiding in the attic the entire time. This movie completely shatters the idea of feeling safe in your home... you can lock your doors and windows, but what if the killer is already inside the house, and you just don't know about it? Very scary concept. To sum things up, "Black Christmas" is an overlooked classic that deserves so much more recognition than it's gotten over the years - I'm sure any horror fan would love to find it in their stocking. Hopefully the upcoming remake will gain the original film some long-deserved attention. "Black Christmas" is the ultimate holiday-horror film for fans of the genre, and is the best slasher movie ever as far as I'm concerned. An underrated masterpiece. 10/10.

Review title: Memorable Horror Film was ahead of its time before John Carpenter's Halloween was released.
Review_body: During the Christmas Holidays season. Members of a sorority house for young woman receives, what they thought was a obscene phone call and the calls gets seriously disturbing each time. When one of the sorority girls is missing. They become scared and they wonder, what is going on not realizing that the deranged psychopath is in their house.Directed by Bob Clark (Porky 1 & 2, A Christmas Story, Murder by Decree) made a extremely bizarre but original horror film. The film was release a few years before John Carpenter's Halloween was release. Black Christmas and Halloween have some similarities in the storytelling.The latest DVD has an fine anamorphic Widescreen (1.78:1) transfer and an digitally remastered-Dolby Digital 5.1 Surround Sound.The new 2006 DVD re-release has new features like new interviews with the cast and crew. The film has a strong cast like Olivia Hussey (Franco Zeffifelli's Romeo and Juliet), Keir Dullea (2001:A Space Odyssey), John Saxon (Enter the Dragon) and Andrea Martin (Cannibal Girls). The film is well made, it's has the right atmosphere and it's quite frightening. One of the best horror films of that era, especially when it doesn't end with the easy way out. Although the real stealing performance is Margot Kidder (The Superman Films) as a Vulgar, Alcoholic Kid with Asthma. Screenplay by Roy Moore. Followed by a remake. (****/*****).

Review title: Decent (But Kind Of Dull) Mid-70's Slasher
Review_body: Before everyone comes gunning for me for my relatively low review of this "classic" slasher - let me start by embarrassing myself by admitting that although I consider myself knowledgeable in most things horror-related - this is one of the classic films that I just watched recently...by recently I mean last night. I know, I know...how could this be, how can you be a "true horror fan", blah, blah, blah - well kiss my ass, I just never got around to this one (or tons of others that I'm now making an effort to go back and revisit...). So with that out of the way, I'll give you my honest opinion...BLACK Christmas is not a bad film by any means. It definitely deserves it's place as a classic slasher film. But, with all of the similar films that I HAVE seen, although BLACK Christmas is obviously one of the originators, it's still like many of the other films I've seen in the slasher genre - and personally the 70's-80's slasher films are not among my favorite of the horror-genre overall. I prefer the more exploitative films of that time frame as opposed to the suspenseful horror films of the time - so my mid-grade rating of this film is based strictly on my own personal opinion...The long and short of this one is about a psycho that sneaks into a girls dorm and starts making obscene phone calls and picking off the "tenents" one-by-one. That's pretty much it.Not necessarily a bad premise - I've seen films work with a lot less, but like I said before, there's not much in BLACK Christmas that I haven't seen before. There is a noticeable lack of gore, which is another gripe of mine with the slasher films of this time-frame (yes, I'm one of those...) and the film dragged in a lot of places. Anyone who is into the classic slashers should definitely check this one out, but I personally just didn't find it as "scary" or enthralling as most others - sorry... 6/10

The attic of a girl's sorority house during the holiday season becomes a nesting place for a grunting maniac, who scales the trellis one evening and begins to murder women amidst the snow and good cheer of Christmas carols. The madman uses the telephone to call the girls and taunts them with noises and deranged ramblings in a very unsettling manner. Olivia Hussey stars as the main innocent girl who is on the receiving end, with Margot Kidder as one of her no-nonsense loudmouth friends. The dependable John Saxon takes on the part of a police lieutenant who tries to help.The first thing I want to say about the film is that it's not unlike everything we've seen since in later slasher movies. Every cliché is present: the heavy-breathing psycho, the obscene phone calls; the terrified girl on the other end who is incredibly stupid; the grisly murder techniques; the killer's point of view shots... There is a sense of the familiar here, and I was almost prepared to give the movie a half-star less rating until I reminded myself .. this film came first, BEFORE all those other clones. Director Bob Clark has said that John Carpenter liked this film, and we can see some of its influence in Carpenter's HALLOWEEN, which often gets all the credit. But it's not the fault of the more rare BLACK Christmas that it spawned all the copycats which make it seem like one of them itself; I'd imagine this trend setter felt much more cutting edge in 1974, and that's why I gave it the extra boost it deserves. There is good and bad here ... I have yet to enjoy Margot Kidder in anything, and her drunken sleaze-mouth character here is annoying, as is the fat female den mom who's got a bottle of booze hidden everywhere in the house ... but not to worry. The killer, who's identity is a mystery, manages to be scary just through his eerie phone calls and creepy sounds. The idea of all this gruesome mayhem as a parallel to the joyous Christmas events happening on the side achieves the proper disturbing effect. The look of the large spooky house from the outside, complete with the image in the attic window, is haunting. The movie is not completely original, but it deserves extra credit for setting up so many now-patented and tried and true horror film clichés. *** out of ****

Review title: Still a good movie, but not a horror classic
Review_body: I enjoyed my first viewing of Bob Clark's "Black Christmas" more than my most recent viewing. I still feel that the film is an accomplished piece of work and established a structure and screen language that have been much imitated. The characters are intelligent and screenwriter Roy Moore even takes a shot at the abortion issue.The obscene phone calls made by the killer are truly obscene (much use of the word "c**t"), and his psychotic rants are rather amusing, if not a little disturbing. The killer's POV, which opens the movie, is effective, and the image of a suffocated victim lurking by a window is a memorable one.The film doesn't scare me, though, or make me uneasy. Perhaps I've seen too many horror films. I can't fault Clark for his direction or Carl Zitter for his atmospheric score, more a soundscape than a traditionally structured series of compositions. I simply found the film a bit slow the last time around.Clark's "Deathdream" is one of my favorite horror films of all time (see my review), and it was made before "Christmas". Certainly, "Christmas" is a larger scale production, but, for me, it does not possess the intimacy of "Deathdream" and the sense of crawling horror. It plays more like a mystery than a horror film and lacks the tragedy that made "Deathdream" so effective. Bob Clark may have thought so, too, because "Christmas"'s score sounds exactly like "Deathdream" (same composer), there is a creepy rocking chair (like the one "Andy" used in Deathdream"), and the house exteriors look like the house exteriors in, yes, you guessed it, "Deathdream".Still, a very good movie, but not, for me, a horror classic.

Before I sat down to watch "Black Christmas" (1975) for the first time, director Bob Clark had been two for two with me. I had loved his previous two flicks--the zombie gut-muncher "Children Shouldn't Play With Dead Things" and his living-dead Vietnam vet horror comedy "Deathdream," both from 1972--and so was very stoked to see "Black Christmas," a film with a great rep and a loving cult behind it. Now that I have finally seen the film, I'm aware of what this cult has known for decades: This movie, besides being highly influential, is also intelligently scripted, well acted by all, deliberately paced and, ultimately, extremely suspenseful. Concerning a psychopathic nutjob who not only makes obscene phone calls to a sorority house (possibly the creepiest phone calls in screen history; you'll be thanking heaven for modern-day "caller ID"), but who also hides in the attic and does some occasional butchering, the film is the template for a raft of more famous slasher flicks that followed. Margot Kidder, Andrea Martin and especially the gorgeous Olivia Hussey (I just love the way she says "Hello") are all very fine, and John Saxon, here playing a police lieutenant, gets a chance to show how very appealing he can be when NOT playing coldhearted dirtbags. I must confess that the first time I watched this film, the open-ended finale left me a little annoyed (I guess I needed a bit more closure); I didn't mind this ending the second time I watched the picture, however, and even thought it kinda cool and freaky. To make things even better, the "Special Edition" DVD that I just watched comes with almost two hours' (!) worth of interviews, plus other features. It is truly a godsend for all members of the "Black Christmas" cult.

Review title: Remade again and again, imitated one film after another, Black Christmas still holds its own
Review_body:
A provocative and well acted thriller, Black Christmas is not only original and well executed, but timelessly clever and quite fun to watch. I'll start with the films flaws, as there isn't much of them. I never found the film to be super entertaining in anyway, there are a few dull moments. However, it is very easy and engaging to watch, as the mystery at hands become more and more interesting as the film plays out. The film can be a bit tough to follow at times as well, as there are quite a few things going on at once, but perhaps the biggest flaw of the film is also something relatively small, that being the sound quality. Its irritating at times how loud it can be and how quiet it can be at other times. I'm not entirely sure if it is the quality of the film itself, or the film quality due to the streaming provider I watched it on, but a remastered version would be nice. Besides that, the film is quite smart. It isn't like other horror films at its time, not like the ones it is claimed to inspire. This is not a slasher film, contrary to what many believe, though it does serve as an inspiration for them. What this film has going for it though that other films that imitated it lacked, is the sense of psychological horror that it had going for it, and the unsureness of it all, which I always find quite brilliant. The cinematography is quite good, and very nostalgic, and the acting in it is quite good as well. Standouts for me would have to be first Margot Kidder as Barb, who provides an incredibly underrated performance, Olivia Hussey, John Saxon, Marian Waldman, and Keir Dullea. In the end, Black Christmas is a shining star among 70's horror, and despite it being nearly half a century old, it still remains to be frightening even today.
My Rating: 9.25/10

Bob Clark, whose life was cut short earlier this year by a freak accident, will always be a genre hero; after all, this is the man who gave us the controversial Vietnam-horror allegory "Deathdream" (1974), the playful Romero homage "Children Shouldn't Play With Dead Things" (1972), and the celebrated holiday comedy, "A Christmas Story" (1983). "Black Christmas," a seasonal slasher that predated "Halloween" by 4 years, establishes the formula with grace, subtlety, and skill, threaded with Clark's strong sense of small-town Americana (shots are composed with the biographical artistry of a Norman Rockwell painting). An obscene phone-caller is harassing the girls of a sorority house; one of the girls and the housemother (an inspired comic performance by Marian Waldman) go missing; and our protagonist, Jess (Olivia Hussey) is looking to get an abortion, much to the objection of her boyfriend Peter (Keir Dullea). Happy holidays, indeed! Roy Moore's screenplay takes a simple premise and lets the layers play out naturally--the collegiate and small-town humor still resonates today, and the characters are played with a minimum of exaggeration (as I said about the Clark-produced "Deranged," we feel like we KNOW these people); my only complaint is that not all of the characters are well-integrated, and some disappear for long stretches at a time. Otherwise, we have some iconic figures that clearly influenced Carpenter's babysitters: Hussey as the Final Girl, Margot Kidder as the hard-drinking joker, and Andrea Martin as the straight- yet-slightly-gawky good girl. The legendary John Saxon is his usual excellent self as the local police captain. And Clark/Cronenberg regular Les Carlson ("Deranged," "A Christmas Story," "Videodrome") has a small role that is the crux of most of the film's suspense (he's the phone-company employee tracking the source of the obscene calls through switchboards as high as the stacks at the Library of Congress). "Black Christmas" is one of the best slashers out there, and certainly one of the most influential (next to "Psycho")--raise some eyebrows at this year's holiday gathering by putting this on right after "A Christmas Story" (and vive la difference!).

It's easy to see and understand why Black Christmas has such a large cult following, not only is it an influential film (see 'Halloween') for the many slasher films to come, but it's also an exercise in minimalism, one of my favorite things about this film is the killer never gets a reveal, it could be anybody, anywhere, how long has it been since you've check the upstairs? It's a spine tingling thriller from a confident director at the top of his game, along side a great cast of scream queens, although they may not all be able to fully save the convienence laden script, there's just a few too many plot holes to make this a true stand out contender, but as a whole Black Christmas will satisfy those slasher cravings in an otherwise slasher-free holiday season.

This film is one that I'll admit, I really did care for the first couple times that I've seen it. I don't want to make it sound like I hated the film, but it just wasn't one that really hit me. When I saw that it was playing at my local theater, I decided that I would check it out on the big screen to see if that altered my thoughts. The synopsis is during their Christmas break, a group of sorority girls are stalked by a stranger.We start out inside of a sorority house in college. Christmas is right around the corner and the winter break is starting. They're having a party and a good time going on inside. We then see someone stalking outside of the house. They climb up the side and enter into the attic through a window.Inside we see that one of the sisters, Barb (Margot Kidder), notices that the front door is open. She closes and goes back to the party. The other sisters are Jess (Olivia Hussey), Phyl (Andrea Martin) and Clare Harrison (Lynne Griffin). Barb has a bit of a drinking problem. There's a phone call for her and it's her mother who scolds her for drinking too. She tells her that she can't do the original plans and invites her and her sisters to come skiing. Everyone agrees except for Clare. Barb and her do not get along as Clare is more reserved. She calls her out for being a virgin and Clare goes to her room.The phone then rings and they have been getting prank called by someone who does heavy breathing and says some inappropriate things. Barb calls the person out this time and he yells some things are her. The house mother, Mrs. Mac (Marian Waldman) then shows up. She has bottles of alcohol hidden throughout the house and takes drinks whenever she can, which is quite funny.Clare plays with the house cat in her room while packing and hears something in the closet. The crazy person is in there and he attacks her. He kills her with a plastic bag and pulls her up into the attic. It should be pointed out that he sets her up in a rocking chair with a baby in her arm right in front of a window. He rocks her as well as speaks with her, but we don't get a good look at him.Clare's father, Mr. Harrison (James Edmond) arrives the next day to collect her. She doesn't show up to where they're supposed to meet. He's not very happy with what he is seeing from her sorority sisters, Mrs. Mac or the place that she is living. He also says that he didn't send her to college to drink and be loose.Jess then goes to see her boyfriend, Peter (Keir Dullea). The night before she called him and he was short with her. He lives in a conservatory and he wants to be a concert pianist, so he doesn't get a lot of sleep as he practices a lot. He has a big performance later that day. Jess drops on him that she is pregnant, but she is going to have an abortion. This upsets him that she made this decision without him and he wants to change her mind. She doesn't want to hear it thoughClare is not at the Christmas Party and this makes Mr. Harrison quite upset. They go to the police, but they won't do anything at first. It isn't until her boyfriend, Chris Hayden (Art Hindle) comes down to the throw a fit that Lt. Ken Fuller (John Saxon) gets involved. There's a 13 year old girl who goes missing around this time as well. A search results in a grisly discovery and Jess reports the obscene phone calls to the police. This leads them to tapping the phone so they can trace where the calls are coming from. It leads to quite a shocking discovery as we see other members of this house fall victim to this madman.I can say, much like how I felt after my second viewing, I do enjoy this film more and more with each viewing. After my second viewing I did know that this film is interesting is that it is regarded as influencing Halloween. There was almost consideration of making more horror films around holidays like this. Something I have to give this film is that basing it around Christmas is great. You have students going away for the holidays or just going home for them, so people can go missing and no one notices it.The killer in this film is quite creepy as well. The prank calls he is making are quite unnerving if I'm going to be perfectly honest. What I find interesting is the remake uses the things he says in this one to expand the story of the film for that one. I almost like that we never really figure out why some of things are said or who the names correlate to. I do like that he incorporates conversations from the house though, because it points to Peter as the prime suspect.I've heard debates whether this film is a slasher or if it is proto-slasher. There aren't very many kills in this one. They're spaced out quite a bit and it really focuses more on the mystery of who is doing it. That almost makes it feel more like a giallo. The issue then becomes though the ending of the movie. I don't want to spoil it, but that doesn't really mesh with how those films normally end. This does give us quite a bit of police procedural.There are still some glaring issues with this film for me though. The first is how no one discovers the body of Clare. She is positioned right in front of a window and we shown that you can see her from the street. I get there could be frost on the window, but at the end of the film, no one checks the attic. This is just kind of laughable to me after everything that goes down. The next issue I have will be with the pacing.I've already kind of touched on this. I just feel this film is a bit boring. It gets right into it, we get our introductions to the characters and the first murder is right there within the first 15 minutes. We do go through quite a bit of a lull before anything else happens. I like the investigation aspect of trying to find the missing girl. We just get a lot of drama aspects and kind of shy away from the horror for just a bit too long. I do think that the film does find its way and builds tension, but just some lulls I have issues with.The acting of the film is good. I absolutely love Hussey. She is quite young in this film, but I love her determination here. This film is actually ahead of its time here as she is a modern woman that is going to abort her pregnancy because she isn't ready for motherhood yet. This is actually very relevant now and she won't be told what to do by Peter. Dullea I think is good and it is interesting, because he really shows us toxic masculinity. I get part of it is the time this film came out, but that doesn't change it. Kidder is solid as the drunk and actually brings some good humor, the same with Waldman. It was fun seeing Saxon and Hindle in this film. I think that the rest of the cast really do round out the film for what was needed as well.I'll move next to the effects of the film. To be honest, they really aren't a lot of them as they do hide quite a bit. I do like the look of Clare after she's been killed. The blood in the film is a bit orange, but I chalk that up to being the era of the film. Mrs. Mac's death is also pretty cool as well. I'd say that overall, they were done practically and look fine to me.Now with that said, I give this film a lot of respect for its significance and its place in history. My rating does seem to be keep coming up with every viewing I have of it, so that is it too. I like the idea of this film, but I would have liked them to go a bit farther. I don't need everything explained, I just like more than what we got. It does get a bit boring as it focuses on some things that can bog it down. The climax and ending are good. The acting really does carry the film and the depth of the main characters is still socially relevant. It is a bit light on the effects, but they're done practically so that really does help. The soundtrack of the film really doesn't stand out, the Christmas music does set the mood of the time of year. I do think that this is a good movie and actually, it does have some socially commentary that is relevant. I would recommend this even if you don't like horror as it is has a good mystery.

I tried to watch this movie many times, but something always had to stop me. Yesterday I finally could see it entirely. From the get go it seems to be an extremely creepy movie, mostly because of the dark version of "Silent Night", but after some moments I could see it wouldn't be that scary. Plot is interesting and sometimes even funny, mainly because of those old people saying such bad words all the time-- come on, old women from a convent aren't supposed to be that rude. What bores me the most is that it took too long for something nice to happen, along with that annoying telephone ringing all the time. However, last scenes are suffocating. That scene with a girl in bed, supposedly sleeping, creeped me out, since ANYTHING could happen to scare the spectator. Happily, directors in that era weren't that mean with us. Surely this film inspired "When a stranger calls" and some others, but it is no big deal after all.

Review title: You couldn't pay me enough money to get me to go in that attic.
Review_body: Random thoughts about this chilling classic: Several years before John Carpenter's wildly overrated Halloween, there was Bob Clark's Black Christmas, quite possibly the best, most underrated horror/ thriller ever produced. Presumably, Carpenter shares this adoration, as Halloween is, at times, a scene-for-scene ripoff.Sweet girl Claire is the first one to be killed in a surprisingly brutal burst of violence by a psycho killer stalking a sorority house at Christmastime. Her dead body, with a plastic coat bag wrapped over her head, is a chilling sight (one which was, unfortunately, revealed on the front cover of the original video box!) Her father then shows up to search for her, around the same time another girl is attacked in the park, and ..... a string of obscene, threatening phone calls plague the missing girl's sorority house.Margot Kidder's character amusingly gives the psycho caller a tongue lashing of his own, before he very calmly states, "I'm going to kill you," and softly hangs up the phone. Chilling and intentionally humorous, not an easy combination to pull off. Indeed, the film's first two thirds are also played largely for intentional humour, to give the audience a chance to breathe in between acts of violence by the unseen killer - which only make his violent outbursts even more shocking.Peter's right eye brightly lit by a lamp, while the rest of his face is largely darkened in shadow, as Jess tells him she's pregnant; then later, we see the killer's left eye brightly lit twice, while the rest of him is in shadows. Silhouette of killer's hair looks similar to Peter, but his clothing is different. Was that director Bob Clark showing us the killer, or providing us with a red herring? And why did Peter go around at the back of the house, and smash his way through the basement window to get to Jess, immediately after the killer was chasing her? Good timing on his part, or incredibly poor timing? One of my favourite scenes has John Saxon's Lt. Fuller walking into a pitch black piano room, silhouetted in the doorway, switching the lights on to see Peter's piano, smashed to bits. Fuller walks toward it in complete silence, and we can see the gears turning over in his mind as he imagines the possibilities of Peter being a violent killer.Strikingly beautiful photography in the wintry setting, and inside the sorority house, is another major asset.Hauntingly beautiful, minimalist music score (which, according to composer Carl Zittrer, was accomplished by lightly strumming wooden forks over piano wire) added to its already odd atmosphere, without distracting from it.I cannot think of anything I would change about this film, nor can I think of any other movie with so many unanswered questions, yet which still contains such a satisfying ending- an ending which still sends a chill down my spine. As we recap the scenes of the crimes, the telephone starts to ring and continues endlessly in the silent night.That ending recap, incidentally, was copied almost identically four years later by John Carpenter in Halloween. A vastly inferior film, in my opinion.

Over the years the "Halloween" "Friday the 13th" and "A Nightmare on Elm St" films have become the Monster Movies of the late 20th century. Instead of having "Dracula" "Frankenstein" and "The Mummy" we had "Michael Myers" "Jason Voorhees" and "Freddy Kruger". Well a few years before those movie villains hit the screen there was another killer who packed a powerful punch his name was Billy and he was terrifying in the 1974 film "Black Christmas". To me he is the scariest man in movie history.This 1974 film is not well known. It is however 10x better than most other horror movies pf the 1970's and 1980's! This film has many things that seemed to of inspired "Halloween". The opening shots and set up were almost identical to "Halloween" which was released 4 years later. In this film As winter break begins, a group of sorority sisters, including Jess (Olivia Hussey) and the often inebriated Barb (Margot Kidder), begin to receive anonymous, lascivious phone calls. Initially, Barb eggs the caller on, but stops when he responds threateningly. Soon, Barb's friend Claire (Lynne Griffin) goes missing from the sorority house, and a local adolescent girl is murdered, leading the girls to suspect a serial killer is on the loose.
