But no one realizes just how near the culprit is.This film developed a cult following and was later remade. The original however is still an edge of your seat thriller! If you like horror films then get this. You will love it!

Review title: A tad overrated, but still a great movie
Review_body: "Black Christmas" is a pretty disappointing proto-slasher.**SPOILERS**Gathering for a Christmas party, Jess Bradford, (Olivia Hussey) Barbara Coard, (Margot Kidder) Phyllis Carlson, (Andrea Martin) and Claire Harrison, (Lynne Griffin) along with Mrs. MacHenry, (Marian Waldman) all prepare for their Sorority party. As the night goes on, they are continued to be inundated with a series of obscene phone calls that many say have been going on for awhile. As they take place, they also find that some of the other sorority members have gone missing, and pleading with Lieutenant Kenneth Fuller, (John Saxon) does nothing as he claims to be more prioritized with another case. Forced back in the sorority house as there's nothing the police can do, the calls continue and the others disappear, making the others realize that there's something wrong with the calls. Checking back in with the police, they realize that there's a killer in the house and try to get out before they encounter him.The Good News: There wasn't a whole lot to this one, as it was surprisingly disappointing. The main source this one gets right is the mystery of the killer. We never see the killer's face aside from a hand and a spastic looking eyeball. We never learn the killer's true motives or identity, or why he decided to plague this particular sorority house. That is just eerie and really makes the killer a lot more fearsome when the identity remains a secret. The film does a spectacular job of making the killer feel really threatening without doing a whole lot. Even more important is that, early in the film, the killer establishes a trademark method of operation, which is maintained rather faithfully throughout the movie. Immediately after dispatching a victim, he immediately places an obscene phone call to the house. That works wonders, especially when it's revealed that this has been going on prior to the beginning of the film. During the first phone call, one remarks that it's the moaner again the, meaning that he has called before. This fits with the later fact that several townspeople have been raped on the college campus during the recent weeks. There's also the fact that the killer starts toying with them in incredibly perverse ways and the tormenting gets more and more vulgar as time goes on. That allows for more fear from the killer, and all of the calls actually go a long way; as well as the other tactics, to make the killer something to be feared. When it switches over to the later calls, it gets even more disturbing and even more furious. From this point on, the caller exhibits obvious symptoms of multiple-personality-disorder, and we hear him switching between three different voices within the course of one call, often times the different voices even overlap one another. It's a neat trick, and again goes even further towards making the killer the ultimate creep. From the moments where just the POV is seen running across the landscape with just the breathing voice heard to the sense of humor displayed with the strangulation gag that comes from the simply mind-blowing original finale, the killer here is one of the best in the genre. A couple of the attacks are pretty cool as well, especially the bedroom one where the screams are drowned out by the caroling group downstairs as well as one where a victim is lured in and attacked with a giant pulley system. These here provide the film's only good points.The Bad News: This one here wasn't all that impressive, with it's laurels really resting on a couple of areas. This one has such a dull and boring middle section that most of the problems are found here. The film decides to stack in as many different scenes and subplots in here to stretch the film out that after a while it gets incredibly dull and boring. From the pregnancy subplot that has nothing to do at all with any of the film's proceedings once it's given to the missing towns-person going missing along with the search by the police, this film is super padded out to ridiculous lengths. These take up a large amount of the film's time to take in with certain areas of the plots that contain nothing of importance in the final count. There's also the fact that this one is a complete mystery surrounding the killer. While it's nice to finally get a mystery, not even being sure of the killer's name is taking it a bit too far. This occurs in a conversation as a line that the person on the other end spouts, yet nothing is confirmed as to whether it's the actual name or whether it's a person who caused the psycho to go homicidal. Other names are dropped in the course of the conversations, but again, not even having something as simplistic as a name is a big shame in the film. Other factors in here, from the reasoning behind the rampage to the motive of selecting this particular sorority, manage to force into the viewer such a state of confusion that there's a really volley of emotions over being scared and annoyed over the killer. The fact that a lot of questionable tactics are put into play over what he tries to do with them or not is another big factor with this one, and in the end, this one ends up feeling very disappointing.The Final Verdict: With a lot of dull moments in this one and a couple of somewhat decent moments, this one comes across as a merely disappointing effort. This is one really for those who have a big fascination with the early-going slashers or are into the film's positives, while those who prefer faster-paced fare should seek caution.Rated R: Graphic Language and Graphic Violence

Review title: It's a Lot Better than the Remake
Review_body: This 98-minute film is a stark and stylish horror/thriller that turns everyone's favorite time of the year inside out. Olivia Hussey and Margot Kidder star among an ill-fated houseful of sorority sisters celebrating the holiday season. Festivities turn fatal when obscene phone calls break the serenity and it becomes clear that a psychopath is stalking the house.Instead of watching this movie first, I watched the remake of it, which was horrible. Watching this, I was surprised how many small body counts there are compared to the remake but I wasn't surprised it was less bloody, which is a good thing. The violence, which was the problem in the remake, does not turn you off.What I like about this movie is that it focuses more on the characters than the kills. I love the characters, including Marian Waldman and Margot Kidder, both who seem to have a good time giving us plenty of laughs. I also like Olivia Hussey's performance.Yeah, there are some clichés here but it was made in the past, okay? I didn't mind the generic ending, which is used in most horror movies these days. What I also like in here is the suspense. There are some scenes that really scares you.I'm sure this movie is underrated and should be better than it is today. It's a good horror movie if you want a fun and scary time. It's not a masterpiece in anyway but it's better than most horror movies, even the remake.

All of the tropes were begun here including many that Halloween ripped off and got credit for. But this was the originator and still holds up, even if the technology in it doesn't. Very well done with genuine suspense.

I heard and read great things about this movie. Some people even implied it invented the genre, before Halloween did. I highly disagree. It's more of a thriller than a slasher. And it is so slow and boring you don't even manage to get into it. Even during the « death scenes », in which nothing is clear and everything is suggested, only in a very confusing and obscure way. I had a hard time taking it seriously. This and the chatty dialogues spoiled the experience. The ending gave a sense of eeriness, but it was far too late. Not a movie I plan on rewatching, and probably stick with that 2006 remake. At least there was some action.

My favorite film is and always will be My Bloody Valentine (1981). However, I love slasher films in general and Black Christmas sadly was remade in 2006, leaving this nostalgic original thrill-ride behind in the dust. What people forget often is that this one is way better in terms of characters, plot and soundtrack. I will say that the phone call they got in the first few minutes was incredibly disgusting and seemed over-the-top even for a horror film, but aside from that, this is one slasher you won't want to pass up! Nothing says Merry Christmas like a crazy maniac making prank calls and killing girls in a sorority house!
No wonder this is so many peoples' favorite horror film. Tension and dread at their literal peak. Absolutely phenomenal.

Finally, a second viewing of a slasher classic, or at least a father to the slasher genre, though not the only one; 'Psycho' (1960), 'The girl who knew too much' (1963), 'Reazione a catena' (1971) and maybe even the elusive 'Delitto al luna park' (1952), if one is willing to interconnect the giallo with the slasher - they all amount to one big happy bloody (this one is relatively not so bloody, by the way) family to me. This one I remember as being particularly atmospheric and creepy, but I never rated it higher than 7 out of 10.After having seen it again just the other night, a theory entered my mind: the piano player did it after all! I have several observations to substantiate this, but first, a few things which director Bob Clarke has stated (if I may believe the - very interesting! - list of trivia here on IMDb): 1. 'Clark (-) insisted that the ending be ambiguous', which means Clark máy have had a certain explanation in mind. 2. 'Clark considered it to be more of a psychological horror film than a slasher film', which will fall exactly in line with my theory. 3. '...The ending of the film forces people to think independently' Again, not a debunking, nor a confirmation, so...So, Peter did it, I'm thinking now. Why? The ending (in the attic', which could be metaphorically observed as 'the mind', the 'top floor') is a way to mess with the viewer and offers an insight to the schizophrenic mind. Next, all the times and places when and where Peter could be at the times of the calls and the murders pan out. In other words, he has NO alibi(s)! Then there are the strange coincidences. Peter shows up behind Jess just after she received a call and the reason he wouldn't kill her right then and there, is because he may still hope for her to choose to have their baby. This 'baby' (/abortion) motif that haunts Peter is also is very important to my theory, as the caller's voices refer to it many times - 'baby Agnes'... When he is finally convinced Jess will not have the baby and she tries to escape, he makes his final move. Which brings us all to the basement (scene). How coincidental would it be that Peter would just show up there, let alone that he knows Jess is there?In terms of general logics it is very strange that the whole house wasn't searched when Clare went missing, when some even feared she might have hurt herself. I mean, it is just common sense then, to check the attic and the basement (if not by the police, then certainly by her roommates and friends) - another little sign? I'm really unsure about that part. All in all, my theory does agree with Clark's statement that this is a psychological horror; Peter is both the brilliant and savvy artist, ánd the demented and traumatized killer - a schizophrenic if I'm not mistaken.Perhaps the film should be considered a hermetic, atmospheric piece of modern art, disguised as a slasher (oops, that term wasn't even invented yet in 1974!) with comedic elements - I know(!); something dirty, ain't it?" Personally, I didn't know whether to love or hate those 'funny parts' (the silly cop, the drunk lady of the house), but there's always next time...In any case, it is a most artful thriller of the eeriest kind, I was way off with my first rating; 9 out of 10 this time around.
If you're the type of persons into the horror flicks / Slasher And you will love black Christmas 1974.

Review title: A little dated, but still better than 60% of horror films released lately.
Review_body: Every time a remake is released (which is almost every week) these days I feel more compelled to seek out the source material to see why it needed remaking in the first place, as in 90% of cases the remake is worse or just as lousy as the original.I never saw the remake of Black Christmas, it looked altogether too teen-y for me and I'm not a big slasher flick fan anyway. But I did read something that said that it was a remake of perhaps the first slasher flick, which at least piqued my interest as it is always interesting to see where certain genres originated.After viewing what is immediately evident is that 35 odd years ago it was apparently unsettling enough to simply set up the kill and then have the killer do the rest. There are no intricate 7 minute "creeping through the halls" or red herring scares here, the victims decide to do something, enter the room in which they will do that thing, and the killer does the rest quickly and in straightforward fashion.Nowadays to achieve the same result the filmmakers have to build the tension or ramp up the gore, guess which one they normally go for ('eh Eli?).The supposed big twist (copied by Scream) is actually made evident in the very opening scene, as we are introduced to "Stalker-Cam" (TM) as someone cases a house from the outside, while a party seems to be going on inside. Said individual then climbs up and into the attic of the house.It turns out we are in what I think they call a frat-house in the US, a communal dorm for students, in this case all female with a middle aged, seemingly alcoholic dorm mother.The girls are having an end of term party before either heading home or settling in for the Christmas holidays. The party is interrupted by an obscene phone call, as the girls are all in their late teens / early 20s they put the phone on speaker and have a chuckle. Of course some are offended and others get into the swing of things and actually try to talk back to the caller, but ultimately no harm is done and they hang up, thinking that's that.Seeing as the film doesn't waste time in building tension or suspense, we get a fair bit of time spent getting to know the individual girls, there are no cardboard cut-outs here (I'm talking to you Friday the 13th remake!), there are drunken sluts, naive young women and other normal girls, same as every group of students. They are beset by the usual circumstances that occur to the age group, horny suitors, teenage pregnancy, busybody adults and the allure of alcohol and mischief.When quite suddenly (to them at least) a member of their number goes missing, they don't just shrug it off as so many crappy horror movies do today by saying "Oh, she must have gone to the shops" or "She'll show up", they treat the disappearance seriously, and as they care for their missing friend so too does the audience care more.The crank calls keep coming and they keep getting more and more disturbing, I would question why the girls keep listening but it is a movie after all. In between a small collection of bodies builds up, again this isn't a 73 dead slash fest as many are today and the remaining girls come across all sorts of roadblocks when trying to solve the issue, not the least of which is incompetent police work.When the ending comes it is in keeping with the rest of the flick, straightforward and basic, and there is no realllll surprise unless you have never ever seen a horror film in your life. What would concern though is the outrageously terrible police investigation that follows that wraps everything up so nicely whilst ignoring so many events and incidents.Again, this was the 70s, maybe they just didn't care too much back then about the details.Final Rating – 7 / 10. You aren't going to see anything new, but I'd rather watch this than most big budget horror remakes churned out these days.If you liked this review (or even if you didn't) check out oneguyrambling.com

Don't get me wrong, if you've read my reviews before, you'd know I love horror films, but this one is sorta boring at some parts. I actually saw the remake of Black Christmas before I saw this, maybe that's why I don't like it as much. In other words, I'm saying I like the remake better than the original. Usually, it's the other way around. It does have some good parts; like the killing scenes, and it has the classic look of the 70's. People are always saying this is the original slasher and HALLOWEEN isn't, but that doesn't matter to me. It doesn't matter which is the original slasher, because I love HALLOWEEN better. Maybe one day, I'll give this movie a 2nd chance. If you love classic slashers, maybe you'll like BLACK Christmas!!!

SpoilersBLACK Christmas is neither scary or even creepy. And it's definitely not the first slasher. The amount of buzz this film has is truly perplexing. This film often played on TV during the late 1970s and early 1980s and I watched it a couple of times then and it didn't even scare me then, when I was 13-14 years old, and the movie still didn't create any sense of dread or horror today. The pacing is sloooow. The killings are boring and the whole idea is mishandled, with too much time spent with the stupid police officers and the sorta seedy side of the gals, such as the scene with that old woman finding a bottle of alcohol in the toilet, which adds nothing to the movie. The good cast of actors overacts shamelessly. But the worst part of this bland movie is the ending. The woman just killed her boyfriend and she's in shock and the police leave her alone at the house?!?! Now come on! That's totally ridiculous! The ending just doesn't work because it defies common sense. Watch the original THE Texas CHAINSAW MASSACRE instead. Now that's a horror movie that hasn't lost any of its edge and makes BLACK Christmas look like kids stuff.

Pretty good antidote to the most cloying of all holidays this film offers mordant, "Twin Peaks like humor to get the viewer over the dead spots (no pun intended) between offings. Big downside for me is the general dearth of the great Margot Kidder at her foul mouthed, cheeky best...outraged that director Bob Clark saw fit to kill off his best character halfway through...and a plethora of the aggressively bland Olivia Hussey. Give it a B minus. PS...Great cinematography by Reginald Morris that captures the look and feel of a Canadian winter (i.e. look up "bleak" in the dictionary and there's...)

They were receiving obscene phone calls at the sorority house. It seems that the definition of cool has changed a lot ever since as Barb was trying so hard to be cool and so do that angry sweaty pianist but they were so cringe. Claire was killed first at the party and she was put on a rocking chair wrapped in plastic. A children found in the park murdered and the sorority girls joined the search party with the father of Claire for Claire. Peter was mad at his girlfriend Jesse about her wanting to have an abortion and the police and the girls suspected him. The sorority mother went to the attic after the cat before leaving the house and billy killed her with a hook. Barb was sleeping in her bed and billy went down and killed her with the glass unicorn's horn while the kids at the door were singing to Jesse. And the police were so obsessed to track the obscene calls and finally they found it to be from the sorority house. The police at the front was killed too and the officer called Jesse to tell her to leave the house but she wanted upstairs to warn the two but found both barb and Phill dead in the same bed. And got away to the basement and peter broke the window and got into the basement but Jesse was scared because she thought he's the killer. The police found peter dead and Jesse in shock and thought Jesse killed the murdered but billy was still at the attic with his first two victims. Claire was staring out of the attic window the whole time but no one just happened to see her nor did they check the attic. The phone was ringing again and Jesse was sleeping in shock in the house alone with billy. Who's billy? Why is he doing all these? No answers. None. And billy sounded like an annoying kid trying to be scary the whole time. But still it was said to be a slasher classic so I had to check it off my watchlist. It was creepy at times especially the way how Claire looked in the rocking chair but we need to know about his motives.

Review title: A foundation of the slasher sub genre that is a good film in its own right.
Review_body: In the weeks leading up to Christmas, a sorority house is harassed by obscene phone calls that serve as a prelude to chilling murders.Released in 1974 to respectable box office and mixed reviews, the film helped pave the way for future films such as John Carpenter's Halloween and Sean S. Cunningham's Friday the 13th. But even taking its influence on future films out of the equation, Black Christmas is a chilling and well made thriller.Bob Clark strikes a good balance between character based moments, humorous moments, and suspenseful moments to build a film where the scares come organically from build up and release rather than through overuse of jump scares. Clark makes good use of the perspective from both the killer and the women in the sorority house, and we never learn anything about the killer other than whatever insane rants he divulges over his obscene calls that are so loosely constructed they may or may not contain the truth.The movie is anchored by great performances as well. John Saxon does a good job of playing the investigating officer Lt. Fuller, and Margot Kidder as the house's brash acerbic Barb brings some subtle hints of humanity to what could have easily just been a hate sink for the audience to want to die, but easily the best performance is Olivia Hussey as Jess. Jess is a fantastic protagonist who we see dealing with the dilemma of terminating a pregnancy despite her boyfriend's objections, and she brings that inner struggle to her performance quite well. She also conveys a caring nature thatmakes her an endearing character who we like spending time with.Black Christmas is a classic for a reason. From its well defined characters to it lean but creepy atmosphere it's a film every horror fan needs to see at minimum once.

Review title: Early Canadian/slasher flick is better than expected
Review_body: Created when both Canadian cinema and slasher movies were in their infancy, Black Christmas is a film that effectively creates a creepy atmosphere with solid production values. It follows a familiar plot where a college sorority is receiving obscene phone calls, before each of the girls is murdered in the house. Eventually, the police trace the calls and they're finding they're coming from the house, too. I wondered if this movie started the cliché- I just looked it up and see the urban legend goes back to the '60s. It's not much of a surprise that the calls were coming from the house, even overlooking how well-known the cliché is now- for one thing, the killer is clearly in the house, and at another point, it's mentioned there's two lines.Some parts of this movie are well-done. Take the fact that one of the girls is killed while children are downstairs singing Christmas carols. That's juxtaposition reminiscent of the baptismal scene in The Godfather, though not as great. The movie is a little silly after the call is traced- Jess could have saved her skin instantly by taking three steps towards the door and going out to the police. Instead, she goes up the stairs. Reminds me of Tippi Hedren asking Hitchcock why she would go into the room at the end of The Birds (1963). Hitchcock's reply: "Because I told you to."I heard this movie described as a whodunit, but it's not much of a whodunit. The movie leads you to believe the protagonist Jess' boyfriend Peter is the killer even before the police identify him as a suspect. Then it's revealed it's not him... it's not entirely clear who it is. It could just be some random guy. That was kind of cheap, and the implication that he killed Jess, while cold and creepy, wouldn't have been as satisfying as the damsel-in-distress killing the bad guy. Oh well- Black Christmas works, and is a fine film for what it is.

This one is a slasher classic. It will always be a 10/10 on my affective memory. After rewatching, I remembered I don't appreciate the Christmas aesthetic that much and that the script wastes much time telling a story that runs through days. I think that's why the 2006' remake works better for me. But I can't deny this movie's pretty much atmospheric and tense, especially on the 3d act.

Predating Halloween and it's countless clones in the stalk'n slash genre, I have to say this movie really serves up the goods. Sure, to today's audience it may seem a bit slow and dated but to the true fan, this is a masterpiece of the genre. A madman hides in the attic of a sorority house, telephones the girls from upstairs and eventually starts killing some of them.So many elements have been lifted from this film and utilized to great effect, think of When A Stranger Calls, Halloween, Scream and countless sorority slashers to name a few, this movie has to be termed as somewhat of a groundbreaker. Filmed with a low budget, director Clark relies solely on mood, lighting and atmosphere to give the film it's edge. He succeeds brilliantly. Apart from a rather tedious 10-15 minute segment involving the housekeeper of the sorority the film absolutely keeps it's tension filled grip on the viewer and doesn't let go at all. I even found myself shouting at the tube, telling the girl "don't do this, don't go there", and I can't remember ever doing this before or after. Watching it alone (plus, it was at Christmas time) the film totally freaked me out. Acting is way above average for a slasher flick. Olivia Hussey, besides being a total knockout, is very good in the lead role. Margot "Lois Lane" Kidder is a delight as the foul mouthed drunk, Keir Dullea fairly creepy as Hussey's not-so-sane boyfriend and genre favourite John Saxon is good as always. For the most part, the humour goes down well also. One particularly funny scene involving a not so bright cop, but that seems to be a regular in Clark's films. If you're a fan of horror films, it doesn't get much better than this. Highly recommended.

Review title: A different kind of "Christmas Story" from Bob Clark.
Review_body: Black Christmas, if nothing else, is a genuinely frightening film. Some have labeled it a "classic" but I'm not so sure I can go that far. True it clearly inspired numerous more successful films, but it's just "good" when taken on its own.Our story is simple enough. A deranged killer has snuck into the attic of a sorority house just as many of the girls are leaving for Christmas break. This guy is a real wacko. He begins calling the young women on a regular basis and threatening them in often obscure but VERY SPOOKY outbursts of jibberish. Then, he begins picking off those who remain behind one by one. The bulk of the latter half of the film centers around a police detective (John Saxon) trying to get to the bottom of everything and save the lives of the remaining girls. This film works mainly because of two reasons. First of all, this film has an atmosphere of gloom set over it like few I have ever seen before. Even though it's Xmas, and people should be having fun, the characters and the audience as well seem to know something terrible is going on around them. A prime example is the duality we are presented with when the group of carolers are singing to the beautiful Olivia Hussey while Margot Kidder is being stabbed to death in her bed at the same time. The second major factor that helps this film get its point across is the absolutely demented phone calls this killer makes. Wow! I have never heard anything more psychotic in any film that I can remember. These calls really make the case for just how screwed up this guy is. His multiple outbursts and different vocal tones will be ringing in your ears for a while after the film is over.The acting was decent, but I don't think anyone was particularly outstanding. The film had a noticeably restrictive budget, but Clark does what he can. This film sets quite a different tone than his later successes like Porky's and A Christmas Story. It makes me want to check out some of his other thrillers made early in his career.One thing about this film that also can give you the creeps is knowing that this sort of thing has happened in real life! Perhaps the most well-known incident like this was when Ted Bundy, one of America's most famous serial killers, dropped in for a visit to a sorority house at Florida State one evening. The results were very similar to what happened in this film. If you think about it, these houses full of young (and often attractive) women would seem a real beacon to these types of killers. Especially in a college town like the one I live in.Makes you wonder if or when this type of thing could happen again...7 of 10 starsSo sayeth the Hound.

.... would be a more appropriate name for this thoroughly dull supposed shocker, which rarely rises above indifferent.WARNING: REVIEW CONTAINS MAJOR SPOILERS. ONLY READ IF YOU'VE SEEN THE FILM.John Saxon and Margot Kidder try gamely with a feeble script that tries to offset it's own predictability by crowbarring in misfiring comic setpieces. Not only do these work against the tone of the piece, they also distract from the main plot. The plot itself is so tedious that we have to wait until the last twenty minutes for the police to work out the killer's been in the house all along... something we were shown from the very beginning. This irritating game of catch-up is only expounded upon by the "twist" ending, which must be obvious even to an amoeba, and a hundred times more obvious to anyone who's seen that particular episode of Alfred Hitchcock Presents.To make matters worse, when this movie was shown on American TV they changed the name to Stranger In The House. Wow, what a sensible network decision that was! I wonder if the same network changed the name of Citizen Kane to It's His Sled and Planet of the Apes to It's Earth All Along Really, You Know. This is not even to mention the classic character stupidity, with Olivia Hussey being told to leave the house by the police. So does she get out and leave? Guess. People that stupid and annoying deserved to be butchered by an unfrightening mad axeman.

"Black Christmas" was a pioneering movie. It's safe to say that this was one of the first if not THE first slasher-flick of all time. As such, the movie has a lot going for itself. Everything that would later become a cliché is established here: the POV-shot of the killer entering rooms, the creative ways of picking off victims one by one, the final girl, etc. "Black Christmas" invented it all. On top of that the movie has top notch direction and an artful cinematography, which is sometimes reminiscent of Dario Argento's work. The acting is fine for the most part, and the mysterious killer and his creepy phone calls give Michael Myers a run for the money. So, if we take all that into consideration, "Black Christmas" is a genuine horror masterpiece.However, a lot of time has passed and a lot of slasher movies have been made since 1974. If you watch this movie now for the first time, it won't do much for you. You've seen these ideas before and probably in a more shocking way. "Black Christmas" may have been the first movie to do it, but other movies were the ones who made the basic slasher-elements famous.That's hardly director Bob Clark's fault, of course. It's just that if you're not a cineaste, you won't care too much about whether or not this movie was inventive when it first came out. All you'll care about is whether it can surprise and entertain you still, and truth be told, if you've seen the "Halloween"- and "Friday The 13th"-flicks or any movies of their ilk, then "Black Christmas" probably won't blow you away.However, if you do care about historical movie facts, then you must see Bob Clark's true holiday classic (the "false" one being "A Christmas Story" from 1983). After all, "Psycho" is also respected for the effect it originally had on audiences mostly. Even Hitchcock's masterpiece seems tame and predictable from today's point of view, so why should you be more critical when it comes to judging "Black Christmas"? For horror buffs, this one is a must, anyway.

The Plot = A group of young college girls decide to stick around they're sorority house for the Christmas holidays, not knowing a mysterious psychopath is hiding in they're attic, making obscene, disturbing phone calls, and that's just the beginning, he eventually proceeds to slaughter the kills one by one in a brutal fashion.Many consider Halloween as the first ever slasher movie but it isn't "Black Christmas" is but sadly this gem never managed the popularity "Halloween" and remained forgotten for years well until they made that not very good remake last year.Black Christmas was and still is bleak movie that packs a punch and gave me genuine goosebumps from beginning to end. I loved the dark imposing claustrophobic feel, the film handled its now known slasher formula like a freaking pro, tossing our way with full force moments of pure shock, a baffling whodunit, hard hitting plot twists and an expert use of the "killer is in the house" motif. The film's firm execution in terms of its conventions. Personally, the element that got under my skin the deepest had to be the killers' phone ramblings. I mean this dude was a hands down, to the core loon. He leaped into these bizarro monologues, taking on different voices (a man, woman, child), going on about things that only he understood while taking the random dramatic pause to slip in a heart felt "I'm gonna kill you" in there. What a CLASS ACT! The phone calls butcher boy (or girl) made, established him early on as one crazy mother to be reckoned with and since we never really got to see the lad throughout (apart from his heart warming toying with his victims' cadavers), that turned him into a constant thick cloud of doom spread wide about this tale. You didn't see him but man did you feel him! The acting was top of it's range in this movie Olivia Hussy (Jess) was solid from beginning to end, Keir Dullea (Peter) played his creepy, neurotic part well, I really enjoyed the house mother Mrs Mac she was great and stole every scene she was in, Margot Kidder was the stand out in this movie and brought in some much needed humor as the alcoholic and chain smoking drunk. Actors always come through when they play themselves. Another statement to that rule applied to John Saxon (LT Fuller) who once more played John Saxon...he was wonderful at it as per usual. Doug McGrath (Nash) was responsible for a few straight chuckles as the incompetent cop.Okay the murders may not be gory but they're still nasty and quite brutal like We get a girl being choked by a plastic bag, a semi blood wet stabbing and after the fact damaged corpses. Although not too graphic, the film still hit hard via the viciousness behind its dirty deeds.The directing was top notch Clark set up an unsettling dark mood from frame one, exploiting his creepy setting fully while giving us hints of slick style on the way (loved the killer POV shots and the slow motion). He also liked to inter-cut murder sequences with mundane events which made the scenes quite effective. And I have to give the man extra credit for two things: 1- That very scary shot of the eyeball (you'll know when u see it) killed me and the ending (which I won't dare give away) was brilliant.All in all Black Christmas is a definite cult classic because it's a well rounded horror flick.

Review title: A creepy tonic to Christmas cheer.
Review_body: An excellent horror film, which manages to build up a quiet, considerable power.  While it may not be out-and-out BOO! YIKES! scary (very little is these days), it combines narrative and subtext to an agreeably creepy pitch. Imagine an episode of THE X-FILES without the gloss, or alien nonsense, or enervating conspiracy theories, or even Mulder and Scully.  Even the amusing accents (the film is Canadian) cease to grate after a while.The story is set in a placid all-girl sorority house on campus in some Canadian university, at Christmas time.  The girls are having a sedate party with some boy friends.  Outside a breathing camera lurches towards the house...  Like Argento's SUSPIRIA, this all-female community is the site of the most horrific repressions, anxieties, fears, waiting to burst out, both within (figured as alcoholism, unwanted pregnancy) and without (rapes, murders, obscene phone calls).  Cleverly, though, the girls don't go hysterically loopy - everything remains externalised - much more chilling, even if it lacks the full on psychogynaecology of the Italian masterpiece.For example, one girl's mother is clearly indifferent to her, gold-digging, she claims, after other men.  Another is a virgin who has previously, we deduce, lived in a very repressive, rigid family atmosphere.  Indeed, one of the noteworthy things about BLACK is how these girls are away from home for the first time - they have cut away from authority, patriarchy and tradition.  The film is not necessarily a reactionary plea, however - the girls' substitute authority figures - boyfriends - become the locus of the terror; and although their self-made family verges on the parodic (with their seemingly jovial, frustrated alcoholic housekeeper as mother substitute), it is a genuine, if finally useless, structure of support.I suppose the film could be seen as an examination of the deep traumas buried underneath the vociferous self-confidence of contemporary feminism - after all, it was directed by the man who would make that radical treatise on gender relations, PORKY'S.  The main plot centres on the lead's right to have an abortion, and the terrifying phone calls - a horrifying, babbling cacophony from the beyond - seem like the pleas of a dying child, or the malicious threats of an Id-mother.  The idea of the disembodied or unreferential voice (those things denied a presence in the film, and maybe our society; e.g. the psychological trauma of abortion), miscommunication, misread signs, disinformation all suggest a culture where all recognisable meaning has gone haywire.  As this is the film's anxiety, we may feel that it is somewhat right-wing.On the other hand, it's thematic interest is the family, set in a family away from a 'real' family.  The BLACK of the title in relation to CHRISTMAS suggests diabolical overtones, a distorted mirror of the Holy Family celebrated at this time.  Maybe the film is reactionary - charging newly independent women with destroying the structures of family and tradition, and unloosing untold terrors and demons.Or maybe it's very sympathetic to the characters' plight.  Patriarchy in all its forms pervade the film - the unseen killer/rapist; the ineffectual police lieutenant; the self-obsessed boyfriends; the downright idiotic cop. The only clever, likable characters are the women.  And, as in the case of Barb, their rejection of family is not necessarily willed.  The path to independence is certainly not made easy in this culture.The great thing about BLACK is how it shows the sheer ineffectuality of trying to specify the unspecifiable.  It is obviously madness to think that Peter could have committed all these crimes, and yet it is quite reasonable to demonise him - he reveals the monster beneath the sensitive New Man. The heroine discovers that she can rely on no-one but herself.  Even this isn't enough.  Notwithstanding the unreassuring ending, she still has to deal with the fallout of her actions, which are by no means resolved.  There is still the issue of the abortion, which is one reason the demon is not dead. There were obscene phone calls and rapes before she knew she was pregnant: the fears may be subjective, but the inability to connect everything makes the film the more scarily effective.As a horror film, BLACK's excellence derives from the disparity between the hysteria of the subject matter, and the cool film style, suggestive, sinister, yet withdrawn.  The breathy point of view camerawork may seem tiresome after HALLOWEEN and its dozy imitators, but here the idea of something submerged, concealed, unknowable, unconquerable, not even human, never mind the cartoon slasher we're used to, is superbly realised, slowing down time.  The images of the first dead girl, with the doll baby in her lap, and the cat purring beside her, will haunt me for a long, long time.

The Canadian classic, Black Christmas is one of the creepiest films ever made! December is a fun time when you are a kid, but this season is kind bored for an young person, at least for me, but Black Christmas brought to me happiness, a tradition for every Christmas eve, I mean a must watch every December 24. Bob Clark take us to a sorority house with a killer stalking a group of college girls, the thrilling story is full of a gray atmosphere, great acting and a scary house! The slasher film was originally born in 1960 with Peeping Tom (UK) and Psycho (USA), but in 1974, Canada brought it first slasher, the amazing Black Christmas. A cool feminist horror film.Billy is still out there, don't answer the phone.

Review title: A terrifying masterpiece of the macabre!
Review_body: It's Christmas break at a sorority house, the girls (Margot Kidder, Olivia Hussey and Andrea Martin) are planning things for Christmas vacation. Until a mysterious stranger makes weird phone calls as he torments the girls then sneaks into the attic of the house as he starts to kill some of the girls one by one. The police are concerned by strange murders going on especially the discovery of a dead 13 year old girl in a park but can the cops find this psychopath or will he have his bloody hands on the entire household? Suspenseful and masterful psychological horror slasher flick from Canada and writer-director Bob Clark who would later give us "Porky's" and "A Christmas Story". It's a true masterpiece of the slasher genre in the 70's with "Texas Chainsaw Massacre", "Halloween", "Torso" and Mario Bay's "Twitch of The Death Nerve" (a.k.a. Bay of Blood) but this was before "Halloween" hit the screen 4 years later. The film also stars John Saxon who is one of cult cinema's best actors, it's a scary and chilling skin-crawler that will keep you guessing till the very end. Unlike most slasher movies which uses gore, this one uses characterizations and tension rather then just brainless blood-buckets. This is a true underrated horror masterpiece that every horror fan should seek and paved the way for other slasher flicks like "Halloween", "A Nightmare on Elm Street", "Friday The 13th", "Maniac", "Sleepaway Camp", "The Burning", "Scream" etc. as it ranks up with "Psycho".

Review title: One of the BEST horror films
Review_body: Black Christmas is a very underrated and un-recognised Canadian horror film from director Bob Clarke (probably most known for the raunchy comedy Porkys). This came before Halloween, Friday the 13th, When A Stranger Calls or A Nightmare on Elm Street. This is what started the slasher genre. This created the killer's POV shots, the creepy scores and the obscene phone calls.There really isn't a huge plot here, it is basically about a group of girls in a sorority house are being terrorised by obscene phone calls. No one has any idea who it is calling them. Slowly, each one goes missing and everyone becomes more aware of what is going on.Despite the minimal plot, this is THE slasher film. It has an extremely creepy score that will have the hairs on your neck standing, very effective cinematography (the house is perfect), a great group of younger, great camera work and older actresses/actors and it packs a walloping twist at the end. The lack of gore or violence suits the movie PERFECTLY. If they had shown the killings in full detail, it would not have been as good. One murder (involving a glass unicorn) is the stand-out, being one of the most recognised murder scenes in horror movie history.Many people consider Halloween the original slasher, that is not the case. BLACK Christmas is the ORIGINAL slasher. But it is much more than that. Instead of a cast of complete asses, we have a group of smarter people. They die not because of idiocy, but because of accident or just the wrong place in the wrong time. There is also some great humour tied in. Margot Kidder being the funniest of them all.The movie gives me the chills, especially the ending, which is the greatest in my opinion, of any horror movie. I urge anyone who considers themselves a horror fan to see this.5/5.

Review title: You'll want to unplug the phone before you watch this movie.
Review_body: Being a big fan of the horror genre, it takes an above average horror film to give me chills. This highly influential horror-thriller does just that, every time I see it!As a college sorority house empties out for the holidays, the remaining girls are unaware that a warped murderer has just climbed into their attic...Black Christmas is one of the most shamefully over-looked films in the slasher film genre, it's also been one of the most inspiring films of the genre. The story that drives this film is an extremely creepy one, taught with suspense, mystery, and an undying feeling of dread. It's also an intelligent story that wisely remembers that the unseen is scarier than anything one can put on film. Director Bob Clark builds an atmosphere of almost unnerving tension through out this film. Clark makes even the singing of Christmas carols very chilling. Adding even more to the sheer spookiness of this film is Carl Zitter's bizarre music score, which sounds as twisted as the killer's brain. A number of scenes from this film are simply unforgettable - the insane phone calls from the murderer, the glass unicorn stabbing, and my personal favorite, our heroine turning to see the killer's eye staring at her from behind the bedroom door.The cast of this film is great and contains a number of stars. The wonderful Olivia Hussey is sympathetic as our leading lady. Keir Dullea is strong as Hussey's boy friend, who's been behaving rather strangely. Margot Kidder provides some comic relief as the sorority bad-girl. John Saxon is solid as the police lieutenant who's trying to solve a murder. Supporting cast Marian Waldman, Andrea Martin, Art Hindle, and Douglas McGrath are terrific as well.Black Christmas has had a big hand in the slasher genre, such films as Halloween (1978), When a Stranger Calls (1979), and Friday the 13th (1980) were strongly influenced by this forgotten classic. For horror fans, Black Christmas is a must-see terror. I wouldn't recommend that you watch it alone in the dark though.**** out of ****

Review title: One of the creepiest films ever made - A great slasher
Review_body: Over Christmas break, a sorority house is terrorized by a mysterious obscene caller. Eventually, the terror increases as the sorority sisters are, one by one, viciously murdered by a psychopathic killer.Let me just say: With the proper viewing atmosphere, Black Christmas can, easily, be one of the creepiest and frightening films around. Stick yourself in a dark room with no light but the Christmas tree, make sure it's nice and snowy outside, and empty the house. Have all of those, and prepare to be scared out of your wits. Unfortunately for me this time around, all I had was the dark room and empty house. No tree, no snow. But, that didn't stop the film from being nearly as chilling. In addition to the chills the film delivers, it also succeeds in its technical aspects. Moore's script is very good, with a nice even flow throughout. It manages to flesh out the 'important' characters and make them seem more complete, even though some of the other characters are pretty much forgotten. Also, though some don't, I very much liked the lack of resolution. The late Bob Clark's direction, of course, was also damn fine. It worked well and took full advantage of the beautiful sorority house. The acting, on occasion, failed. Olivia Hussey, whom I never found to be a GREAT actress, was for the most part good, but still seemed a bit over-the-top on occasion. It wasn't enough to distract from the quality however, and can easily be overlooked. In the end, Black Christmas (1974) is a success of chilling slasher cinema that fans of such films as Halloween should truly love.Obligatory Christmas-Horror Elements:Subgenre: SlasherChristmas Carols: The soundtrack is primarily made up of holiday tunes.Snow: That there is.Person in a Santa suit: Yes, we see a Santa-clad person a few times.Violence/Gore: It's not as 'bad' as the remake, but there is a bit. The deaths are certainly better here.Sex/Nudity: None, although the phone calls are pretty graphic.Scares/Suspense: Endless. This is one of the creepiest films I've ever seen and it definitely stirs deep.Mystery: Absolutely. This is one of those rare films where the mystery lasts long after the credits roll - -Final verdict: 7.5/10. See it! -AP3-

Aside from a few logic holes like the totally inept police and the slightly slow pacing this is a fantastic scary horror. There are no laughs here as this is as serious as horror gets. This is what is so good about it. The creepy phone calls really set the mood leading towards the intense and petrifying scary ending. This is a very good and well-polished but still gritty stalker horror. The killer is always hidden. There aren't many jumps in the film, there doesn't need to be as there is this impending sense of doom that lingers throughout even after the intense ending. Very good horror film.

Black Christmas is one of the creepiest slasher movies I've seen in a while, for starters this film did make my skin crawl especially with Billy's phone calls. The atmosphere of the house and attic was also creepy, Bob Clark did a good job creating the suspense with the camera shots for the killers POV just like John Carpenter's Halloween, the acting is good from all the cast.The scenes with Billy are intense when he phones the girls because he's reacting his childhood while also saying other things, this slowly lets us understand the character and why he's killing people. I couldn't wait to hear the next phone call from Billy to see what he said next to them because they really are creepy.This film is a real classic 70's horror movie that really sends a chill down your spine. 10/10

Mostly well done chiller with elements later re-used in the better-known Halloween (1978) and When a Stranger Calls (1979).Olivia Hussey, Keir Dullea, Margot Kidder, John Saxon do some good acting. The locations are well used and the suspense builds well. The tense final segment is effective.Bob Clark later did teen sex comedy Porky's (1981), and there's much Porky's style comedy here. However it weighs the film down and dampens the suspense. The gags of Mrs Mac having booze hidden everywhere, Barb (Margot Kidder)'s jokes about turtles having sex and the fellatio telephone exchange, and the character listed in the credits as 'Laughing Detective' who acts accordingly, seem try-hard and drag on too long.Also weakening the film are the unbelievably dumb cops. The detectives openly mock dim Sergeant Nash (Doug McGrath) yet the detectives also screw up so badly it becomes distracting. The most obvious blunder is never properly searching the house even though Clare is still missing. There are big logic lapses. After threatening calls and a local murder, characters go back to joking like there's no danger. Even if Mrs Mac really would leave while a student is missing, no one reports her not arriving at her destination or tries to inform her of the murders in the house. Near the end the boyfriend (Art Hindle) of the still-missing Clare, and Clare's father, sit casually chatting beside the catatonic Jess (Hussey). Shouldn't they be searching for Clare who is still missing?

This is a real let down, the movie goes on and on. But it really doesn't say much. It does have a good cast and that helps. But it makes you wonder what the hell were they think when they agreed to star in this snooze. It's long, it's boring, we never learn the identity of the killer of his motive. Near the end of the movie, the guy who was nothing but a Saint is killed and takes the fall for the killings, but the real killer is still lurking about the house and they never found the one girl who was killed with the plastic bag who still sits in the attic. Good thing the Police did such a intense search of the house. This is a stupid bad ending, I just pray the remake fixes the stupid ending of this crapper and I hope the stars remove it from their resume. I give it the LUMP OF COAL.

Black Christmas is about a deranged killer on the loose in a college town. He takes up residence in the attic of a sorority and picks off the girls one by one. One of the first killer in the attic films, it was scary for the early 70s and is one of my favorites. Many well known actors had their first roles in this film. There are continuity errors and some obvious scene remakes, but overall a good film for the time period. Some masterful camera angles. The dialog was ripe for the time period, but quaint these days. This is one of the few scary PG rated films (except for language) that can get you going. One of the best parts of the film is the calls from the killer and the demented dialog. Very creepy.

Review title: Might Have Been Impressive Way Back When... But Kind Of Old Hat Now...
Review_body: BLACK CHRISTMAS (2 outta 5 stars)I remember that this movie was a big deal (at least in Canada) back in 1974. It was a huge hit and audiences raved about how scary it was.  This was a slasher movie that pre-dated Halloween and Friday the 13th... it probably didn't seem as cliched then as it does now.  In fact, a lot of scary movies that came out later sure seem to have been influenced by this one.  Young women in a large, spooky sorority house are plagued by weird, obscene phone calls... and then mysteriously they start to vanish, one by one... victims of a crazed psycho killer (sound familiar yet?)  The movie is competently-made... but the acting is very uneven.  SCTV's Andrea Martin plays one of the sorority girls and it's a little difficult to accept her in a "straight" role... as accustomed as we are to see her making fun of movies like this.  Margot Kidder plays another of the girls... the wild, outspoken, rebellious one (might as well have a target pinned to her back... dang!) The rest of the actors are Canadian performers of varying degrees of competence.  Some of the scenes are suspenseful... even if some of the goings-on defy logic and/or common sense.  (I mean, really...can nobody SEE the dead girl's body sitting right beside the upstairs window?)

Review title: Has Always Remained My Favorite Slasher
Review_body: I'm not even sure what sequence number can I assign to this year's re-watch, but what I am sure about though is that "Black Christmas" still remains my favorite slasher of all. Bob Clark did a terrific and highly creative job, and got hated back then, but eventually, deservedly it became a cult classic, and, more importantly, a huge influence to the genre - beginning with John Carpenter's "Halloween" which, in early stages, was meant to be a sequel to "Black Christmas".It's a bit of a slippery topic, about wether it's a slasher or not, but I made up my mind the first time I watched it - it is. What makes "Black Christmas" so enjoyable is the simplicity of the production, there are no over-the-top kills, no goofy chase scenes, no unintentional humor. Instead we get presented a contained, straight-forward, but unnerving story that's rooted in reality. The atmosphere feels pseudo claustrophobic and vulnerable. Bob Clark takes his sweet time to build the story, the characters and create suspense - by general slasher standards I'd deduct that "Black Christmas" is quite the slow-burn, but trust me, it's a value instead of a flaw. Despite an awfully tiny budget, "Black Christmas" feels polished and confident. The entire cast is almost unexpectedly terrific, with Olivia Hussey and John Saxon being the highlights & Marian Waldman provides a warming and healthy humorous character as the Sorority house's mother. The villain, the killer, mostly portrayed in back then extremely rarely used POV style, is just perfect for a slasher flick. The ambiguity surrounding him is all the character needs & his terrifying voice is an icon on its own. All the while the aforementioned qualities keep the movie going smoothly and creepily, even visually, given the budget, it's very creative - mad props to the cinematographer."Black Christmas" is, without a doubt, an overlooked movie if not also underrated. I might love it more than most of its viewers, but I'm telling you, it's a landmark in the horror genre that still has the ability to provide enough kicks. My rating: 9/10.

3 years before "Halloween" forever changed the horror film genre, "Black Christmas" was the original slasher film...and what a weird-ass film it is! There is a killer hiding in the attic of a posh sorority house, a killer whose face we never see and whose motives are never revealed. The film begins almost immediately with the sickest, most obscene phone call ever put on film. It's not so much what the caller has to say (although, for 1974, it's pretty graphic, sickening stuff!) but how he says it; his (or her?) voice changes with every sentence, sometimes two or three voices overlapping each other. It is indeed a chilling thing to hear, reminding me very strongly of Reagan MacNeils Legion of voices in "The Exorcist." The call ends with the mans voice, now speaking in a normal (but no less frightening) baritone, informing Margot Kidder that he is going to kill her. The spree begins almost as soon as the call ends.All of the characters are rather offbeat, and all of them suspect. Olivia Hussey is the surprisingly non-virginal and newly pregnant heroine. Keir Dullea is her moody and slightly obsessive piano playing boyfriend who refuses to allow her to get an abortion. Margot Kidder is the drunk, rude sorority sister with a mouth only slightly less foul than that of the obscene caller, who continues to phone and torment our confused and increasingly frightened Miss Hussey. The girls continue to disappear, but no bodies are ever discovered and no one has any reason to climb up to the attic, where a display of horror awaits. There are some ingenious killings here: a plastic bag, a hook on a rope, the glass horn of a unicorn, all very wince-inducing. The climax obviously went on to inspire "When A Stranger Calls" and can be appreciated anew here.It's not a flawless film, however. I personally hate ambiguous endings. I want to know who did it and why, and although it really is not necessary (real life killings oftentimes have no motive and the killer no history with his victim, after all) it still left me feeling irritated. I also had a serious problem suspending my belief when, at films end, the cops simply leave our heroine alone in the house to sleep her drugged sleep. True enough, they think they have caught the killer...but the girl is in shock, she's just committed a murder of her own (albeit, one of supposed self defense), and I'm supposed to accept it when they turn off the lights and just leave her there? What the hell? Okay, reshoot the last ten minutes or so, and I'll stop griping about the fact that we never find out who the killer is.I'm not sorry I watched it, if that's any consolation to you hopeful horror fans looking for some lost oldies but goodies. It's a good film. It could have been really great, but just fell a few inches short, that's all.

Black Christmas is ultimately one of the most under-appreciated horror films in the horror genre and really a pioneer movie for the slasher genre. The beginning of the film is terrific since it really takes its time setting up characters and the unseen psycho, inside the sorority house, almost like a chess match. Bob Clark did a fantastic job with the casting and character development. Oliva Hussey and Margot Kidder was what steered this film forward with their fine performance and natural attractiveness. John Saxon, who most know from A Nightmare on Elm Street, had a major role and was also top-notch. Perhaps my favorite part of the movies though is the psycho phone calls that the sisters get. Many films have tried to duplicate the phone calls, but none have been able to match the insanity and effectiveness that Black Christmas achieved. I could rave forever about Black Christmas, even the ending, which many people may not have liked; I thought it was definitely a good way to end an incredible horror film.

Review title: True horror is a mood...and nothing is moodier than this
Review_body: Really good horror movies stay with you for life.Any idiot with a camera can pull you into a one-off scare with a ghoul's mask and a horrendously loud stab of music, but it takes real chops to pull off something as cumulatively horrific as Bob Clark's 1974 indie masterpiece. Watching it is like being at the center of a really macabre jigsaw puzzle that keep getting more forbidding and gruesome until you realize the last piece has your name on it.There are many exhaustive reviews (deservedly so) on this site that detail the plot, so I'm going to summarize the pieces of the puzzle that make it such a delight to return to time and again.1) The Sorority House - Just one look at this thing could send you running for the hills the way Clark, Art Director Karen Bromley, and DP Reg Morris have portrayed it. A look at the house in the daylight without the ominously warped lenses, dreary lighting, and blanketing snow reveals nothing remotely forbidding. But the thought of having to stay overnight there, as it's portrayed throughout the bulk of the film, with the majority of the occupants gone on winter break...chilling stuff. It's a character unto itself.2) Carl Zittrer's score - Quite possibly the most effective horror music soundtrack ever composed, it's a wonder for several reasons. It's economical. It uses what it needs to when it's needed. Zittrer tore up an old piano and raked the strings with a variety of odd objects, neatly echoing male lead Keir Dullea's avant garde mashing on the keys, when the character wasn't brooding ominously. Then there are the ghostly carols: "ooohs" and "aaahhhs" bent, slowed-down, sped-up, played backwards until they're ready to send you over the edge. Turn out the lights and turn up the volume on the newly remastered 5.1 soundtrack and watch your skin crawl.3) The Phone Calls - My god. Hey, there are a ton of menacing phone call movies, but nothing like this. The caller in "Black Christmas" doesn't just pant or moan or blare obscenities....he does all of this and more. "Could that possibly be ONE person?" Lynne Griffin's Claire asks the other girls early in the movie. It's a valid question, because the caller seemingly has a background soundtrack going while he's going out of his mind. Was he using a tape player? Probably, but who really cares? The point is this: the guy is obviously OUT OF HIS MIND. He's not trying to threaten, he's not trying to scare or pull a prank. He's merely letting the contents of his demented psyche loose in a torrent that's loaded with the organized chaos of a Jackson Pollack painting or John Zorn track on steroids. He laughs, screams, and sobs...many times all in the span of five seconds. The jarring vileness of these (many) calls was really toned down in the TV cut ("A Stranger In the House," which is how I first saw this --- and even hacked to pieces for late night TV it was disturbing - NBC would run it near the holidays in syndication after SNL, I remember).4. "Wrapped in Plastic" - Way before Twin Peaks, Black Christmas played with the idea of a killer "preserving" his kills with transparent casing. This is particularly morbid when they're stored in the attic of the house you happen to be occupying.5. The Totally Canadian Humor - With as much gloom and doom as BC has going for it, you'd think it would never make you crack a smile. But then again, it has two of the funniest, least self-conscious actresses playing supporting roles: Andrea Martin and Margot Kidder. And the late great Marian Waldman has the role of lifetime as a uniquely foul-mouthed, hard-drinking housemother who keeps bourbon in the toilet tank. And need I mention Doug McGrath's bumbling Sergeant Nash? His performance generates laughs and pathos simultaneously...he's a rube you can't help but pity, in a nice way.This film has an impressive fan base, and yes, it did fail when it was originally released. I hale from Peoria Illinois and it even hit our theaters a bit softly....but....the theater owners were shrewd enough to bring it back each Christmas for a limited late-night run. Why? because they knew it scared the crap out of the few who DID see it.It still does. And what better endorsement can you give a horror film?

Review title: The father of the slasher genre.
Review_body: Black Christmas tells the story of a group of girls in a sorority house who are getting obscene calls from a mysterious man. The calls grow increasingly more macabre as the film moves on. Soon, a girl in the sorority goes missing, and everybody goes on the search while the calls continue. There is a killer on the loose, and as time moves on, he grows more and more blood hungry...Black Christmas isn't the best slasher movie ever made, but it's the movie that started it all, and for that it deserves respect.Black Christmas borrows it's basic plot from the most famous urban legend of all time, and adds a bunch of characters and plot developments to make it more interesting. The plot is pretty good for a low budget slasher movie, and it's still creepy today. Many of the devices used in most slasher movies came from this film including the point of view shots and the tension building silences. Though Halloween started the slasher boom of the 80s, it wouldn't have been made the way it was had it not been for Black Christmas, and fans of Halloween should recognize that. The movie uses many creepy build up scenes to build tension and makes the smart choice of never showing the killer's face. We only get to hear his deeply disturbed voice through phone calls, and an eyeball through the shadows. It is especially creepy that we have no knowledge of the killer's identity or his motive, however a motive can be put together by anyone with an imagination through the phone calls. Bob Clark, who went on to do the famous Christmas film A Christmas Story, did a very good job with this film.The acting is pretty good. Keir Dullea gave an intense performance, and Canadians Margot Kidder and Andrea Martin were both funny and dramatic.Overall, Black Christmas isn't a great classic, but it was the first slasher movie ever made, and it is the reason that most slasher movies are the way they are.7/10

Black Christmas is first of it's kind. This movie started the trend of slasher horror in hollywood. This movie inspired John Carpenter to make classic Halloween.Movie was good and enjoyable at some points but most of the time you will feel bored. Movie had some problems with pace and setting of story. Till the end of the movie, you don't know killer's intentions and most, importantly his identity. Hiding the identity is good for suspense but by the end nothing was cleared. Everything should have been shown step by step just like Halloween which helped audience to feel what's happening with the main lead but that was not the case with this one.Overall, by reading what I wrote above don't think that the movie is bad. For 1974, it is ahead of it's time and gave birth to slasher genre. It was just that after watching so many slasher movies, this one felt short.

Review title: A Christmas Horror Classic That Will Send Shivers Up And Down Your Spine.
Review_body: The movie starts out with a prowler/killer approaching the Phi Kappa Sigma Sorority house. The girls are throwing a Christmas party, they have no idea that a stranger has gotten into the house. Later that night, they start getting strange phone calls from a guy using 3 different voices. One is a perverted voice, the other Billy; and someone named Agnes. Barb( Margot Kidder) answers the phone, and she just laughs it off like who cares. Claire ( Lynne Griffin) who is leaving for the break to meet her father, doesn't take it lightly, leaves to finish packing upstairs. While packing she is suffocated with a plastic bag, and taken up to the attack. When Claire's father comes the next day and explains she didn't show up; red flags are raised. Jess( Olivia Hussey) gets Barb, and Phil(Andrea Martin) to file a report at the police department. The first time they go the Desk Sgt. Nash( Doug McGrath) doesn't take it seriously. When a girl is murdered in the park close by and the calls are still happening, Lt Ken Fuller(John Saxon) gets involved. The calls still come and this time they seem personal like only someone close to her would know.Jess, has her own problems, especially how will she tell her boyfriend Perter(Keir Dulla) she's pregnant. She goes to the conservatory, and tells him she wants an abortion. When she tells him he flips, he is high strung and orders her around. He's control freak who is threatening; and could go off like a firework . When Jess gets back she gets another call, and it sounds so much like Peter; that it's chilling. Peter is weird he sneaks in the house to take a nap, and approaches Jess like a creep. When I first saw this movie I thought Peter was the killer, but who's Billy? While watching this movie I notice that the killer wears the same clothes Pete wears. I also think he and the killer look alike, i.e. when Barb gets killed the killer resembles him to a T. I do think he made some of the calls from the upstairs phone; because he was in the house at the time she receive one.That one she got got the phone company involved. When Jess was on the phone to the police Peter started down the stairs. Jess had no idea he was there; and too me that's a little unnerving.When a tap is put on the line on the two phones downstairs. Lt Fuller and lineman Graham(Les Carlson) tells Jess in order to catch the person, she needs to keep them on the line. Phil has a talk with Jess before she goes to bed. Jess thinks it could be Peter, but isn't sure. Phil gives her some advice, then goes to bed. Ten minutes later a call comes in, and they get the location. Sgt. Nash phones Lt. Fuller and tells him the calls are coming from inside the house. When Nash calls Jess and tells her the news, she warns Barb and Phil. When she discovers they have been murdered, and the killer is still in the room. Jess fights back and escapes to the basement. It's about two minutes later, Peter shows up and knocks on the basement window. He eventually gets in, but Jess doesn't trust him. She ends up killing him with a fire poker. Afterwards when they find Jess, people in the background think he is the killer or is he? I loved this movie especially the joke on Sgt. Nash. One thing this move has in it is a little comic relief, especially the Fellatio joke on Nash. There were others, but that one had me going for awhile.I didn't see this movie until after the re-make came out, the original is always the best. Too me I think there could have been two killers Peter and Billy. Peter was just so creepy, and was always around when someone was killed. The whole sneaking in the house to take a nap; WTF-WHO DOES THAT/? This is a fact, this movie is a must see. If this movie doesn't give you the creeps, check your pulse.

Review title: A Horror Classic That Helped Shape the Slasher Genre
Review_body: I don't know why I've waited so long to see this film because I hear about its greatness all the time, but I saw it for the first time earlier this afternoon. I was pretty blown away at how good it was. I was expecting it to be good but I was also expecting a good amount of cheese because it's so little known. However, it wasn't cheesy at all and it is still terrifying to this very day.I thought the story was incredible. It's really simple but it accomplishes so much and instilled a lot of fear in me. I've heard a lot of people say how Halloween ripped this movie off and I don't see that. I definitely see how Halloween was influenced by this film but that doesn't mean it isn't its own film and a great one at that. I would call them equal films. Both have great stories.The acting was very good and the characters were portrayed very well. The atmosphere is probably the creepiest part about the film, it was executed so well. This is definitely one of my new favorite movies and I am bummed that I waited so long to see it.Every horror fan owes it to themselves to see this movie immediately. It is essential not only to see, but to own as well. And remember, if this movie doesn't make your skin crawl, it's on too tight!

Review title: Groundbreaking and original, awesome early slasher.
Review_body: As a holiday tradition, I make a point to view this at least once every December to get myself in the Christmas spirit. This year was no different and I have decided to review this old favorite once and for all.The ambiance is genuinely creepy and the Christmas theme being used in a horror movie is upsetting to see. I would not recommend this one to kids. "Black Christmas" is one of the first true slasher movies. A killer is on the loose and stalking members of a sorority house. We are not sure who it is and the ending is shocking. The killings are brutal. It's crazy to think that the guy who directed this went on to do such hits as "Baby Genuises..." He should have stuck to horror! Highly recommended classick that will sit with you for awhile after viewing. And avoid at all costs the Michael Bay remake for that is absolute garbage and just a sorry attempt to cash in on an awesome movie that DID NOT NEED TO BE REMADE.9 out of 10, kids.

Review title: One of my all time fav horror films
Review_body: One of my all time fav horror films. Yes it's tame for today standards but it's pure suspense. I wish this film got more credit cause it's amazing. The acting is great the story actually has character development. The death scenes are good too. It's scary also. One of the best horror movies ever.

I watched this film last Saturday evening. I thought that i was far better a movie than the remake of Black Xmas(2006). The actors were way better than in the remake. The film seemed to have a much more creepier feel to it. i really liked how the camera work was done which made it feel that you were being followed through the house. I think that it is best to be watched late at night with the lights out for full effect. I thought that there was good amount of gore in the film. as well as having a a good psychological feel to it so that you are on the edge of your seat waiting for something to happen. The killings were done well especially one one with the girl having been suffocated with a plastic bag.I recommend this film for fans of all the 80's slasher films. such as Halloween (1978), Friday the 13th (1980. You should feel quite afraid after watching this film (Enjoy!!)

Review title: This is classic, don't miss it
Review_body: You may never have heard of this neglected 1974 gem, but you've probably seen one of its many imitators. Olivia Hussey and Margot Kidder (also look for Andrea Martin of SCTV fame) star as two residents of a sorority house that is emptying out as Christmas approaches. The atmosphere is jolly and carefree, except for an ongoing series of menacing telephone calls, and, oh yes, we've just seen someone climb into the attic with apparent ill intent. Kidder does some scene-stealing as the bad girl, Hussey illustrates one of the downsides to having beautiful long '70s hair, and Keir Dullea does a nice turn as the creepy boyfriend. Director Robert Clark knows that the unseen is far scarier than what can be seen and he ratchets up the tension beautifully, making good use of ominous shadows, and putting in nice touches like replacing the sound of a distraught woman's scream with the piercing ring of yet another ominous phone call. This is a terrific, well-made little movie that is genuinely sleep-with-the-lights-on scary. Don't miss it.

Review title: A classic 70's mystery horror slasher film - Olivia Hussey is the best slasher heroine
Review_body:
A classic mystery 70's horror slasher film one of the best slasher films that evolves around Christmas hollidays. Black Christmas (1974) is one of the most influential slasher movies of all time. John Saxon is this movie from a A Nightmare on Elm Street (1984) My Favorite Horror Movie of All Time. Black Christmas I watched now the second time around I like this film a lot. The ramake I watched the first time around I like the ending a lot more than in this movie. The ending is kind a chilly.In my theory I think there were two killers I know that Peter Smythe (Keir Dullea) was the killer because he broke in to basement and it is weird that this guy knew where Jess suppose to be. I think they were 2 killers since Billy could not kill Jess, Peter decied to kill her.The story takes place in a sorority house on Christmas hollidays, where the residents are throwing a Christmas party before they depart for the summer. Little do they know, however, that a perverted killer has made his way into the house, and is preparing to pick them off one by one. The movie was inspierd by a classic urban legend of a babysitter who learns that the threatening calls she's receiving are coming from inside the house. It was a movie called When a Stranger Calls but I hate that film, I prefer the remake.Actress Olivia Hussey as Jess Bradford the heroine did a great job a wonderful believable performance I love her. I wish there would be more fight in the film with an assaliant on the end of the movie, but it is what it is. The kills are brutal, great effects, grousome death scens. Margot Kidder dies in this movie I wasn't happy about this. Olivia Hussey is a bad-ass she really did a good acting performance. The actress deserves more. Jess Bradford deserves to be one the best survivors out there. I love this my mstery great slasher film. John Saxon was great as Lt. Kenneth Fuller.The second remake is coming this Friday out and I can say the second remake will suck! I watch the trailer it will have nothing to do with the original except the title. It is Rated PG-13 as a family film so it is not worth it to see it. Black Christmas 70 movie is a cult classic. Bob Clark and A. Roy Moore the both helped developed the story in the remake. They bot did a grest job. In the movie Billy is preferening Billy and Agnes what they did. Really psycho, creepy and scary. In the park they found 13 year old girl probably Billy's first wictim. Clare Harrison (Lynne Griffin) disappeared. The killer was stalking her than he killed her with a plastic bag. You see her body stahed in the attic. He killed Mrs.
