MacHenry and he stashed her body too. Phyl and Barb are both killed.I will never understand why horror movies like Black Christmas the original classic are not made anymore. They are not made. I love the remastered version. I love the phone calls that sorority girls recieve. This movie is really great constructive. So I have been talking a lot about this movie it deserves a proper review. I don't own this film in my collection, because it is over 40 years old. I download and I saved the film on USB key so I can watch it whenever I want.I like this movie a lot Olivia Hussey is the best heroine she deserves a great recognition. This movie gets 10/10 R.I.P. Review title: Far Superior To The Feminist 2019 Remake, But Still Bad
Review_body:
Pros:
1. The first-person view of Billy (Albert J. Dunk) helps to imbue more tension as it feels like you're the one stalking the victim.
2. Albert J. Dunk delivers a fantastic creepy voice-acting performance.
3. The does a really good job at cementing the horror atmosphere.
4. The last 20 minutes are captivating, intense, and thrilling. It's a shame this only happened towards the end.
5. The film keeping the identity and physical appearance of Billy shrouded in mystery, helps to increase the tension, suspense, and intrigue, as you're constantly trying to guess who it is.
6. The shot of Billy's eye through the door crack is utterly terrifying and bone-chilling.Cons:
1. Most of the acting performances are very wooden and flat.
2. There are quite a few useless characters as they are given nothing to do. Mrs. Mac (Marian Waldman), for example, is only there to be a drunk.
3. The comedy is massively unfunny. The fellatio gag is presented as the height of the humour, and it's awful.
4. The film is needlessly slow-paced, especially after the first kill where very little happens.
5. The dialogue is clunky and is often used to spew out forced exposition.
6. Most of the characters that die are either unlikable and/ or uninteresting. This makes it hard to care.

Review title: Other movies have borrowed heavily from this holiday horror film, but there's a reason for that
Review_body: It's ironic in a way. "Black Christmas" predates pretty much every single slasher horror film (including the one I consider the first in the genre, "Halloween") but you can see so many elements in this film that have been borrowed or distilled into familiar horror tropes that at first, it will seem kind of routine. For this reason, you might be wondering what the big deal is about if you're just a casual movie viewer. There's a lot more to it than just an ancient ancestor of your "Friday the 13th" and your "Prom Night" though. It goes without saying that if you're a true fan of horror cinema, this is a must-see. The plot, as you might expect happens on Christmas Eve/Day. It follows a group of sorority sisters who are stalked and murdered by an unknown killer hiding in the attic of their sorority house. Sounds basic? In a way it is, but it's the details that make this movie stand out.As a fan of horror movies, I have a great deal of admiration for this film. I enjoy seeing the beginnings of the horror genre. The cast of characters gradually being reduced in numbers as the movie comes along, the building tension, "the final girl", the various kills and the escalating terror as the sorority sisters slowly realize that there is something very wrong happening. It's like looking at the skeleton of an ancestor to Tyrannosaurus Rex and looking at what bones are going to gradually turn into which ones and what traits were deemed unnecessary so they were dropped until the creature in front of you became this legendary killing machine. From a fan of horror films, this historical aspect ranks about 3rd on my list of "favourite things about Black Christmas". I'll get to #1 in a bit, but my #2 isn't the familiar aspects. It's the sort of precursors to some of the familiar tropes in slasher films that are quite different in their primeval state. For example, the main character in the film isn't very clear at first. Are we going to be following the killer? Is it going to be Margot Kidder's character, the sarcastic, drunken girl who appears to kick-start the plot? Usually the protagonist of the film is "the virgin", so maybe it will be Claire (Lynne Griffin), who leaves the party early when she is offended by Barb's lewd remarks? Maybe it's Jess (Olivia Hussey), the recipient of the obscene phone call that is our first clue as to who the killer might be? Just as there are some points in the film where your familiarity with slasher films will help you deduce some developments, the fact that this movie doesn't adhere to many of the clichés (because it predates them) makes it often unpredictable and unconventional as far as films of the genre go. You'll be surprised to learn, for example, that the killer in this film does not have a signature weapon, that we don't really learn a lot about who he is and that there's really not much blood in the film. Just when you think you've got this movie figured out, it throws you for a loop, and I like not knowing where a plot is going to go.You're probably wondering what the main appeal, my favourite thing about this movie is. Well, it's the fact that the film is genuinely frightening. There's a very naturalistic look about the film that brings home the terror. The movie doesn't begin with a fresh face going to college for the first time and being introduced to a slew of characters, some of which act funny from the start to indicate they might be the killer later. It starts at Christmas time. All of these characters know each other, they're all busy doing their own thing, and it's like you're coming in uninvited to peep in on the action (in a way that's similar to the killer). When we hear the phone ring and learn that it's a strange man making lewd phone calls, and that he's been doing this for a while, it's not really a grandiose shock to the characters, they've heard it before and yeah, it's creepy, but it's not a big deal. It really feels like these people have a life outside of the events of this movie. We hear several off-hand remarks of other crimes that have happened around the campus, and we have no way of knowing if they're connected to this plot at all. This helps make the identity of the killer even more mysterious. Has he been murdering people for a long time and he's just now coming into contact with these sorority sisters? Is this the first night and the other events are just coincidences in the same way that you have coincidences all the time in real life? A lot of it can only be guessed because like the characters in the movie, you don't really get big bits of exposition explaining the who, the what and the why of this plot. This lingering uncertainty as to what exactly is happening, and why, makes the conclusion of the film incredibly intense and unsettling. There are images of the killer that spook me every time I see them."Black Christmas" is a movie that does suffer because it has been imitated so much, but there's a reason it hasn't been forgotten. It has some really genuinely frightening scenes, a lot of tension and also several humorous scenes to throw you off. I really like the comedic moments because just like in real life, when you get genuinely scared you do manage to find little nuggets of humour to try and steel yourself. You have probably heard some things about this film and wondered what the big deal was about, but watch it again, really watch it and I think you'll agree that it really is something special. (On Blu-ray, December 5, 2014)

Review title: A perfect slasher if not for the bloated subplots.
Review_body: It's hard to write a review for Black Christmas. On one hand I thought much of the movie was a pathetic attempt at an emotional slasher film, and on the other hand there were scenes that were some of the best kill/scares in the history of horror movies. It's almost like Black Christmas flirts with perfection then jumps back to lame subplots. Yes, I understand that this film literally invented the slasher genre, but, no, I cannot call it perfectI can only call certain aspects perfect.As I said, the main standout flaw is the complete lack of focus. The movie starts out in a sorority house, but from there jumps to a lot of other places to focus on characters and subplots that don't really matter to the story at all. The whole subplot of Clare's father coming to the sorority house was completely pointless by the end of the film, and just takes away from the actual story. The subplot between Jess and her boyfriend should have been cut much shorter, in order to, once again, focus on the actual story. Most of all, the subplot of the missing child still has nothing to do whatsoever with anything else in the film. I don't understand why the director takes 20 minutes to go into it, when in the end, like all the other subplots, it is nothing important. It could have easily been a passing reference instead of its own section of the film. The police scenes, also, added nothing to the story except take away from the amazing atmosphere. Everything the police scenes added could have been done with phone conversations, instead of taking up half the movie time to show things the audience could have guessed. Without all these subplots the movie would have been much, much more effective and tense.Another problem I had was the title of the film is Black Christmas, but other than the opening and one of the death scenes, nothing in this movie referenced Christmas at all. Most of the time there wasn't even snow on the ground. It would have been so much more emotionally effective if it played into the Christmas nostalgia more than it did, but the movie made the ability to play Christmas songs more of a gimmick than a plot point.Though I'm being negative with almost every aspect of the film, I really did enjoy part of itthe actual story. When the movie isn't trying to have five different subplots that go nowhere, the actual core story is done to perfection. The killer, the kills, the girls, the sorority house, the phone calls, the endingall truly perfect, and by far the greatest slasher of all time. It's sad to see what is really a beautiful minimalist horror story turned into a bloated crime drama with more pointless subplots than kills, and that is the only thing holding this film from perfection.Overall, I wish I could go in and just watch the actual plot happen in Black Christmas, but I can't. Still, as much ranting as I did, there is something there that makes it better than so many movies that I've rated higher. Something that Hollywood forgot four decades ago. Maybe it's the fact this movie has very little blood, but is still very effective. Or, maybe, it's that the core plot was actually thought out, truly terrifying, emotionally captivating, and also something original that had never been done before it. I think that is it.4/10

Review title: A Christmas As Red As Blood
Review_body: *Black SPOILERS* Christmas Break; most of the Pi Kappa Sig Sorority girls have already gone back home for the holidays, but a few are still in the house, and begin to receive chilling phone calls by an unknown person, and after Barb (Margot Kidder), a drunkard Sorority Sister, disses him, he says calmly 'I'm going to kill you' and hangs up.One of the girls, Clare (Lynne Griffin) is scared, and mocked by Barb, she decides to go pack, since she's leaving the next day for home with her father, but she is lured by the caller in her closet and suffocated with plastic wrapping, and her corpse is put in the attic (where the killer hides) on a rocking chair, with a doll in her lap.Her father obviously doesn't meet her, and worried (but somehow worried more at the decor his daughter used in her room) he calls the police.And as the Pi Kappa Sig's housemother, the alcoholic Mrs. Mac (Marion Waldman) 'goes missing' also, and the calls become increasingly frightening, the sorority sisters, which include Barb, the pregnant (and planning an abortion) Jess (Olivia Hussey) and the geeky Phyllis (Andrea Martin) begin to realize the danger in which they are in, but is it too late? Not many know of this movie (yet), especially where I live (Italy), where it's rare to find (until Dec. 5, when the DVD is going to come out... I hope), but it's a real treat for horror movie lovers, and it takes you back to a time where Final Girls were still believable, the horror movies were thought out and original (heard that, Michael Bay?), and suspense, not gore, was a priority.The obvious inspirer of 'HalloweeN' (along with Italian thrillers 'Profondo Rosso' (1975) and 'L'Uccello Dalle Piume Di Cristallo', (1970) which also use the technique of the killer's POV), 'BC' conserves intact the power to scare you silly with a very simple storyline and almost no blood.The actors (which other than the above mentioned include Keir Dullea, Art Hindle and John Saxon) are also really great, and there is a subtle sense of humor throughout (just a quote: 'These broads could hump the Leaning Tower of Pisa if they could get to the top of it!'), and let's admit it, Christmas has always been a little *too* cheery, hasn't it? Black Christmas: 9/10.

Haunting, dark, atmospheric and suspenseful are probably the best adjectives to describe director Bob Clark's underrated horror film. Before there was "Halloween" in 1978, four years earlier came this terrifying slay ride (pun intended) from the man who would give us "A Christmas Story" in 1983.Set in a sorority house during the Christmas season, a group of young women are stalked, taunted and mercilessly seen by an unseen madman living in their house's attic. The tension only escalates as the girls are picked off one by one and the phone calls are garbled insane gibberish, filling the film's main heroine with dread as she becomes the 'final girl'. Can she and anyone else survive the terror of the night?The film's cast is impeccable from Olivia Hussey plays main protagonist, Jess, to Margot Kidder (four years before she would become Lois Lane) as the foul-mouthed Barb, Andrea Martin as levelheaded Phyllis 'Phyl', Keir Dullea (best known as Dave Bowman in '2001 a Space Odyssey') as Jess's unhinged boyfriend, Peter, and John Saxon as the policeman assigned to watch the town and ultimately solve the murders. The cast displays a quirky chemistry and genuine sense of mistrust as the tension ramps up in the narrative.The story is simplistic in its narrative: murders occurring in the sorority house and everyone is under suspicion. However the film is original in its format with inventive techniques as POV shots from the killer's perspective (soon to be overused in later horror films), obscene phone calls that taunt the surviving girls ('Scream' would borrow the phone call angle, but put its own spin on escalating tension) and a limited use of violence in order to scare the viewer with what is not seen rather than what does happen. Most audiences and critics were unsatisfied with the film's ending as there are questions left unanswered, but this makes "Black Christmas" so different from its successors as it begs us to wonder what happens after the credits. Any horror fan should definitely see this little gem and I promise it'll haunt your dreams.

Review title: EXCELLENT PERIOD PIECE not just for the month of December!
Review_body: Andrea Martin! * * Margot Kidder * * John Saxon! * * Some old guy you see on TV all the time who plays the old geeky guy all the time!! * * Listen I'm sorry, I wouldn't say that the performances are good...at all at all atoll!!! They are pathetic, in fact! All the way down the line!! Do you hear me?!?! PATHETIC! Indeed though, sure 'twas that it was the case that these gals and guys without exception "didn't have much to work with". In fact I think looking back that aside from Andrea Martin perhaps, all the characters single and in to-to reminded me viscerally of those dimwitted folk who try the patience of detectives Joe Friday and Bill Gannon on "Dragnet" starring Jack Webb forcing the fuzz to raise their eyes to heav'n on numerous occasions so provoked by the half witted dimwitted of LA are they as they go about their "beat" investigating crimes. Not just the good citizens, look you, of this campus town but the peace officers themselves are equally unintelligent leaving it to the audience - you and me - to roll its eyes a la Joe And Bill in this Canadian production entitled, "Black Christmas" but when I saw it in the theater when it originally played I believe it was called "Silent Night, Evil Night". Only with R rating: brace yourself to hear profanity aplenty in this motion picture! Ms. Kidder also does some lewd tongue things. In fact the least nasty of the bunch is probably the heinous killer who has some story to tell about Agnes and Billy which as many other reviewers have indicated, comes off less as an attempt to terrorize than as some little kids intending an attempt to entertain (however feebly!) or kids making "prank" calls and struggling not to laugh as an accompaniment or kids dead set on simply sending "everything but the kitchen sink coming down the line" as one reviewer comprehensively put it.On to accentuating the positive: The color is very richly saturated and the set design and lighting are nothing short of lushhhh, like Barb (Margot Kidder)! As a result, while you'd probably be making a mistake to date any of these sorority sisters, you'll make no mistake dating this picture: this is 1974 all right in all it's glory, with fashion palette ranging from mod to retro and in fact what makes this film really juicy is the heady flavors of '74. Why you can almost hold the aroma in your hand which emanates from the chicks of patchouli, rose oil and from the dudes English Leather, Brut and the like with which you'll be juggling the stench of blood, egg nor, the house mother's "B for Booze" which - charming if hardcore woman that she is, this broad drinks from out the toilet without any kind of rinsing of the bottle I guess she figures if it's a battle to the death between e coli and her saliva she's nothing to worry about with the egg nor, Xmas tree, various other fixings, etc. and the booze the other girls are drinking too, cause the house mother is by no means the only one drawing refreshment from the "tis" punch bowl! Kier Dullea is an evil conservatory composer/pianist whose blatant atonality and extended techniques while one would hope could convey a sense of menace yet even sweating and squirming on the piano which is practically smashing literally to bits during his performance he puts the jury assigned to hear his recital to sleep. Philistines! This movie is so funny cause of its 1974 vintage with all the young women being so potty mouthed, each wanting to be more outrageous and provocative than the last. well at least two or three of them would give any woman a run for her money in a contest for which of them is the sauciest lady of them all, verbally/orally that is. Visually though you may find yourself musing, "I wonder who put up the poster that is the "peace" sign made of the pelvis and legs of a man and woman - the woman's are spread as the man appears to penetrate her from above, his legs tightly clamed together. By today's admittedly different standards it is the female of the species, aside from the "bespectacled" (as the reviewer who spoke of the kitchen sink called her one - i.e. Andrea Martin) one and maybe a couple of the others who bent over more in the direction of soft spoken, who would be charged with sexual harassment in this day and age! Is this a sorority house or a museum of erotic art? The place is, as a rule choka block with knick knacks - carousels, a collection of glass swans, etc. Ah the good old days! Were they so good?!?!?! "Black Christmas" raises this question without doubt.Well for one I was disappointed not even to see a composer credit in the credits for the spicy piano music. The IMDb indicates that the composer recommended sexy John Saxon for the roll of the top cop. Wouldn't it be funny if this composer actually in this instance proved to be the first cause of Mr. Saxon doing the many and various copious cop rolls he was eventually fated to you might say specialize in - let's call it of course a sub-specialty of cop in horror rolls! The last 2 shots were kinda cool. I didn't "get" who it was outside, I guess another ineffectual cop and why he didn't react to the phone ringing!! I'll give it a 10 for being an outstanding "time capsule" cause it really is more interesting in this way than many another bad movie or even good! :)

Whilst it's widely thought that it was John Carpenter's Halloween that initiated the slasher genre those who actually know anything about horror know that it was actually Bob Clark's Black Christmas made in 1974. In fact, Clark and Carpenter worked together on a project after Black Christmas was made. Clark said to Carpenter that he no longer worked in horror but that he had had an idea for a horror film that was never realised. This would be based around the occasion of, you've guessed it, Halloween! Carpenter then later asked to use the idea for a film he was to due to work on and the rest is history. This isn't to say that Carpenter ripped off Clark but this explains how The Babysitter Murders (the original idea for Halloween) suddenly morphed into the masterpiece we now know and love.In fact, the opening shots of Black Christmas are similar to those of Halloween- the killer's point of view camera shot. Halloween reveals who this person is (and it's one hell of a reveal) but Black Christmas doesn't. In fact, the killer isn't revealed fully throughout the entire film which is the first reason that Black Christmas is so revolutionary.The story involves a group of female students on the night before they leave their sorority house to go home for the holidays. They start to receive very disturbing phone calls and things start to get dramatically worse soon after.Another reason to love Black Christmas is that the extent of the killer's mental instability is shown by the first girl he kills. She is suffocated and then placed in a rocking chair in the attic where the psycho is hiding out. Throughout the film we see him ranting and manically rocking her.Arguably some of the most disturbing sequences within the film are when the intruder calls the girls. They don't know the calls are actually being made by the killer who's in the attic within the same house. From the calls we come to learn that the person making them is called Billy and that he seems to be playing out incidents from his past, incidents rife with cruelty, abuse and possibly murder. Bob Clark used five different actors for the calls. These phone calls are some of the scariest, most disturbing and unsettling sequences I've ever seen in a horror film. They were even cut when the film was first released in the UK.Theres also the fact that Black Christmas was the first film to use the now established trope of a killer's phone calls coming from inside the same house as their potential victim(s). This was years before When A Stranger Calls.Another great thing about the film is the humour contained within the movie especially from Margot Kidder's character, Barb. It's amazing that such an unnerving film can still have genuinely funny interludes but without forsaking the movie's tension.But maybe thats because the film is extremely tense indeed. Theres a certain sense of doom to the proceedings that are depicted in the movie. A great example is where Olivia Hussey's character Jess has just found out that the calls are coming from the sorority house, that Billy is ensconced within it but so are two of her friends (the audience knows otherwise as we saw them get dispatched earlier). On going upstairs (even though the police have phoned and demanded that she leave the house immediately) she enters one of the girl's bedrooms to discover their dead bodies- and the killer looking at her through a crack in the door. This sequence is one of scariest in horror history.Add to this one of the most warped endings I've ever seen in a horror movie and you have a masterpiece.Theres only two horror films with the ability to give me sleepless nights. One is The Exorcist, the other is Black Christmas. Essential.

A psychopath stalks young girls at a sorority house during the holiday season in "Black Christmas". This Canadian made horror movie is by far the best of it's kind I've ever seen. It falls under the categories of "killer is in the house" and "holiday horror", therefore is compared to such classics as 'When a Stranger Calls' and 'Halloween'. The thing is that Black Christmas was made before both of those, yet never got recognition over the years. The plot is pretty simple. A group of sorority sisters get obscene phone calls around Christmastime. It all seems fairly harmless until we see one of the girls murdered and then stored in the attic by the killer. The rest of the characters go to the police to report her missing. After receiving more disturbing phone calls, the cops tap the phone to find out what location the calls are coming from. As the movie moves along, we see a few more people murdered leading to the shocking scene in which the lead character jess is told that "the calls are coming from inside the house".The plot sounds simple and has been done to death in eighties slashers, but Black Christmas TRULY does it best. So many things about this movie are done so right. The caller is not your average deep voiced creeper. His ramblings range from high pitched squeals about "Billy and Agnes", and get even more twisted towards the end. The sounds the killer makes when he's alone with the dead bodies is so unnerving, I've never watched anything like it. The suspect list is short and really only includes the boyfriend Peter. We see throughout the film that he is a very troubled guy and you really start to believe that he is the caller/killer.Despite this being a creepy horror flick, there are a lot of laughs especially from the character of Mrs. Mac (Marian Waldman) and Barb (Margot Kidder). Mrs. Mac is the house mother who loves her booze and loves her cat Claude. She has to be one of my favourite horror characters of all time. The acting is top notch from Waldman and Kidder, but also from our leads Olivia Hussey/Andrea Martin/John Saxon/Keir Dullea. Black Christmas is one of the most frightening and terrifying horror films of all time. It's got the premise of a slasher flick, with out the blood and gore. It uses shadows, creepy phone calls and a mystery in the story that leaves us in fear and with many unanswered questions. This film by the brilliant Bob Clark should be seen by all!10/10

Whilst I was continuing on anti-Xmas crusade what better movie then to cap of the festive celebration with none other than Black Christmas. I bought the DVD a while back ago assuming that it was the 2006 version but by looking at the trailer thank god I got the original version and not the 2006 teen trashy version! Not much over here that is new but you can that a movie like this was the one that would set the 'rules' for future horror movies and slasher flicks. The movie goes straight into the action and does not waste in any time , although it does tend to drift off in a few places the good part was that we introduced to a tense atmospheric moment which but the tone right again. There also some genuine creepy moments that stand out and the odd funny moment here and there . There are also good uses of camera which helps dramatically to its quality and really make this movie stick out. Olivia Hussey was undoubtedly the star of the show but having said that Margot Kidder was amusing and John Saxon's performance was worthy as well. To conclude although Black Christmas did not exactly make my skin crawl , it did however jump out moments and also the fact that it annoyed some bible thumping Evangelical watching this makes me more happy as I hate Christmas and this movie just feels like a kick in the balls to old Santa, one definitely for horror movie fans who can do with some decent horror during this 'cheerful' holiday.BLACK Christmas: 6.8 OUT 10IF THIS MOVIE DOES NOT MAKE YOUR SKIN CRAWL ... THEN IT IS ON TOO TIGHT.

Most of the time I was bored.The acting doesn't amount to much and the story drags. There is one stretch towards the end of the movie that is suspenseful, but it peters out.The way in which the movie is made is very good. The problem is there are no characters to give a hoot about and no real story within which to involve them.It's not unique; it's not engaging.It might have been a good drive-in movie to snuggle up to a date. But I wasn't in a car, and this didn't set any mood.A passable bit of time wasting.

Review title: Very creepy movie..... don't watch it alone
Review_body: This movie was very creepy and it reminded me of Fulci's movie "New York Ripper" in the way that the pycotic caller would call up after he would kill his victims with all kinds of wierd strange noises that sent shivers up your spine.  This movie was about a sorority house that becomes victimized during Christmas after an obnoxious prank caller would call up each time he would kill his prey.  The only problem with this movie that I have is it does not release the identity of the killer.  The boyfriend of one of the tenants had me fooled for awhile but at the end it left me guessing again.  And who is Billy?  Otherwise... I would highly recomend this one to anybody that likes a good scare, but don't watch it alone, this kind of crazy stuff is something that could happen anywhere.

A top-notch horror film from the 1970s, Black Christmas' only drawback is that it occasionally drags. There are a handful of times that you wish things would speed up but perhaps Bob Clark is just building the suspense, because once things begin to happen you'll be far more ensnared than you'd otherwise be.The story concerns a sorority house where the girls receive prank calls from a psycho. When Clare (Lynne Griffin) goes missing, her father (James Edmond) shows up to locate her. Since Clare didn't make it home her sorority friends grow more concerned with the obscene caller and wonder if he is to blame for Clare's disappearance. But Clare's loss is just the beginning as the girls get picked off one-by-one.STORY: $$$$ (The script is really quite strong. Characterization is not forfeited for blood and guts in this tight little slasher. Olivia Hussey and Keir Dullea play a couple who bicker over her pregnancy, Margot Kidder is a lush who seems to be following in the footsteps of their alcoholic house mother Marian Waldman. You will like these characters. Suspense is in large supply as well. Director Bob Clark has a knack for placing you on the edge of your seat and then giving said seat a swift kick at the right time to jar your senses).ACTING: $$$ (The acting is generally strong along the board. Genre favorite John Saxon is terrific as usual in the role of the town sheriff but he is upstaged in the acting department in his own precinct by Doug McGrath as Sergeant Nash. McGrath masterfully portrays the rube desk sergeant who is the butt of every joke. The scene where Margot Kidder leaves him the sorority house' phone number is a riot! Keri Dullea is effectively pompous as Olivia Hussey's emotional unstable boyfriend and Miss Hussey shines as the mother hen even though she opts not be a mother. Art Hindle, man-fur and all, does a fine job as Clare's jock boyfriend while Margot Kidder gives one of her best performances as the crass Barb).NUDITY: None

Review title: Not a slasher film, but the one that started it all!
Review_body: I watched this movie after much searching through Mom & Pop video stores and found a pristine copy. It scared my pants off! BLACK CHRISTMAS is one of those movies that is an unsung classic and is most appreciated by horror buffs. I tried to get my friends to watch it, but they are all into gory, graphic horror opuses like SCREAM and URBAN LEGEND. Unfortunately, those movies have very few scares and are just cheap rip-offs posing as tributes to great films like this one. There really isn't anything to complain about for this movie unless you don't like movies that rely on suspense and hinted-at violence.One reviewer said this movie wasn't a slasher movie because BLACK CHRISTMAS wasn't gory enough. The gore in slasher movies is what ruined the entire horror genre. BLACK CHRISTMAS, HALLOWEEN, TEXAS CHAINSAW MASSACRE, the older films rely on suspense, mind-numbing suspense and require your imagination. People are spoiled by the gore effects in films now, sometimes the effects are gratuitous and don't move the story along at all! BLACK CHRISTMAS' story moves along briskly, dragging the viewer into it, making the movie seem so real! Horror buffs should appreciate the fact that BLACK CHRISTMAS attempts to "befriend" its audience instead of "ripping its guts out"!

I was really looking forward to seeing this movie, in the main because I have read from several sources that this was massively influential on Halloween, the John Carpenter slasher classic. I have to say, though, (and I'm not proud of this) that I found this to be very boring throughout. There's some good POV work, which I guess is the inspiration behind many of the similar scenes in Halloween, but overall it's all a little too soap opera, with endless scenes of Sorority dullards wittering senseless prattle. I must confess that the film has one of the finest taglines I've ever read: "If this film doesn't make your skin crawl...it's on too tight." Pure quality.I don't know, maybe I was expecting too much, but this just left me a little cold.

Review title: Horror movie fans know this is before HalloweeN
Review_body: First off I want to say the remake is totally lame but this one is awesome! It's a fun slow burn horror film and this is before John Carpenter HalloweeN film came out. The story is good, the acting is great, and the script is good. The phone calls are down right disturbing like it's better than the remakes phone call. Yeah this movie is a pre Scream world at the time but it's effective still. The kills are creative but the sad part about this movie is that it's forgetable like not alot of people know this movie. This is my review on Black Christmas (1974), a forgetable underrated classic.

Review title: The slasher before the slasher era.
Review_body: This is kind of a incredible film for 1974. It's a well wrapped movie with some all round decent performances. The plot is simple yet very effective and I don't think I've been scared of a killer in a genre like this for a while. The acting, mostly voice acting for the killer is chilling. It's really emits the sense of insanity above anything else. After watching so many horror movies, I can't believe I thought the things that I did. Especially the later sections of the movie really grab onto you.Now as for the beginning, the movie starts off pretty much right away and is very engaging at the start. Then it does get a bit tedious and drawn out around the beginning-mid section which is probably my least favorite of the movie because nothing really happens.Regarding gore this film has a very light amount. But stil enough disturbing images, especially the ''second'' kill Clare is done very effectively. So for its age, it still did a great job at being somewhat scary. Also what really helps this movie is that its pretty barebones, no special fx, no crazy plot. It's very grounded and real. One of the only caveats is the amount of plotholes and characters that ''need to be alone''. Though it wasn't that annoying. I guess the main offender in this would be Phyl.Barb was one of my favorites throughout this film and seemed to be the lead in the first part of it, Jess gradually took over and became the lead girl which was an interesting shift. That said, Barb was one of the only ones that had some comedic relief in her dialog, though I still think this movie lacks in that department. Most of it is very dry and serious.As with many slashers, the killer is important, but not here. You're not gonna know, its completely kept to your imagination. Which in this case definilty works in favor.The cinematography and directing is honestly really good as well, filled with moments where as a viewer you get real claustrophobic with slow zooms, and long ended shots. One of my favorites is of course the final scene with Jess in bed.That said this movie suffers mostly from some annoying plotholes and ''convenient'' events.All in all this is a must watch for slasher fans, and will still be pretty thrilling if you aren't one. 6.5/10.

This movie is great on so many aspects. It sounds like a unoriginal slasher but this movie is unique different than any other slasher, and the movie itself is what started slasher movies. The soundtrack is great, the shots are amazing, the characters are good and likeable and aren't as dumb as a rock like in most horror movies. The deaths are brutal and creative. The movie has some great turns and twists it takes, and left me guessing, and the end reveal and is amazing and the end shot to the credits is one of the greatest movie endings of all time. This is a true masterpiece and is criminally underrated. MASTERPIECE 10/10.

Here's the one I watched on Halloween but couldn't understand due to all the ruckus going on at the party. And now that I have sat down and watched it properly, I see exactly what makes this one such a classic.Black Christmas is one of those old school horror movies that knows what it's doing, unlike mostly every horror movie that comes out these days. The build-up is long and it sets a tangible mood - this is not a movie trying to rush itself into the blood and gore, which is not really one of the focal points of this movie anyway. Yes, there are stock characters, and there is some thin human conflict going on between them, but you actually care about these characters, and you don't really want to see them die. What a novel concept, right? This makes it all the more disturbing as the stalker's phone calls escalate in insanity and as the bodies begin to pile up. The acting is really good for these kinds of movies, too, with great performances from all of the characters.And goddammit, those phone calls get really, really creepy! I mean, I know what you're thinking; "oh, wow, a phone call, how can that be scary," but no, it is scary. I won't spoil the reasons why for those who haven't seen this gem yet, but the atmosphere of the whole thing is blackened, haunting, claustrophobic and memorable as Hell. This is all very believable, leaving no room for anyone to laugh and pan this movie off as unrealistic or silly. This could happen to anyone! And that, in a similar manner to Halloween, is perhaps the scariest thing about this movie.From before a time when horror equated to ridiculous special effects, gory amputated limbs and torture chambers, Black Christmas hits you hard no matter where or when you watch it, with a ferociously creepy mood, a calculating, dark atmosphere and just enough pizazz to have you looking under your bed this Christmas eve to make sure that there aren't any bogeymen coming to get you. Highly recommended.

Bob Clark's Black Christmas is a criminally underrated film, not just in the horror genre but also in film and art. The film is so real, sometimes you will think it's based on a true story. With a tight, sold script, laser focus direction and great performance from the cast giving grounded, real characters, coming together to make Bob Clark's Black Christmas a instant classic.
The script plays with the audience expectation by the characters actions and a faceless mysterious antagonist in putting us on edge of wondering and guessing what going to happen next and the film will deliberately will leave us with unanswered questions.
On a side not, the film overall message is the most pro choice message I ever saw in cinemas in my life without being a pro choice film that just preaching without any creativity.

When the remake of When A Stranger Calls was out, obviously I was interested in watching the original. Then when I read about the original (which I recall had my sisters totally freaked out back in the day) I saw that the real money is on Black Christmas, which apparently beat everyone to the "the caller is in the house" punch. So I Netflix that, and it sits at the top of my list for months due to its "very long wait." All this time I am getting more and more eager to see it! Then one day, out of the blue, it finally arrives! ...And it's a total snore.Sure, maybe I had elevated expectations, but I don't think it would have gained more had I seen it fresh. The thing is it's Christmas in some Canadian college town, and there's this sorority having a party. We see some killer-POV shots as he climbs this trellis and sneaks into the attic. So we KNOW he's in the house. Then we're introduced to our characters-Olivia Hussey as the mousy, whiny, Canadian-accented Jess. Margot Kidder as the annoying, overtly aggressive alcoholic Barb. She's so annoying even her mother dis-invites her for her Christmas festivities. There's also this irritating Janis Ian clone ("Phil") and this alcoholic den mother Mrs. Mac, seen taking nips from the various bottles of booze she has stashed all over the house. We also meet Jess's highly-strung boyfriend Peter, played by Keir Dullea of 2001 and Bunny Lake is Missing fame, though halfway through the film I was still asking myself "Which one's Keir Dullea?"So it seems that the house has been receiving obscene phone calls, but this was before email, so they couldn't ask him to send a photo. Then-well, you know how they say those plastic dry-cleaning bags are not a toy? One of the sisters finds that out the hard way. Don't worry if you don't catch the first 14 shots of the plastic-encased corpse face as it reposes in the attic-there'll be 28 more interspersed throughout the film, obviously there to make you say "Oh my God! There's a corpse in the attic!" Though after the first hour that changes to: "How come the dumb police haven't found the rather prominently-placed plastic-encased corpse in the attic?" Especially as it is made abundantly clear that it is clearly visible from outside the house. Really, any time before CSI came on the air must have been such a golden age of crime; the cops are so dumb. Fortunately some of them look like John Saxon.Anyway, after a lot more darn boring human drama, the house mother fears that her precious kitty has ascended a vertical ladder and has pushed open a heavy-looking trap door that rests atop it (those wily cats!), for she sticks her head in there and ends up with a hook pulley in her neck for the trouble. Now we have two corpses up in the attic-hey, why don't we have 75 more shots trying to chill us by the fact that there are now TWO corpses in the attic?So by now the police have begun to take the situation seriously, and tap the houses' phone and station a cop outside. They inform Jess and her pal Janis Ian that if the obscene caller calls back, they need to keep him on the phone. Jessica, who has grown even more whiny, mousy and annoying keeps asking the caller "Who is this? What do you want? Who are you?" after like the first 89 calls, when it is clear that he is not going to answer her. Isn't that like a sign a developmental disability? The inability to learn from unsuccessful attempts at something? And what's he going to do, suddenly say "Oh yeah, hi, it's Bob from the Laundromat?" Dumb Jess.Spoilers! Anyway, soon Janis Ian and Lois Lane (Kidder) are piled in bed with ketchup splashed on their faces (this film's idea of gore), and idiot Jess realizes that not a single door or window in the house is locked. Hello? Are you being stalked or what? Then the cops realize that the killer is in the house, and call Jess and tell her "don't ask questions, just do as I say walk to the front door and get out." So what does moron Jess do? Starts screaming "Phil? Barb? Phil? Barb?" Hey, great idea sister. Now why don't you go right upstairs where you know a psychotic killer is lurking? Of course she does, and sees her former friends, all splashed with ketchup, prompting this viewer to scream at the screen: "Have a clue now?!"Now, obviously one needs to be understanding and realize that this movie was made before the classic slasher movie tropes were solidly in place, and that it doesn't move to the same pace we're used to, and seeing a plastic-covered corpse in the attic like 206 times probably WAS scary back in the day, and people weren't used to being stalked by psychopaths, so they wouldn't think to, you know, lock the doors or windows. And they might be tempted to wander upstairs when they have just been told that a rabid killer is up there. You see, people were stupid back in the 70s. We have to understand that. One of the big shocks is that we don't even see our proto-Final Girl kill the psycho. But believe me, that fact is more interesting being read in this review than sitting through the movie for. Spoilers end! ------ Hey, check out Cinema de Merde, my website on bad and cheesy movies (with a few good movies thrown in). You can find the URL in my email address above.

A seriously disturbed man stalks girls at a sorority house over Christmas break. It is sure to a very Black Christmas for most of them ...The film opens to the POV of a prowler outside of a large Victorian house which is a sorority house for women attending classes at the local university. He crawls up an outside ladder leading to the open attic. A bunch of the sorority sisters meanwhile are having a holiday party downstairs. After a terrifying and crude obscene phone call, one of the girls goes upstairs and is murdered by the prowler with a plastic bag and put in the attic to sit by the window.Our main characters include mostly the sorority sisters - Jess, the film's fiery heroine, Barb the house drunk, Phyl the level headed intelligent one, and Mrs. Mack, the house mother who is our comedic relief character always looking for booze anywhere she can find hidden around the house. After a few more phone calls, the killer starts coming out from his attic to attack the girls left at the sorority house during winter break. With only one girl left alive, will the killer be stopped or is she destined to be murdered?Black Christmas might be the best horror film I have ever seen. I rate it so high not only for it's quality, but for setting the tone of my favourite subgenres - the killer in the house and the slasher film. Pretty much every one that comes after this has used elements from this story. When A Stranger Calls and Halloween definitely found inspiration from this terrifying classic. Black Christmas still does it best - I have yet to see a film that musters the whole "the calls are coming from inside the house" routine the way that Bob Clark did in 1974. The moment that line and truth is revealed, the viewers heart sinks with the realization that our characters are in serious danger.The filming locations are set in my hometown of Toronto. I recognized most of the places which was nice, including the police station in the east end and the University of Toronto campus. The house they used is actually the film's biggest plus for me. Not only is the exterior eerie with the winter winds blowing and snow on the ground, but the inside is equally creepy with turns and dark corners and that attic where the killer hides out. Super effective location to make a movie like this.The acting is so superior for a horror film and for a low budget film like this, very unusual. Olivia Hussey is our final girl Jess and she plays the heck out of the role. She is such a strong female lead and is a unique one with her noticeable British accent. Marion Waldman as the house mother is one of the best things about Black Christmas. This lady is constantly seeking out small bottles of Sherry that she has hidden around the house, and is constantly grumbling around the place clearly so over her job as the head of the house. Margot Kidder and Andrea Martin are the supportive female characters and both were perfect for their roles.Everything about this classic is so creepy to me. The obscene phone calls are so manic and crazed that I still get goosebumps thinking about them. The murder scenes are well done, but it is the shadowy figure coming out from the attic each time that sets them up to be as effective as they are. The thing that is always talked about is the ending and how up in the air it is when it comes to figuring out the killers identity. Following an amazing chase scene involving Jess and the maniac, we are left to wonder who the actual killer is. Was it Jess' neurotic boyfriend, one of the other frat boys we see, or some crazed maniac who is perhaps named Billy? We never find and probably never will.Black Christmas is a film to be seen by all and should be studied by any horror director who is looking to make a movie in this genre. It is a perfect masterpiece.10/10

I saw Black Christmas this month I was honestly scared after I had watched it. It was really scary. You didn't know if the killer was Billy or the boyfriend.The film starts of quickly as an unseen, stalking psychopath returns to his home house on Christmas which is now a sorority house which is owned by girls who celebrate Christmas together every year. The killer sneaks into the attic of the house. Soon after, the girls start to get creepy, insane phone calls. They don't realize it's from the attic. In their own HOME! Soon after all of them are murdered.I loved this film and it honestly kept me tuned in to watch the rest. It's like your watching Halloween (1978) all over again. Word of warning though that this is a very slow & long film that goes on forever though for a film like this, slow is good.I suggest you ignore the remake and watch the original. 9.5/10

This is considered a cult, classic and protoslasher, all the terms popular with fans and scholars of genre and slasher filmmaking. It's obvious being made in the mid 70s that the Italian Giallo (POV shots) was popularly used and Bob Clark's earliest entry with Children Shouldn't Play with Dead Things also had influence on this film.The innocence of Jess, played by Argentinean Olivia Hussey (real name Olivia Osuna) was perfectly cast opposite of her sorority sisters, like loud-mouthed Barb played by the late Margot Kidder and the outrageous Marian Waldman as the house mother! Supporting actors such cult veteran star, John Saxon and Crononberg's The Brood leading actor, Art Hindle.The rest of the interior location are excellent in creating (although the house is insanely large) claustrophobic and dark. Strong dubbing of the murderer's voice still create a distrubing chill today.Roy Moore wrote this script in his late 20s Bob Clark was not a beginner,he was building a grouping of filmwork. This film precedes the similar plot twists of Halloween and When a Stranger Calls. They are some weak spots in the story but the chill feel of shots, oddly though behind cheerful imagery of Christmas.This is definitely a film that should be seen and appreciate by filmbuffs and horror fans.

Review title: Good, solid film. Well worth it to see!
Review_body: Excellent film which combines good acting and an interesting plot, which it seems is very unusual in the horror genre. It's Christmas and as the girls prepare to leave their sorority house they are plagued by harassing phone calls. Soon the calls lead to murder as an intruder breaks into the house and starts killing off the girls who have not yet left. Now its a quest to find the killer before everyone is dead. Margot Kidder gives a wonderful, hilarious performance as the perpetually drunken sorority member. And Olivia Hussey is worth seeing as well for her solid performance. One major thing that should be noted is that this movie preceded Halloween by a good four years, and it seems obvious now how that movie was influenced by this one. Further, unlike later horror movies, the heroine isn't a near saint, rather she is just as imperfect as the other characters. Overall this movie works on many different levels and should definitely be seen by fans of the genre.

Review title: Season's Griefings, The Gore the Merrier
Review_body: Intelligent, frightful, part of the 1970s "Big 3", which includes "Halloween" (1978) and "When A Stranger Calls" (1979). Olivia Hussey is fine as a sorority sister who is terrorized by unnerving calls to the house by an obscene presence. Margot Kidder, as an asthmatic sister, is foul-mouthed, funny, and outstanding. Keir Dullea plays a possibly disturbed pianist, who is also Hussey's boyfriend. The setting at Christmas time with all the lights, snow, coldness, is well-presented. The sorority house is suitably creepy, atmospheric, and claustrophobic, even in the Christmas decor. An "eyeball" scene may freeze your blood, and the closing scenes are startling.

I'm not sure why a lot of people like this film.  I didn't think it was all that great.  Also known as SILENT NIGHT, DEADLY NIGHT, directed by Bob Clark of PORKY'S fame, this one involves psychotic killer who hides in the attic of a sorority house and starts killing off all the "girls", one by one.  
I say "girls" because most of them look over 30 instead of 20, especially Margot Kidder as the slutty one with the foul mouth.  (Check out Brian DePalma's SISTERS if you want to see Kidder in a terrifying role)The film does just fine until the last 15 minutes or so when Olivia Hussey goes upstairs to look for her friends and doesn't follow police instructions to leave the house.  What a dumb bitch.  Anybody who is THAT dumb deserves to be killed.It's also pretty obvious 40 minutes into the film who the killer is, but director Clark tries to pull a fast one at the very end of the film by implying that it's not him.  It looks like Clark wants to have it both ways, casting doubt upon the whole thing and trying to leave it open-ended like he does.  There's no gore being shown and very little blood, making the whole thing look pretty tame by today's standards.   In fact, the only thing missing is the ax-wielding Santa.  But no matter folks, that'll come in a later film.The Critical Mass DVD has filmographies for most of the cast along with a short, uninformative interview with Saxon that doesn't reveal much of anything, and no extras from Bob Clark.  At least not in the DVD version I saw.  Maybe Clark was embarrassed by the whole thing, who knows  He should be.3 out of 10

The little known slasher named black Christmas happens to not only be the first serial slasher ever made, it is the icon to the likes of Halloween, friday the 13th etc and to this day is timeless. The plot as the title suggests is based in a sorority house on christmas eve and the poor girls lives getting distressed from an unknown caller that funnily enough holds alot of intrigue partly due to margot kidders performance was hysterical and ahead of its time. The rest of the cast show thier worth, and a very errie resemblance to ted bundy as the protagonist which happened to get banned around the late 70s due to how similar it portrayed the horrific chi omega sorority murders. Was later re-released in the 80s & slowly became a timeless classic.

Pre-dating what is generally considered the ultimate Slasher film by several years - the original "Halloween" - "Black Christmas" is a highly-underrated, and amazing horror-slasher flick which would set the standard for practically every slasher film to follow - from the ringing telephones, the 'don't go upstairs', re-hearings and of course a strong female lead."Black Christmas'" strong female lead is the equally underrated Olivia Hussey, whose fantastic accent is a special bonus to her calm and sympathetic character Jessica. While the majority of slasher films all feature a female lead (though there are exceptions like "A Nightmare on Elm Street 2", "Prom Night 3: The Last Kiss" and "Friday the 13th VI: Jason Lives" which all have a male lead) not every female lead is as terrific as Hussey's Jessica. (Exceptions being Neve Campbell's Sidney from the "Scream" Trilogy, Heather Langenkamp's Nancy from "A Nightmare on Elm Street", Lar Park-Lincoln's Tina from "Friday the 13th VII: The New Blood" and of course Jaime Lee Curtis' Laurie from various "Halloween").Jessica's resourcefulness, and cool personality makes her a character that you really care about, and the fact that she has various real life stories going on (abortion for example - something I don't think has been featured in a slasher since "Black Christmas") makes her a very likable character. The majority of the characters in "Black Christmas" are actually very realistic and likable. Margot Kidder's Barbie provides a lot of the comic relief, but has the most tragic death also. Andrea Martin is excellent as frizzy-haired (though its nice frizzy-hair) Phyllis. John Saxon is always great in his performances, and his role as Lt. Fuller is no exception. Keir Duller does a good job of playing perhaps the most unlikeable, but very realistic, Peter, Jessica's over-bearing and high-strung boyfriend. Marian Waldman is a riot as the house-mother for the sorority girls, Mrs. Mac.The plot, pacing and general story is probably nothing new to anyone who has seen "Scream" or "Halloween", as previously mentioned, many slashers take a least a note or two from "Black Christmas", which does everything splendidly. Great direction, interesting camera angles, a couple of good jump scenes, and then there's the telephone calls...perhaps one of the most disturbing things in all slasher movies.So overall, "Black Christmas" is an amazing slasher-horror film, setting the stage for a myriad of followers over the years, but thirty years later, does not seem out-dated or cheesy. Sure, there's not a lot of gore, but that's not necessarily a bad thing. And for the pre-cursor to the likes of "Halloween" and "Scream" to be this good, then it's certainly worth a watch, even if just to watch for all the things in the film that will eventually become standard conventions in slasher films.

Review title: Since its Christmas i thought i'd review this Classic Film Black Christmas.
Review_body: This is one of the best horror films I've, seen! and I love it.I feel that this film is underrated and overlooked and some people don't realise how good it actually is.I was very impressed by this film the first time i saw it and it has been in my head ever since. This film has everything,great acting,great likable characters a nice location,and a story that works very well. Since this is such an old film i'm sure that a lot of people have seen it so i don't have to explain much of the story,Its about a crazed killer stalking a bunch of girls at their sorority house on campus and the killer starts killing people one by one. This may sound like your typical horror movie but believe me its Not!. This movie works well because of its atmosphere and its creepiness. I found this to be a very dark and chilling film it was also suspenseful and had some mystery behind it,and i quite liked the mystery,it makes a nice change because most horror films just have a bunch of kills but there seemed to be more to this film than just killings.I guess i just thought this film had more of a story to it than most horror films do. There are a lot of chilling and creepy scenes in this film that will make your skin crawl and my personal favourite was the weird phone calls,i thought they were done well,and the killer spoke in a way that made your skin crawl.he was creepy and his voice was creepy. The actor that played the killer did a good job and i thought this film had some good idea's like the killer hiding in the attic of the girls sorority house i thought that was a great idea and i found it creepy that he was up there watching people out the window and nobody knew he was up there and the heavy breathing from the killer is also very creepy especially when we don't see him.I liked him as a villain and i liked the lead girl Olivia Hussey she was pretty and i found her likable in the film and she played her role well and the rest of the cast were good too.I liked the whodunit aspect of the film and I thought the twist was clever and the ending was effectively Creepy.This is a classic film and deserves a watch,its highly recommended.This excellent film deserves a 10/10.

Director Bob Clark is best known for his 1983 film A Christmas Story, the feel-good tale of a child who wants a Red Rider BB gun from Santa Claus. What a lot of people don't know, however, is that Mr. Clark has approached the holiday season from a much darker perspective. And his 1974 slasher, Black Christmas, is surprisingly effective.I'll be completely honest. I expected shoddy acting and lame scares to abound. Black Christmas does have its fair share of the preceding, but it also generates a somber, brooding atmosphere that's heightened by the frenzied piano stylings of a college student, named Peter, who appears to be on the verge of mental collapse. This guy is dating one of the sisters who lives in the sorority house where the bulk of the terror takes place—this comes in the form of harassing phone calls and some odd, funhouse-mirror-style first-person perspectives—and he's meant to be suspect number one. The elusive psycho's identity is never revealed, and it's clear that screenwriter Roy Moore wants us to believe that Peter is, in fact, the bad guy, but some last-second revelations result in the old switcheroo. This, along with a number of other strategies used in Black Christmas, seem frighteningly clichéd in this day and age, but I can only imagine that they were fairly groundbreaking during their own time (okay, so Psycho is really the movie that spawned the modern slasher, but let's at least give credit to a movie that's notably more tense than most of the horror to emerge from contemporary Hollywood).As previously disclosed, this isn't to say that Black Christmas doesn't have faults. Some of the acting—and corresponding character responses— to what's going on in and around said sorority house are completely unbelievable. The father of a missing sister, for example, calmly explores the campus when his daughter doesn't show-up for a rendezvous they had planned early one afternoon. Even after the police get involved and it's somewhat clear that foul play is afoot, this guy never exhibits any urgent sense of emotion to locate his daughter. There's also the presence of a pointless old woman who, for one inexplicable reason or another, lives in the sorority house. She curses and has liquor stashed in books and septic tanks throughout the home. I'm guessing she was meant to serve as some sort of comic foil, but she's more of an annoyance than anything else.That's Black Christmas in a nutshell. Would I recommend it as a cozy little holiday horror movie? Sure. It's certainly not bad, and it has its creepy moments, but don't expect the reinvention (or invention?) of the wheel.

Black Christmas, directed and produced by Bob Clark is one of the best Christmas films ever made! Clark used a lot of vetern film making tools to add a lot of depth and mystery to this film. The story was very fresh, original, and stays on track with great pacing. Black Christmas was not only a Christmas classic, but sparked a lot of influence towards John Carpenter's Halloween, Wes Craven's Scream, and Sean S. Cunningham's Friday The 13th, with it's horror elements & tactics.The lead characters were extremely entertaining, showing a lot of pure emotions. The supportive cast complimented the leads well, because they actually had purpose, unlike most supportive characters in horror and/or Christmas films. I like how Bob Clark made the killer a complete mystery; he didn't even let us see his face! The phone calls and actual physical violence he portrays was vicious, and very creepy.The screenplay by Roy Moore was right to the point, and unfiltered, which I can really appreciate for this kind of film. Some dialogues and scenes got a tad stale, but the screenplay was above average, and carried great merit.There was only a few things that I could really nit pick in this film. The story definitely was original and inspiring to other film makers, but I'd be lying if I said there wasn't a few disposable or dry scenes. Other than that, there's other minor things you could fault, but it's not something that would really bring the rating down.Overall, Black Christmas is a must watch every year before Christmas! You will be hooked from beginning to end!

Black Christmas is one of the greatest horror movies of all time. It builds up a scary atmosphere not only blood and gore like other movies. (Friday The 13th) Imagine getting phone calls and on the other end someone is using three or four voices, their comments are sexual in nature, they are filled with profanity and they say I'm going to kill you. (ring a bell, SCREAM) The phone calls are very strange and bizzare and just listening to them gives you the chills (the calls are coming from inside the house). There is also a bit of a who done it, you think you know who it is and then there is a twist. There is violence like all good horror movies, but not too much, there a funny scenes. I especially liked the directing of the scenes with the killer. We don't see the killer but we move with his eyes, and we hear him panting, puffing, and making strange noises. Phone calls were excellent, with the weirdest noises coming from the killer. great performance by the actors. This movie was made before a lot of the other horror movies and many have tried to copy it greatness but failed. WATCH IT!!

I love horror films, but could only make it half way in before turning this snooze fest off. Too much talk and no horror. They should've added more slashing and blood and called it Red Christmas. Watch only if you have trouble sleeping because this will knock you out.

Review title: The greatest and most refreshing and unique horror film of all time
Review_body: This movie is great on so many aspects. It sounds like a unoriginal slasher but this movie is unique different than any other slasher, and the movie itself is what started slasher movies. The soundtrack is great, the shots are amazing, the characters are good and likeable and aren't as dumb as a rock like in most horror movies. The deaths are brutal and creative. The movie has some great turns and twists it takes, and left me guessing, and the end reveal and is amazing and the end shot to the credits is one of the greatest movie endings of all time. This is a true masterpiece and is criminally underrated. MASTERPIECE 10/10.

Review title: Before "Scream" ... before "Friday the 13th" ... before "Halloween" ... before "When a Stranger Calls" - there was this!
Review_body: Before "Scream" ... before "Friday the 13th" ... before "Halloween" ... before "When a Stranger Calls" - there was this!A uniquely creepy (the scene where one victim is stabbed with a glass unicorn is particularly harrowing) movie that seems to be one of the earlier slashers, though in many ways though it has slasher hallmarks, it really is not a slasher; the death scenes are not gruesome and hardly seen, the bodycount is low...A refreshing movie featuring relatively intelligent characters, all the more surprising considering they're sorority sisters, and don't prance around half-naked!! Wow!!Also, some fine moments of serious drama, and a great cast, particularly Olivia Hussey and John Saxon (from horror "A Nightmare on Elm Street" fame).Unfortunately overlooked and underrated, this is a great film.

Review title: it was ok WARNING CONTAINS A SPOILER
Review_body: i was reading some of the other comments on this film and most of them say how great and scary this movie is. don't listen to that. i will give this movie one thing it started the horror genre, the way Bob Clark directed it was alot like the way John Carpenter did Halloween, but Halloween blows this movie away, another movie that this is like is Scream with the phone calls, but once again Scream blows this movie away, though i will say the phone calls were good, very strange, my problem with the movie is it is way too slow, put it this way the first hour and ten minutes are kind of a waste, but the final 30 minutes are very good, the concept to the movie is good, the writter fails to bring the goods, it's worth a check though. one other problem i have with this film is you never find out who the killer is. i give it *** out of ***** only cause of the storyline.

Review title: Amazing - the birth of the slasher
Review_body: This is from 74, so slashers weren't there yet. I think this film started it. Bob Clark is an incredible director. The film is great. Forget the remakes. Watch the original! :)

Black Christmas, also known as Silent Night, Evil Night (the title they initially gave it for the first American screenings so movie-goers wouldn't mistake it for a blaxploitation film), is generally considered to be one of the first classic slasher flicks, and apparently even had a hand in inspiring John Carpenter's Halloween. But you might know director Bob Clark from a very different Christmas movie - one that will probably be playing on at least one 24-hour loop on some basic cable channel this week - A Christmas Story.It's a shame that this movie didn't get the recognition it deserved at the time, but it has gone on to become a cult horror film in the years since. It's smart, well-acted, wonderfully shot, terrifying, and even genuinely funny at times.** SPOILERS! **I knew I was in for a treat during the opening shots, moving seamlessly between the inside and outside of the beautiful sorority house and showing POV shots of the mysterious killer making his way around the home (I especially loved the shot of him climbing the trellis). There's a great theme throughout of happy, celebratory, or even just mundane things going on in the house while the killer lurks within... super creepy. I think the whole "Babysitter and the Man Upstairs" legend in general is TERRIFYING so the use of it was great - it's one thing to know that the threat is outside trying to get in, but what about when you're locking it inside with you? The search party coming by and almost cheerfully reminding the girls to "just keep your doors and windows locked and you'll be safe!" was a chilling reminder.The phone calls were surprisingly scary - and surprisingly vulgar. The killer's alternating between multiple voices/personalities, seeming to scold himself at times, crying, screaming... the calls became more and more frenzied and his incomprehensible fury makes him unrecognizable as even a human threat. There's no way to know his background, his motives, which makes him terrifying in a much less tangible way. We can't relate to him, we can't see our own pain or shortcomings in his motivation, which makes him completely unpredictable and alien.I enjoyed that, aside from the (possibly unrelated?) girl being killed in the nearby park, the main characters don't have any idea that murder is afoot until it's too late. The victims themselves have NO idea, but even Jess (Olivia Hussey) has no indication that anyone has been killed until she finally swings Barb's bedroom door open in the last 15 minutes or so - we're the only people privy to that information.Speaking of which, the kills - surprisingly few, really, considering its status as a slasher film - are all creative and well done. There's no lingering on blood spurting from knife wounds, no over-exaggerated looks of horror that go on for too long, no shirts being ripped open for no reason besides showing a hint of breasts. They're quick and effective but still fun. My favorite is probably Barb being stabbed with her own crystal unicorn grabbed from behind her bed - shot beautifully and the juxtaposition of Jess listening to a young choir singing carols downstairs is just awesome - but the image of Clare in the rocking chair with the plastic garment bag sucked into her mouth is classic for a reason. That reveal definitely got a gasp from me, and the occasional return to the attic - showing his hand rocking the chair her corpse sat in, or her cat innocently licking the bag she was contained in - was a cruel reminder that the search for her was hopeless.There's no denying that there's a strong feminist undertone to the whole film - or, really, far less subtle than that. This movie taking place in the early 70's - and just a year after Roe v. Wade was decided - is important context for its content. Women being terrorized by a dominating and violent male presence is par for the course for countless horror and slasher films, but it feels more relevant here, more close to home. Barb's murder being the most intimate - taking place in her own bedroom, practically in the throes of sleep, with one of her own belongings - was no accident considering we saw her crassness offend multiple male authority figures (Clare's father and a local sergeant, most obviously, but she fights back - verbally anyway - against the crazed prank caller, too).In addition to the more direct threat of the looming killer, we have more pervasive examples of men attempting to silence women in a variety of ways. The bumbling sergeant first ignoring Clare going missing because she's probably shacked up with some guy and then ignoring the prank calls because it's "probably one of your boyfriends playing a joke". Clare's father is basically just walking disapproval throughout the entire movie, turning his nose up at Mrs. Mac's language, posters around the sorority house, and Barb's attempts to be humorous in her slurred, drunken state.And, more directly, there is Jess informing her boyfriend, Peter (Keir Dullea), in no unclear terms that she is pregnant with his child and seeking an abortion. Again, the freshness of Roe v. Wade in American society informed his hateful response - "don't you think about anyone but yourself", and later "let's get one thing straight: you are not going to abort that baby". He's outraged at the idea that she dare make a decision about her own body without his express approval, and is pushed further into his own spiral of deflecting blame when she rejects his very matter-of-fact marriage proposal. He's belligerent to the point of being rightfully suspected as the killer - especially after seeing him destroy that piano after his unfavorable recital.The irony of such gruesome acts being carried out during what is supposed to be the happiest, coziest time of year is constant but not obnoxiously so - it's more something that we notice rather than something that is being told to us, if that makes sense. The warm glow of the colored Christmas lights, the metallic tinsel on the wreaths, the campus emptying out as people scurry off to see their families... it all feels incredibly nostalgic until we remember there's a goddamn psychopath holed up in the attic.Which leads us to the ending, which is amazingly dark, even for a horror flick. There is so often some kind of humanization of the villain, or maybe a dramatic standoff between the final survivor and the killer. We almost get that, or at least we think we might, when Jess is cowering in the basement after Peter smashes his way in. When the police find her slumped over with a dead Peter on top of her, we think there's a chance - albeit small - that the nightmare is over. Jess has not only defeated her would-be killer, but she's defeated this domineering male presence that is trying to control her. But as the camera pans away from her, sedated in bed, and glides by the attic - mumbling and giggling echoing off the walls - and eventually outside, we hear the phone ringing and ringing as the credits roll, and we're reminded that evil often does prevail.Ultimately, a brilliant and sorely under-appreciated film. Go watch it now, get into the Christmas spirit!

Black Christmas is the story of a group of girls in a sorority house being stalked and picked off by a psycho.  Sounds familiar.  Well Black Christmas came out long before all the those others and laid the foundation for them. This is the first flick to offer those cool killer POV shots.  This slasher also likes to use the phone, his phone calls give me chills just thinking about them.  This guy is insane!  The slashings are cool and it has a great twist.  Oh yea and this flick is actually creepy.  Bob Clark does a great job creating a bleak atmosphere just right for some slashings.  Bleak, creepy, and really cool.  What more do you want from a slasher? A must for all genre fans.  Go find it!  An underground masterpiece!

Review title: I liked it better than Halloween
Review_body: If Alfred Hitchcock's Psycho is the grandfather of the slasher genre, then Bob Clark's Black Christmas is the father, spawning/Inspiring John Carpenter's Halloween.While Halloween became a mainstream success, Black Christmas was destined for cult stardom only. Which is a shame because I enjoyed Black Christmas more, and I believe it's a better film.Firstly, all the characters have personalities and little quirks that help keep you more engaged. Theres next to no "spelled out" backstory for the slasher villan, most of it is hinted at through the phone calls the girls receive, but he's still intimidating and scary. Also this movie is suprisingly funny. It knows not to take itself too seriously, which helps the horror scenes feel serious and frightning.If you haven't already, I highly recommend seeing this excellent film

Review title: The original and perhaps the best slasher film ever made.
Review_body: The girls of a sorority house are being tormented by a twisted prank caller who continually calls to convey increasingly vile and abusive sentiments. What at first appears to be a sick joke eventually turns violent for the girls during the season of supposed goodwill and merriment.The original and maybe even the best, Black Christmas' set the ball rolling for the slasher genre and was the biggest influence for the phenomenally successful John Carpenter classic, Halloween' (1978), which was, in fact, originally conceived as a sequel. Although Italian director, Mario Bava, had previously created what some see as the first slasher movie, Bay of Blood' (1971), it was Black Christmas' that was to become recognised as the catalyst for one of the most lucrative sub-genres of horror cinema. Bob Clark (who previously made the kooky, enjoyable, low-budget zombie film Children Shouldn't Play With Dead Things' (1972)), still at this point something of an amateur director, took a simple yet naturally frightening concept and turned it into one of the most unsettling and nerve-wracking one hundred minutes in cinematic history. Only a select few films such as The Haunting' (1963) and Alien' (1979) are atmospheric enough to truly equate to the eeriness and feelings of apprehension that are to be induced by Black Christmas'.The simplicity of the production is what makes it so endearing. There are no overly bloody death sequences or unlikely, comic-book style events; the viewer is just presented with an unnerving tale which could easily have a strong basis in reality. Inventive camerawork and POV shots as well as a superlative use of lighting are the elements that combine to achieve the desired results.
