The often pseudo-claustrophobic environment of the sorority house, from where the vast majority of events occur, offers the perfect, vulnerable and unguarded location susceptible to intrusion and thus attributes to the continual foreboding atmosphere. Clark was not afraid to take time building both the story and characterisation as well as introduce the viewer to the aspects that he would use to build the suspense. This is prepared before plunging the viewer into a seemingly uncontrolled nightmare that one experiences along with the protagonists. Another aspect that firmly stands out is the mysterious way that everything is presented; even at the very end, very little has truly been explained yet everything seems like it should have an obvious explanation. Even in its undoubted simplicity, Black Christmas' has complicated facets that require thought from the viewer to entirely comprehend the film. In some ways, the concealing of several key points puts the viewer's knowledge of events on a par with the actual characters.Black Christmas' is also complimented wonderfully by strong acting performances from Olivia Hussey, Margot Kidder, John Saxon and a highly pleasant and amusing turn from Marian Waldman. Despite the tiny budget, this is a highly polished horror film that genuinely belongs among the elite of the genre. This is where it all started and those familiar with later slasher films such as Halloween', Friday the 13th' (1980), Slumber Party Massacre (1982) and The House on Sorority Row' (1983) should be able to spot several of the now-clichés that first materialized in Black Christmas'. My rating for Black Christmas' - 8½/10.

This has got to be one of the most genuinely terrifying movies I have ever seen! There are many terrifying aspects of this film. The soundtrack is horrifying with it's various screams, vocals, and the constant Twang of the piano. The atmosphere is haunting with the various camera angles showing you the killer's point of view and the consistent image of the first victim in the rocking chair with the plastic bag still wrapped around her head flashing across the screen at various moments and then there's the telephone calls. The terrifying screams, moans, and various voices that the killer uses during these calls will make the hair stand up on the back of your neck. The most terrifying aspect of this film though is the fact that you never find out who the killer really is. The viewer is lead down a particular path and falsely believes that they know the identity of the killer but then the film betrays the viewer. This is sheer cinematic genius and one of the essential elements for true terror. This film set the benchmark for future films such as "Halloween" "Friday the 13th" and "Nightmare on Elm Street"...ESSENTIAL VIEWING!

Review title: Prototypical and exemplary slasher-film with a realistic and suspenseful atmosphere
Review_body: Say 'Slasher Film' and most people will probably say 'Scream', 'Friday the 13th', or 'Halloween'what's more, most will probably be referring to the franchises each of these has spawned rather than have a particular movie in mind. The fact that (despite the inevitable and tired re-make) most people don't know about/haven't seen 'Black Christmas' is certainly criminal as in terms of chills, suspense, and quality of filmmaking it is far ahead of virtually every other film in the slasher genre. What's more, 'Black Christmas has the prestige of being (after respectful nods have been made towards 'Silent Night. Bloody Night' and some Italian gialli) the film which kick-started the genre.As befitting a slasher film, the set-up will be familiar: a group of teenagers, here composed of a group of Sorority girls and a few boyfriends, are picked off one-by-one by a maniacal killer. In addition, other slasher tropes like the menacing phone-calls-coming-from-inside-the-house, the holiday theme, and the (kind of) final girl really do put most viewers in a state where surprises are not to be expected. However, 'Black Christmas' certainly raises itself above the imitations that followed in presenting a realistic and engaging atmosphere which captures the suspense of what is, when looked at without cinematically desensitized eyes, a scary idea: a mentally deranged person killing without apparent motive. The realistic touch comes from the pared down direction which is reminiscent (or should that be prescient?) of Carpenter's approach in Halloween, the time taken to build up a relationship with the characters, the absence of over-the-top Tom Savini-style "kills" (which have the effect of distancing the viewer from the fact that someone has died), and a thankful absence of the strained conservative moral message that teenagers should listen to adults and avoid drugs and sex before marriage etc.It is a wonder this film is not more widely recognised. I believe it is due to the fact that it doesn't present us with a tangible figure of fear like Myers, Voorhees, Freddy, the Fisherman, or Ghostface etc who, even though masked, nonetheless localise and personify fear and in doing so suggest ways to combat it. In contrast, 'Black Christmas', apart from a startling eyeball shot, offers us nothing to hang our fear (and our consumerist franchise fetishes) on. As such, while 'Black Christmas' and its killer may not have entered the pop-culture lexicon, this has meant that the film has retained its power and sense of discomfort and maybe, like the killer, the film belongs in the periphery where most people don't look.

I still don't know who it is! I thought that when I saw that the focus was around sorority girls I thought it was going to be iffy. It hooked me from the beginning. You wonder who is doing it and where are the call coming from. Once you think you know who might be doing it, it is unclear. The voices on the phone are creepy! Wonderful movie to watch for Halloween.

Review title: Scary, creepy, old movie, don't answer the phone
Review_body: This movie reminds me of that tale everybody has heard by now. But instead of it being a baby-sitter, it takes place in a co-ed dorm. Somebody who sneaked into the attic by climbing a rose vine (or something like that) and makes obscene phone calls to the kids. one by one the kids get killed off. The people who are alive just think the kids are missing. Why somebody would stay in a dorm all Christmas holiday instead of going home is beyond me. This is a good movie considering it was made in 1974. One year older than me. After reading all these comments want me to watch the movie again.(considering i didn't know who Kidder was back then). The only problem is that it's very hard to find these days.

Review title: A great slasher film - Sadly underrated
Review_body: Horror films have a bad reputation for being completely senseless and lacking a sense of artistic integrity. I'm not going to lie, some of them do fall into that category. However, there are moments in cinema history when you get a film that defines the genre. Something that is so good that it transcends the usual trappings that hold films of its kind down. A Nightmare on Elm Street, Halloween, The Exorcist, Alien, and The Texas Chainsaw Massacre are just a few of the horror gems that are well made and also very scary.The story is quite simple. At a sorority house, the girls are getting ready to go home for Christmas but begin receiving phone calls from a strange caller who won't give his name. The next day, many girls leave, but one who should have met her father doesn't turn up, which causes great concern for her safety. When another girl goes missing, the police begin searching the area and find a body nearby. Meanwhile, with only three students left in the sorority house, the phone calls continue, getting more and more menacing each time, but unknown to the remaining members of the house, the caller, and perhaps the killer, is closer to them than their nightmares could ever imagine.Keep in the mind that the killer calling his victims before he strikes them practically began here. Some might tell you it started with the original When A Stranger Calls, which was actually released a few years later, and it certainly took place before Scream, which was released in 1996. Black Christmas was the first to effectively use this technique and I must say this film uses it the best. While, menacing phone calls can get tiresome in some thrillers, the calls in this film generate fear and tension with each one that is made. They gradually become more violent and disturbing, to the point that they're almost unbearable. This isn't someone merely playing a game, this is someone with deep emotional and mental problems. The phone actually becomes a character itself because for most of the film it's our only link to the killer. We learn very little about him but what we do learn about him is through his acting out on the phone. I guess you can say the phone is an extension of his character.I also liked that this film believe less is more. There is very little blood and most of the violence is implied. Sometimes a visceral approach to horror can work but I think horror is most effective when they leave a lot of it up to the imagination. Your mind certainly creates a more disturbing image then they might've even shown.Speaking of the killer, he's probably one of the better ones to appear in a film of this nature. The most fascinating thing about him is you don't know anything about him throughout the film. The fact that he has randomly chosen to strike these girls makes him all the more frightening because it proves that sometimes crime is unexplained and completely unprovoked. You never really get a clear look at him, since he's merely a voice on the phone or cleverly shrouded in darkness but he's still a very powerful presence. The fact that he's seen rarely makes his few big "appearances" all the more terrifying. I'll provide two pictures of his most frightening exposures in the film and i guarantee when you see it, even after seeing these, those images will still stay with you long after the film is over.Halloween is commonly known for its effective opening scene which a steadycam shot that is supposed to be the perspective of the killer coming upon the house. That technique was made popular in that film but it was used first here and it's actually used often to great effect. The camera is constantly giving you the sense that danger is approaching and it's a very simple but effective technique. A lot of the film is seen from his perspective so it becomes very interesting to view a film through the killer's eyes.No good horror film can work without engaging leads and Black Christmas certainly has a pretty good cast. Olivia Hussy, who at this time was very popular due to her turn as Juliet in Romeo and Juliet, is a very likable heroine. She differs from most because she's definitely flawed and is nowhere near perfect but it also makes her all the more human. She's able to carry the film and while she's not the strongest actress around, she certainly handles the task at hand very well. The rest of the sorority girl cast consist of mostly unknowns but Margot Kidder, who would go on to play Lois Lane, is featured as one and quite funny as the booze hound of the house. John Saxon, of A Nightmare on Elm Street fame, appears here as a detective and is always a welcomed presence in anything he's in.Black Christmas is pretty hard to find in stores. I had to get mine on amazon but if you can try to catch this film. It's simple, effective and very scary. It should be given more credit for its role in shaping the slasher genre and maybe with the release of the remake this year, the original will get its much deserved mainstream attention. Check out Black Christmas this Halloween season, you won't be disappointed.

It's a shame I wasn't shown this film sooner. Now it's not really a 10/10 but I'd give it a strong 8 to a 9... but I think it deserves a 10 because of the simple fact that it REALLY is ahead if it's time and influenced not only Halloween but MAN this film was more than ahead of its time. There's no cliche teen sex or even nudity, the characters shine all around the block it's not really one main character that has too much of the spotlight until it starts going down by the numbers. The music isn't as effective say as Halloween but it gets the job done. The sound effects are skin crawling and the ending is the most iconic endings I've ever seen in ANY horror film. I absolutely loved this film and just as I make it my duty to watch Halloween every Halloween I will watch this film every Christmas. Good job Clarke, you have 2 of one of the most iconic Christmas films down in the bag. He invented the slasher genre with this and inspired many to come.

Review title: Mind numbing chiller that stays with you long after....
Review_body: I remember first seeing this film in the early eighties, i was about six or seven, and horror films have a stronger affect on a child than they do an adult, this film proves it. I was utterly terrified to go to sleep in the dark after Black Christmas, the film's bogeyman is the film's mentality, the audience sees his point of view as he stalks the sorority house where the students are staying and the music is chilling and uncanny, its almost like the killer is an entity rather than a human being, and when he terrorises the girls with obscene phone calls the camera slowly pans over their reactions creating a chilling atmosphere, like the killer's voice is searing into their minds. It's a frightening and scary picture.In January this year though, i bought the film on DVD as a creepy childhood reminder, it has lost none of it's power but now that I'm in my late twenties the effect isn't the same. but i will watch it at least twice every December. A Classic.

Alfred Hitchcocks Psycho was the starting point of slasher films, Black Christmas was the main point of slashers for the 70s because lots of 70s horror slashers used some of the ideas from this like Halloween for instance where you see the vision of the killer himself like on Black Christmas. But no sequels though only a crappy remake in 2006 and even that was 33 years after the 1974 classic.The 2006 remake sucks, it tries to hard to be gory and violent when it doesn't look real, so DON'T WATCH IT (unless you want a good laugh at how rubbish it is) 10/10

This film practically invented the "slasher" genre, and it is better than most films that fit that category.  It can make you laugh one minute (the sorority housemother is a riot!), then send chills down your spine (that voice on the phone is just plain creepy), the next.  Often copied, but almost never duplicated.  It is an original, and anyone who enjoys horror films must see it.  Be warned, even after all these years, the first telephone call from the mysterious stranger, is a shocker! Director Bob Clark (Porky's, A Christmas Story), serves up a first class chiller.

Black Christmas has been the scariest psycho horror film I have ever seen!This is like an old version of Scream and Urban Legend because the killer is inside the house when he makes these creepy, crude calls.The story begins at a girl's sorority house on Christamas eve when an outsider decided to climb up to a window on the next story and then sneaked into the attic. And then, the creepy, crude calls began.The creepiest moments were when a girl named Claire Harrison decided to pack her stuff and leave the sorority house and suddenly, she could hear someone was in the closet and when she approached it, she was suffocated with plastic and the killer dragged her body through the trap door of the attic. And when morning came, the girls went outside to go look for her, and sitting in the rocking chair next to the camera [ close to the window of the attic] was little Claire with a plastic bag over her head!!! The second one was when Mrs. Quate went throughthe trap door of the attic and before she could do anything else, a hook went through her head! And another was when Barbera ( Jess's friend) was murdered by the killer when he came into her room and got hold of the horn of one of the glass unicorn figures!! And the last one was when Jess thought the killer was arrested and gone, he still lurked in the attic with Mrs. Quate with a hook in her head the cat and strangled Claire Harrison. And then, the telephone rang again.THE COPS NEVER FOUND HIM AND THE OTHER TWO BODIES!!!!!!!!! And Jess and the cops thought that it was her boyfriend Peter who was doing all the murders! To make things sound scary, the killer never shows himself in this motion picture. The only thing we get to see are his light green eyes. And to make things worse, Jess receives calls that came from the upstairs when she doesn't know it. DARN IT! You can hear the victims being strangled, suffocated and murdered!!! You want to know something? Once you watch this movie, you will never want to answer the phone when you have your friends around ever again! IT WILL MAKE YOU LIVE YOUR LIFE IN FEAR!!!

Review title: This is where it all began
Review_body: The 70's were without a doubt the golden era of horror films. Many brilliant classics have been produced in that time and "Black Christmas" is one of them. This is the godfather of all slasher films and rarely surpassed - "Halloween" would be on the same level as this one. Some argue that the first ever slasher made was Mario Bava's "A Bay Of Blood" which came out three years earlier from "Black Christmas". If you are a fan of the genre I would definitely recommend it since it does contain heavy elements common to the genre but nevertheless "Black Christmas" has a look that is considered modern even today. It has all the ingredients that make a great horror film: creepy atmosphere, tension that never lets go, nice camera work, eerie soundtrack and a nice mystery. There is even some dark humour thrown in. You will not be bored for even a second. The characters are interesting as well; they are not all your cliche college students which became very common in future slashers. Highly recommended to every true fan of classic horror.

SPOILERS AHEAD!!!After two competent attempts at horror (Children Shouldn't Play with Dead Things, 1972, and Deathdream, 1973), Bob Clarke made Black Christmas, one of the first American Slasher films that mixes the Italian giallo genre and the psychoon-the-lose cycle initiated by Hitchcock's Psycho (1960). The results were original at the time, but even today, aware of all the clichés attributed to Slasher cinema, the film is still quite chilling.Set in an old dark sorority house during the festive season, a group of girls are brutally murdered by the raving lunatic that resides within the attic (Margot Kidder among them, who also starred in De Palma's Sisters, 1972, then found success as Lois Lane in Superman, 1978). The film even manages to mix horror and humour involving a buffoon excuse for a cop, Margot Kidder and John Saxon's detective character. The red herrings are characterised very well leading you to wonder whether it's Olivia Hussey's eccentric boyfriend (Keir Dullea of 2001: A Space Odyssey, 1968) or the escaped mental patient' that kidnapped and killed a young girl remains a mystery right up to the tense finale. During the film mechanics are used effectively, especially the now familiar caller is inside the house' routine. These are where the scares really lay. The foul-mouthed killer screams abuse at the girls down the telephone, occasionally snorting like a pig and mumbling something incoherent about a boy and girl called Angus and Billy'. The film ends with the fact that it is neither, but a deranged maniac who can only presumed to be Billy.The ending was intentionally left ambiguous for a planned sequel. It is even suggested that Bob Clarke, who then chose to do comedy, allowed John Carpenter to pick it up where he left it. As we all know what finally materialised wasn't Black Christmas 2, but the Daddy of the Slasher, Halloween (1978). This is one of the best Slashers, but definitely gets the award for the best psycho killer at Christmas, leading the way ahead of Silent Night, Deadly Night or Don't Open Until Christmas (1984).

Watching this film gives me the chills! The story is about a killer who breaks into a sorority house and hides in the basement while killing the women in the house. You have Jess (the always beautiful and heartbreaking Olivia Hussey), a young woman facing an unexpected pregnancy and facing up to her high strung, emotional boyfriend, Peter (2001: A Space Odyssea's Keir Dullea). Then you have outspoken, drunk, Barb (Margot Kidder, who is excellent in her earlier role). The atmosphere is perfectly set: like the weather it is cold and chilling. It is a horrible nightmare of the idea that a homicidal nutjob is not only killing but hiding in the place where the murders are taking place. The film has a Hitchcock quality to it and more frightening is that we never see what the killer looks like and we see him killing through his point of view. It is such a shame and an embarrassment that they had to make a remake of this when certain filmmakers in Hollywood are not clever enough to come up with originals. Great thriller: intelligent, disturbing, and amazingly well acted by the cast.

Directer: Bob Clark, Script:Roy Moore, Cast: Olivia Hussey, Margot Kidder, Keir Dullea, John Saxon.This is one of my all time favorite horror/slasher/thrillers. It is about a group of sorority girls that are being terrorized by a psychopath. Christmass vacation has just started in this small college town(actually Toronto!) so most of the girls have left the sorority house leaving few behind.At the beginning of the film we see some unknown person climbing up into the house. This,of course, is the killer. The girls start to receive very disturbing phone calls(from inside the house!). This guys voice still gives me the creeps. The girls are not threatened at first. They think it is just some sicko pervert(sorority houses probably get a lot of calls like that!)but the calls get more violent and numerous. Eventually,the girls start to come up missing. When the dead body of a young girl is found in a nearby park, they get downright scarred.This movie has a great cast and a great sense of style. Olivia Hussey was a classic 70's beauty(she became popular after doing Romeo and Juliet). She add class to this movie. Margot Kidder is hilarious as the raunchy fowl mouthed Barbie. That fellatio joke is classic! This movie has some very funny moments but it does not distract from the horror. John Saxon, horror movie icon, plays the police detective. Kier Dullea(from 2001: a space odyssey)plays his rather dry self but it is adequate for the part.We never see the characters face in this movie. It is the atmosphere and the sense of unknown that makes this movie scary. This movie has no real gore yet it has some of the best death scenes in horror. Wait till you see how Margot Kidder dies, it is rather unique! The first girl that he kills he does so by suffocating her in a plastic bag. He then sticks her up in the attic. She is shown from time to time in the the attic on a rocking chair---creepy! This movie also has a creepy ending.This film is one of the greats of the horror genre yet it seems to be often overlooked. The problem might have been timing. It was made right after The Exorcist and and the same time as Texas Chainsaw. I think it got overshadowed by both of these films. No doubt it had a huge influence in the slasher sub-genre that would continue with Halloween and Friday the 13th. Bob Clark is a rather diverse director. He did movies from the teen sex comedy Porky's to the warm family film A Christmass Story. Black Christmass is to be remade in 2006 with Clark serving as executive producer.

This an average horror film, with a good story line.  The story doesn't hold up throughout though.  It's kind of confusing.  Anyway, Olivia Hussey as our main star is super terrific.  Margot Kidder as the drunk sorority house sister gets what she deserves.  There are some suspenseful scenes which are well done.  John Saxon as the lead detective is wonderful as always.  The bumbling cop and one of the deceased girl's boyfriends are Porky's alumni, since this film is from the same director.  5/10 Average

Review title: Black Christmas: A Frightening Holiday Slasher
Review_body: After "Psycho," and "Peeping Tom," people wonder whether movies like "The Texas Chainsaw Massacre" or "Halloween" invented the slew of slasher films that we get today. But hardly anyone gives credit to a 1974 film directed by Bob Clark that guarantees some serious chills. It's frightening, and weird, and yet, "Black Christmas" goes unnoticed. Perhaps the older genre fans have set aside a place in history for the film, but the more contemporary audiences hardly know it exists. This is where my review of "Black Christmas" begins.A figure approaches the Pi Kappa Sig sorority house. He climbs up the ladder to the highest window, and isolates himself in the attic. Below the attic door is a party. The sisters of the sorority (including Jess, Clare, Phyllis, and Barb) are enjoying themselves one last time before Christmas break. Many of them are leaving for the holidays while the rest stick around over the weekend to clean house with their house mother, Mrs. MacHenry(also known as Mrs. Mac). But as the obscene phone calls from an anonymous voice continue, and the girls quickly begin to disappear, the yuletide festivities are coming to a close and terror is setting in.Many movie buffs know Bob Clark for his classic comedies "A Christmas Story" and "Porky's," but don't let the fact that he directed "Black Christmas" fool you. The film is dark, and sincerely one of the scariest movies ever made.As I've stated before, the importance of the film lies within the fact that it was released four years before "Halloween." So, which film started the slasher saga? The argument has lasted forever. However, comparisons should not be drawn between the two. They are their own films with their own significance to the horror genre.The ingenious idea of inserting such a happy time of year into a time of fear and despair works extremely well. Since the film is set around Christmas time, the feeling of the holiday is evident throughout. There are decorations everywhere, as well as Christmas trees and snow. Throw the color of red onto snow, and the mood easily changes.Thanks to Roy Moore's script, not only does "Black Christmas" have a load of atmosphere, but it is also host to a series of some of the most profane, shocking, and outright creepy phone calls of all time. During the first call, the killer uses very foul language, and when Barb challenges him, his tone changes, and we hear a rather humanly voice simply say "I'm gonna kill you." From then forth, we are scared not just for ourselves, but for the sorority sisters also.You see, the characters of the film have such likability. Barb is the life of the party, but she means well. Poor Jess has a struggling relationship with her boyfriend Peter, who joyously accepts that she is pregnant but immediately becomes furious when he finds out that she's planning an abortion. These characters feel real, even when there's some comic relief from the house mother and the police department. You don't want to see them die.Telling from the phone calls, the killer keeps everything under wraps. We don't know who he is or what he plans to do, but he gives himself slight recognition of his identity by simply nicknaming himself 'Billy.' The rest of the time, we never truly see the face of the villain. In fact, we don't see much of him period. When we do feel his presence, it is in his perspective, from his point of view. While he's freaking out in the attic, we're freaking out in the attic. When he's killing somebody, we become him. It's an uncomfortable and horrifying notion, and that's why it works.In terms of acting, the cast is above average. Olivia Hussey (whose star quality was projected in "Romeo & Juliet") makes for a terrific Scream Queen as Jess. Also, the early Andrea Martin and Margot Kidder keep things going as Phyllis and Barb. The appearance of genre vet John Saxon as Lieutenant Fuller is also worth noting, as well as Keir Dullea ("2001: A Space Odyssey") as Peter.All in all, it's a shame that the subordinate remake of this fright-fest got minimal attention and the original film got no attention at all. Thankfully, a DVD release has fixed the problem, and more fans have found a place in their heart for the film. It's still not as popular as "Halloween" is, but "Black Christmas" is a horror classic. It will scare and shock you, and equally provide you with a healthy dose of entertainment. This one's a must-see!P.S. The "eye behind the door" scene still keeps me up at night!

Review title: Sorority girls shouldn't play with mad killers
Review_body: Best known for directing "Porky's", Bob Clark also directed "Porky's II", "Baby Geniuses" and "Baby Geniuses 2". To be fair, he's also the director of a decent zombie film with an excellent title: "Children Shouldn't Play With Dead Things". And of course of "Black Christmas", a film that has all good films should have: an inspired screenplay, good actors and excellent camera work.Olivia Hussey is the star of the film. She was mainly cast and admired because of her leading role in Zeffirelli's version of "Romeo And Juliet". "Black Christmas" isn't the weirdest film Hussey is in: you can also spot her in Metzger's "The Cat And The Canary", Kinji Fukasaku's "Fukkatsu no hi" (a.k.a. "Virus") and "Turkey Shoot" (a.k.a. "Blood Camp Thatcher"). You'd almost be more surprised she recently played Mother Teresa. Olivia Hussey is excellent in "Black Christmas" as Jessica (Jess) Bradford, the pregnant and terrorized girl in the sorority house. Don't be put off by the fact that "Black Christmas" takes place in a sorority house: this isn't the sort of film where scantily-clad bimbos are chased by a maniac with a set of knives. The film actually bothered about something called 'plot' and most characters have (at least a little) depth. A welcome change.Also noteworthy is the camera work. The hand-held camera allows us to look through the eyes of the killer, four years before John Carpenter's "Halloween" did the same thing. The cameraman had to climb up and down the occasional stairs, which often looks silly because of a hand-held camera, but "Black Christmas" does an okay job here.Back to the cast: Keir Dullea ("2001: A Space Odyssey" and a handful of cult movies), Margot Kidder ("Superman" and "Sisters") and Art Hindle (best remembered for being in Cronenberg's "The Brood", but also in Clark's "Porky's" films) are just a few actors in a film where most people do at least a decent job. A special mention should be reserved for John Saxon (who starred in more cult films than one could name), who accepted the role of Lt. Fuller when the original actor (Edmond O'Brien) seemed unfit for the role. Saxon flew to Ontario and rushed to the set, just in time for his first scene (in the middle of the night).One might argue why "Black Christmas" needed the subplot of the missing girl, but it's effectively used in a handful of scenes. The naive policeman is there for comic relief, but not the brainless sort of humour one often finds in horror films. If you look at the IMDb message board for "Black Christmas" (but don't do that before you've seen the film) you'll notice the film is vague enough about the identity of the killer, which allows the viewer to guess whether the killer is one of the main characters. So is (s)he? For the answer to that question, I refer you to "Black Christmas", one of the better horror films of the 1970s. Don't expect too much, just sit back and let the film work itself towards an exciting climax and finale.

I always recommend "Black Christmas" when acquaintances and I are sitting around talking about the scariest movies. Like everyone said (I knew it before reading other reviews) this came out first and the later "Halloweenish" flicks copied ideas and atmosphere.My dad and two sisters were watching this on TV when we were kids and I remember my dad would try to scare the hell out of us by staging a fake horrified jump and a cry of fear from his prone position, which sent us all jumping! It was called "When a Stranger Calls" (for TV) and they must have cut some of Margot Kidder's lines like "You f***ing CREEP!!!" which she says into the phone with such power and conviction that it makes me crack up whenever I hear it. Yeah, I kinda made a sound bite from of it.I still had to grab a blanket, cover myself and put my feet up on the couch when I saw the video release a few years ago. Of course I only make it worse while watching it in the dark. The only other movie that even comes close in creeping me out is "Omen" when Mrs. Baylock's face appears as she goes after the mother. A 7 out of 10, this movie ranks in my top 5 of the most frightening ever.

Review title: Cold, classy, and straightforward; still manages a good slice of old-fashioned suspense.
Review_body: Black Christmas isn't the horror film that started it all. In fact, it isn't even perfect horror to begin with, however, it's certainly one not to be missed. Directed by Bob Clark, creator of the childhood comedy A Christmas Story, Black Christmas is undeniably a somewhat agitated and graphic film for the time it was made. It features above marginal acting as well from Margot Kidder, John Saxon, Keir Dullea and Olivia Hussey. The film has a great advantage though of good acting by the female leads played by Kidder and Hussey and there isn't a lot of gore, which proves Clark relies on good Hitchcokian suspense to scare, making the film not to be hampered by typical gatutus sex, nudity, gore, or sleaze.The story is about an obscene phone caller that dials up a sorority house. Finally the police trace the calls... and he's in the house!!!! Along the way, Black Christmas has the sorority girls go vanishing one by one. Still they don't really get it, going about their drunken holiday revelry without a care. The movie has several very interesting plot twists, but perhaps for new viewers it's now predictable and sometimes frustrating, such as the entire concept that we never really see the killer, who hides in the attic the entire time. Suspicions are cast on the crazy-boyfriend-as-a-potential-suspect (Dullea) of the coed (Hussey) that survives the longest, but his creepiness is never fully explored.Overall, while Black Christmas is innovative but made a strong attempt at suspense and terror, it would easily inspire many latter-day horror movies like Student Bodies, When a Stranger Calls, Silent Night, Deadly Night, Halloween, just to name a few, its progeny wouldn't always improve on the formula. Highly recommended!!!

Before Halloween, Friday the 13th, and countless other such films there was "Black Christmas." And unless you are a horror film aficionado, you probably had never heard of it.Of course there was the remake, or "reimagining," a year or two ago, which I did not see but did not hear many good things about. After all, a truly good movie doesn't need to be remade, no matter how old it gets.Black Christmas definitely was good enough to stay un-reimagined. It will appear dated to some, but for me this really played in its favor. Older movies often have corny dialog, but it feels more genuine than many modern horror films. Characters that are truly terrified don't constantly make wisecracks or seem otherwise indifferent to their situation.The dark mood of the film was set very early, and was gradually built upon until the finale. It did not rely upon "boo" scares but upon ambiance, situations, and general creepiness to convey the horror.If you want to see the roots of the slasher genre, or are just pining for a unique and excellent horror experience, then Black Christmas won't disappoint. It may be hard to find but is worth a little extra effort. Check it out.

Review title: Effective and stylish North American giallo: much more than just a proto-slasher!
Review_body: This movie mixes elements of humour with psychological thriller and Italian giallo to produce a film that is both tense, harrowing and grimly satisfying.The girls at a sorority house preparing for the Christmas holidays become the target of a menacing crank caller (the content of whose calls is genuinely creepy and disturbing). In a shocking moment, one girl is murdered early on and left undiscovered in the house: an enduring and sorrowful image that the film returns to frequently throughout its duration. In a way, this is a comedy of errors - the comedy being extremely black in this case - as parents, friends and police fail to spot the clues right under their noses whilst further murders are carried out.Innovative and impactful use of camera angles, POV shots and editing really heightens the tension and terror as the film reaches its pivotal conclusion and the movie ends on a sickeningly ironic twist that leaves a lingering mood.Go out of your way to see this - especially at Christmas for added chills!

Review title: The scariest film I have ever seen
Review_body: I caught this on a cable movie channel when it was under its alternative title Stranger in the House. It's a film that is impossible to "spoil" because there is no great reveal, which adds to the disturbing quality of the story. It was only recently that I have discovered that the identity of the killer was intentionally distorted so that we could never arrive at any definitive answer. Some might find this frustrating and annoying but it is the antithesis of the standard "slasher" flick. I cannot place this in that loathsome category. Since it was released before Halloween it cannot be lumped in with the rip off junk that followed in the footsteps of the John Carpenter film. He has obviously "borrowed" a lot from Black Christmas but it is hardly a copy. What is genuinely creepy and unsettling about Black Christmas is that it feels very plausible, with no invincible killer to be found in a hockey or some Halloween mask. It scares me more than The Exorcist. What distinguishes this from other films of the genre is that we sympathise with the victims. Each kill is shocking and disturbing. Many years ago I had the opportunity to meet Kier Dullea when he appeared at a Q & A for a screening of 2001 at the theatre where I worked. I regretted afterwards not mentioning Black Christmas (or whatever title it started with) and tell "" You were in the scariest film I have ever seen. "

Review title: The Godfather of all Christmas Films! Take that Silent Night, Deadly Night!
Review_body:
The film Black Christmas shocked the hell out of me when I saw it on christmas eve 10 years ago. Though it is 25 years old, the scares are still present. It mixes gore with humor. I quite love that Margot Kidder as the foul-mouth sorority sister slut. I especially like her turtle story and when she gave the cop a phony phone-number! I won't say anymore! See it as soon as possible to help you through this holiday season.Lovely weather for a slay ride. So have your self a scary little christmas! It's not at all like the ones you used to know.10/10
1974 100 mins. Rated: R CC.

Our local festival theatre was showing Black Christmas for one night only so we decided it would be fun to go see it again. It was the 3rd time but the 1st on the big screen. We weren't disappointed. The film was shown in one of the larger theatres not the small venues they also had. The theatre was quite crowded although not full.From the beginning where we follow the serial killer through his eyes into the sorority house the film packed a punch. Billy is truly one sick crap. No we never get know who he is nor do we ever see him except in one scene that was truly disturbing all we see are his eyes. At times there were shadows in the background that made no sounds. But we heard his voice and it was truly disturbing.That the film does have a certain cheese element and lapses of logic does not take away from the fact that this film should rank up there with the best horror films. Suggestion and not seeing the killer are far better than seeing some crazed guy in a hockey mask come at you. It is not the first but many that came after pay homage to Black Christmas. Think Halloween. Before that there was Psycho and Peeping Tom (that ruined Michael Powell's career). And going back even further there was The Spiral Staircase (1945) where a deranged killer stalked girls with disabilities. Pretty daring for its time.Margot Kidder in particular stands out in the cast. This was before Superman. One should also see her in Sisters another truly creepy film. Sadly she has passed away. Also good was Olivia Hussey and Keir Dullea was just creepy and disturbing. John Saxon also appeared as did Andrea Martin before SCTV.But it was the atmosphere created an atmosphere of dread and the voice of a deranged killer that you never saw. Yes the ending was ambiguous leaving the audience shaken and up in the air. And the phone kept ringing. "The calls are coming from the house."

Black.... is a scary and effective horror-movie about some bloody murder which take place in a dormitory. Is it a sick student, a random serial-killer or somebody else...Great actors, atmosphere and plot. Not the usual kind of movie which you usually get when you rents a movie in this category. (8 out of 10)

Review title: Great film for both fans and regular film goers.
Review_body: This film was really great to watch when I saw it last Christmas. I was expecting more of a "Halloween" type film, except the fact that the always brilliant Margot Kidder was in it. So I was into it from the start. The film follows a sorority house on the days proceeding Christmas when a psycho stalker starts getting into the house and, quite frankly, under the girls skin. Then the murders begin. Thesetting has been seen before, and so have the P.O.V. shots, but who cares?This film was scary anyway.Olivia Hussey is terrific and tense as the lead sorority sister, Jesse, who has the burden of dealing with all the other sisters' crisis problems. She looked really great too! And in the finale, she really played her role out for all it was worth.Kier Dullea was descent. A little too humble for the role, and not as, well,intimidating as he could have been. His scenes here are played out like a play. if not Broadway style, more conservative.Margot Kidder, being as good as she is, was not surprisingly fabulous! Hercharacter was the rough tough stuff sister who drinks, swears, and is the only one of them who has the guts to show off some glitz. The rest of the cast does just fine, particularly Andrea Martin as the soft spoken sister, John Saxon as the police chief who only wants to find the answer, and the actress who played Mrs. Mac was certainly worth the view too!Writing wise this film was greatly and adroitly planned. The central theme of this film is that you can't trust anyone, friend or foe, and the scares are genuine, and come psychologically, instead of in your face like "Halloween" or "Friday the 13th." Bob Clark is in love with his actors as he photographs them in brightexuberant colors, while his killer is photographed in jaundiced, grainy colors. All in all, a very artistic film and very creepy to the bone. Great atmospheric music too!

The grandfather of slasher films we know today all started with 1974's Black Christmas. Set during everyone's favourite time of the year, Black Christmas takes a total 180 approach on a usual upbeat holiday and makes it dark and mysterious. This film may have introduced the first person killer camera angle which has since been done better by recent films. The other camera angels are also well done and you can tell a lot of work went into that. The movie also uses a lot of phone calls that come with profound language and suspenseful leads (Sounds like Scream, right?). Lastly, I like how the killer is always kept a mystery. We don't truly know exactly who the killer is and we never visibly see the person.As much as I like the novelty behind this movie, I can say for certain that Black Christmas is INCREDIBLY boring. You will not believe how many scenes drag, how long we focus way too much on the police officers and the investigation of the murders, the killings are slow and unimaginable, and the dialogue will put you asleep standing up. The build-up to the climatic parts of the movie, which is basically the last 15 mins, isnt worth the trouble to sit through.Olivia Hussey eventually becomes the main character after it's not really determined who our main lead is at the beginning. She clearly acted well and did her part and she's absolutely stunning, but I feel her performance was wasted.Black Christmas has seemingly become buried in time. With some cool horror elements that have been copy and pasted into other horror franchises and a bar that was set for future horror movie directors, the unique history and nostalgia behind Black Christmas is undeniably intriguing. But as a movie of its own, Black Christmas mostly flops, and that is why I lead to believe that this film has been lost in time and why, for example, hasn't resonated with a younger crowd, or hasn't had too much of a cult following (not denying there's a cult following, because I do believe there is one but it's minimal in size).If you're a history of horror buff or wanting to learn more about it then take notes from Black Christmas, but be warned, this movie is awfully slow paced and it'll take a lot of patience to sit through the dialogue and suspense.

Review title: One of the first and finest slasher films
Review_body:
A staple in horror history and an influence on the genre and start of the slasher era. One of my personal favorite horror films. I still do prefer John Carpenter's Halloween, but Black Christmas delivers a great combination of suspense and horror, along with an original and well written plot. You hardly ever see the killer yet this movie was horrifying for its time. Its mostly because the writing of the script, its suspensful, tactical, and realistic. You can relate to the situation, you can imagine yourself in this situation because it is much more realistic than a lot of horror movies. Not showing the killer till the end was an important aspect to this film, it slowly built up a plot, we got connected to some of the characters, once that connection happened, the horror starts. An underrated slasher forsure. Overall just a great horror film that any fan of the genre should see and own.
The 70's did horror best

Review title: Proves That Slasher Flicks Can Be Very Good
Review_body: This film is to slasher flicks what "The Changeling" (1980) is to horror flicks: intelligent, somewhat reserved, and representing the cream of the crop for the genre. Can a low-gore slasher flick really work? You bet ya! Much better than most of the bloodbaths earning millions of dollars nowadays. "Black Christmas" is big on atmosphere and fear - but quite reserved regarding dismembered bodies and blood spatter. Also unusual for this genre, the acting is competent, and the potential victims are believable, likable characters - not insufferable morons. On top of all this, the fact that Olivia Hussey is in the cast makes this film a really good choice. Recommended.

Ironically I purchased this film on DVD in Christmas 2001.What a corker this turned out to be, scary setting, memorable performances all round enough said. Can you imagine a more scarier place for someone seeking refuge in an upstairs attic. .  .during Christmas time? Please, even that thought starts to make me feel paranoid.Olivia Hussey (beautiful as ever) delivers a very convincing performance. Vivid appearance from Margot Kidder as the hard drinking Barb (sexually explicit jokes aplenty) and John Saxon as resourceful as always as Lt. Fuller. Bob Clarke shouldn't beat himself considering the fact that the ending was left to an unanswered scenario, who cares it's gem. This was without a doubt the true benchmark to domestic horror before "Halloween" or When "A Stranger Calls" began to over take.Black Christmas rules. 8/10

Many offer Halloween as the classic against which all stalker movies should be compared, but four years earlier, Black Christmas, a minor but exemplary effort succeeded in being far creepier, and avoided many of the former's failings. The telephone scenes are unnerving, the killer truly scary, and the ending is superlative, with a terrifying coda. It strains credulity sometimes, but the terrific use of setting, especially the snowbound Canadian campus, and the admirable character development (so it's not Anna Karenina; how many horror films actually give attention to the minor characters?) make for a highly recommended, as well as historically important, terror film. Olivia Hussey gives a standout performance, Margot Kidder steals her scenes, and Andrea Martin makes an impact in a non-comedic role. Definitely outshines its knockoffs.

Run of the mill slasher flick featuring the classic killer's P.O.V. which was used so effectively in Peeping Tom (1960) and imitated many times since. Boring, predictable and badly acted for the most part.  Even the murders suffer from a lack of a novel approach.  I did like the sicko's voice during the obscene phone calls and the scenes in the attic were creepy enough.  Had to watch the ending a few times cause I thought I'd missed something.  Turns out I didn't.  It's just bungled and falls rather flat. 
Perhaps this film was considered innovative at the time of its 1974 release, but it certainly hasn't aged well.  Worth checking out if you're a true fan of the genre, but there's nothing here you haven't seen before.  A far cry from what I consider Bob Clark's best horror film, Deathdream, a.k.a. Dead Of Night, a.k.a. The Night Andy Came Home.

This Horror-movie is very exciting, suggestive and sufficient terrifying. Black Christmas is a classic from 1974 and same scary today.I can understand why Black Christmas won and nominated for Best Horror film and for Best Motion Picture.The director Bob Clark can make very good directing, so the actors act very well.The acting is very important in film and this Horror-movie acts everybody very good.It is fascinating they made Black Christmas from 1974 in Canada. Canada is a very good country to make Horror-movies!

Review title: possibly the scariest film i've ever seen
Review_body: o god rest the soul of bob clark for having brought this amazing gem of filmaking to the screen. this is such a horrifying film, that i can barely go into my attic anymore, and every time i see a rocking chair, a crane hook or a unicorn, i can't help but squint. the music by Carl Zittrer is just amazing. How do people make that kind of sound? what's the instrument or machine called? i have to know. olivia hussey is just dman beautiful in this movie, and margot kidder (who is equally attractive) is the one thing that made me calm down during the film during it's scary scenes...but then the movie f***s it all up and kills her off! now, i knew her character would die, but i didn't think so grotesquely. also, the ominous ending. why didn't the director choose to show Olivia Hussey die? Because she's Olivia hussey, damn it!! 9 stars. here's to the best(and first) slasher film ever made.

Review title: a true classic in both style and substance
Review_body: the original black Christmas from the year 1974 directed by Bob Clark is a slasher classic. before john carpenters Halloween black Christmas really set the bar high for how good a slasher movie can be. I tend to go back and forth on which film I prefer but most of the time I do like this film better. it is a very stylish and slick film with a brisk pace that keeps you indulged in what's happening on screen. the atmosphere is genuinely chilling and the Christmas setting is used to deliver some dark and unique tones, which is impressive. most of the time when a Christmas setting is involved we are treated to more of a campy and fun style, but this film grits its teeth and stays dark and mysterious. the score is also great and complements the films visual style and setting very well. adding to the already intense and enthralling atmosphere. not only is the atmosphere an excellent aspect of the film but we also get some genuine suspense in multiple scenes. I'm aware that the film is old but for those of you that haven't seen it I won't spoil anything for you, but I will say that there are a few chilling scenes that really show us that bob Clark knows what he is doing behind the camera. he knows what to show and when to show it to get maximum effectiveness out of each scene. so of course this means the camera work is wonderful and another aspect of the film that is a true strength. the acting is also very good, john saxon, margot kidder, Olivia hussy, and keir dullea all give excellent performances. their characters are by no means complex but for what they have to work with they do, do an exceptional job. even the supporting cast are pretty good, especially considering for the most part they are all no name actors with little to no experience to my knowledge. the killer in the film is also a very memorable and iconic villain and his phone conversations with the sorority girls are definitely disturbing and riveting.in truth there really isn't anything wrong with the movie I give it a perfect 10/10

My understanding is that BLACK Christmas is considered to be a cult classic because it is one of the first slasher movies; it laid the foundations for those that came later. Although pretty well done overall, it does have some problems. The film is lightly based on an urban legend - it concerns a Christmas holiday murderer who primarily targets those living in a sorority house. The killer may or may not be involved in some other murders around town, but the focus here is on the people living in the house.The acting is fairly well done by all of the cast, however, some of the characters are very one dimensional. We only see one side of their personality - the conservative virgin, the vulgar party girl and the inept policeman are perfect examples. There are others who are a little more fleshed out and have more depth to them, but the movie does suffer from that shallowness as many horror movies do.Unlike the slashers that came later, BLACK Christmas is very tame in it's graphic violence. Many of the murders take place off screen although the aftermath is generally seen. Although very little blood is filmed, the movie does have a fair amount of bad language so be warned if you don't like profanity or sexual references. It's definitely not suitable for kids.The film is really genuinely creepy in parts, especially in the interactions between the killer and the girls living in the sorority house. The ending is quite creepy as well.Parts of the movie don't make a lot of sense though. I don't want to get into any spoilers here, but lets just say that certain things should easily be heard when things are quiet. And of course, you have the character who stays and puts herself in danger when she's knows that things are quite amiss - one of my biggest pet peeves with horror movies. The film is pretty well paced overall which made it enjoyable to watch. Although some reviewers disagree, I actually did like it's final scenes but I wouldn't want to live in a town where the police don't think things through to a logical conclusion.If you like your horror tame, this one would be a pretty good choice if you can handle the vulgarity. There are other "entry level" horror films that are better, but this one is okay. I don't know that a seasoned horror buff who likes their movies bloody and violent would like it though.

it has a lot of elements that have been used since a million times over...the caller in the same house.widelens action of a madman...i do also think that this has gotten a little old this movie.and another thing i don't get, that i've read quite a bit of psychology, and i know from fact that most murderers are sexual freaks...i mean almost all movies have just people doing murders, while in reality it's almost always connected with rape or sexual perversions... the murderer was a pervert on the phone, but his actions were not like that.i think it's the American hypocrisy in this movie also. sex is evil while violence is OK.we'll you could watch this from a old movie channel, but i wouldn't even rent =/

Review title: The scariest film of all time.
Review_body: I've just watched this again for the umpteenth time. It never ceases to terrify me. This is the ultimate scary movie.My Dad recorded this from the TV back in the early 80's when i was little and my Mum told me under no circumstances am I to watch this film which was a total red rag to a bull. So i managed to watch it at some point...alone and my God I wished I hadn't.Set in a Sorority house and the girls are receiving obscene phone calls (and I mean obscene). Can't really say anything more without spoilers.This film gets creepier and creepier as it progresses and by the end you should be terrified. To get the best effect, watch it alone with all the lights off.....if you dare.

This could only be considered the only pre-Halloween film that ever scared the crap out of me. This is the original "When A Stranger Calls". No one can ever come close (except for Carpenter) to the scares Black-Xmas holds. If your a fan of John Carpenter's Halloween - check out Black Christmas.
One of the creepiest and most effective slasher films ever made. A criminally underrated masterpiece of slasher cinema.

Black Christmas - 1974.( This Films Rates B+ )
After a disturbing obscene phone call, a sorority house is stalked during Christmas break. Its really so 1970's, scenery and all, but the atmosphere is perfectly dark and creepy. The phone calls are deeply disturbing even by today's standards. Not always the best acted, sometimes bad, sometimes good and sometimes just stupid and funny. Like, what? "Fellatio - 2 8 8 0". Not much gore and often times very predictable, yet still genuinely effective. There are plots holes for sure and the killer isnt always the most believable person. You'll see lots of Christmas decorations so you can feel festive enough for this to be a Christmas movie. Is that really the dumbest cop ever? And whats up with those random Christmas carolers around the one hour mark or the search party not long after. Ultimately the ending makes the movie even if slightly absurd, but those camera angles!

Review title: It's actually as good, if not better than all the reviews that made me see it
Review_body: I am a huge movie fanatic and horror is one of my favorite genres. Horror films from the 70s to the present are my favorite, but it's usually quite difficult to find the good ones amongst all the junk. I had gotten to the point to where I thought I had seen all of the great horror pictures of this time period...including...THE CHANGELING, AN American WEREWOLF IN London, THE DEAD ZONE, SHAUN OF THE DEAD, EVIL DEAD 2, THE THING (1982), HALLOWEEN, THE SHINING, SUSPIRIA, THE DESCENT, DEAD-ALIVE(aka BRAINDEAD), THE EXORCIST and THE BROOD...to name a few, so obviously I was skeptical that this film BLACK Christmas that had passed me by for almost my whole life could actually be as good as all my fellow IMDb reviewers were stating. But being a huge fan of Bob Clark's A Christmas STORY, I took a chance and purchased this DVD right out and to my surprise all of the hype didn't even begin to do this film justice. It's been compared to HALLOWEEN and John Carpenter's film is certainly one of the best of the genre but BLACK Christmas...dare I say it...is actually better..scarier and more original. First of all I was impressed by how good the film looked for its age. BLACK Christmas is a class act, with pretty fine actors, a great script and an excellent crew behind the camera. It's hard for a film to scare me after all the films I've seen but my wife and I were often creeped out by BLACK Christmas. There is very little gore and you don't see much of the killer which proves sometimes less is more...WAY MORE in this case. BLACK Christmas is now in my top five of all time horror flicks. See it if you like a good scare. BOO!

No matter how absurd or ilogical was the behavior of the girls and the police, or the fact that I could easily guess the ending. This film is incredibly suspenseful and well acted (especially Olivia Hussey in an early role and veteran John Saxon), plus a very creative use of sound/noise. Clearly Bob Clarke knows how to use a camera to build up tension and disturb the viewer. Possibly the creepiest villain ever in a slasher film; and the funny thing is we never see him, we only hear his ugly, menacing voice.Forget about the crappy "Halloween"; this is the real deal. An amazing movie (2 thumbs up)

Bloodless (but spooky) film about a killer in the house. The murderer kills sorority girls one by one, makes obscene phone calls and trips everyone out. Although it is now format and doesn't seem very eventful, keep in mind the year it was made (it pre-dates Halloween from 1978) and just watch.  It's extremely scary and the phone calls are pretty over the top

Black Christmas is what happens when a director decides to make a slasher but also decides to make a good movie.Each character has a purpose. By that, I don't mean simply to drive the plot along. Each character is a person, and they each have their own unique personalities and motivations. Barb isn't just the drunk and morally abrasive stereotype; she's driven by her jealousy and likely by issues from her childhood. Each character feels about as deep as her, at the least.The only character who isn't fully explained is Billy, and that's for the best. Billy isn't a character we want explained, and it only drives the horror deeper that he isn't.This should be on every horror fan's Christmas playlist.

Move over, Halloween! The scariest holiday is now Christmas. Coming a few years before John Carpenter turned trick 'r treating into a night of horror, Bob Clark told a similar story about an unknown psychopath killing sorority sisters and leaving them terrifying obscene phone calls as the police tries to track him down. It's boasts a likable and strong cast featuring the likes of Olivia Hussey, Margot Kidder, Andrea Martin, and John Saxon who keep everything grounded and increasing the horror around them.

This weeks entry is something special. For starters it is directed by none other than the genius behind one of the most beloved Christmas classics in the history of Christmas classics, A Christmas Story (1983). Yes, the man himself, Mr. Bob Clark. I bet you're thinking to yourself, "Self, I bet the movie this week is going to be a sweet, fun filled romp that will transport me back to when Christmas was chock full of magic and wonder." Well, you'd be wrong. Instead, The Mock Films Blog is proud to present the one, the only (unless you include the lack luster remake from 2006) Black Christmas (1974).Why, you may ask, did I choose a horror film for this joyous holiday season? Well, honestly, if we can call Die Hard (1988) a Christmas movie then we can do the same for this one. (Merry Christmas. On with the blog.) The film revolves around a group of happy-go-drinky sorority sisters getting ready for Christmas break. Little do the naive ladies know, someone other than Santa will be paying them a visit this year.What makes this film so great is that it's as funny as it is scary. Clark puts his signature subtle humor that we saw in A Christmas Story and applies it to this much earlier work. Margot Kidder as the loose cannon is really amusing, along with the booze hound house mother played by Marian Waldman. But for all of its goofiness, the scares are just as strong. From the creepy POV of the killer wandering through the house unnoticed, the disturbingly graphic prank calls made to the sisters, to the solid gore effects,this is a nasty little jump scare flick. Although, it might be a rough watch for those who are bummed out easily during the holidays (go watch A Christmas Story marathon. Bob Clark thought of you too).—

Review title: Santa's not the fusing on this screen
Review_body: This is the very first of it's kind in more than one aspect:  1) It is basically the first real slasher film.  2)  It is the first movie to really employ the phone terror tactic.  3)  It is the first movie to show the film through the killer's eyesight.  This are 3 very big firsts, because they have shaped the horror genre very drastically.  So this is like a monument to the whole genre of horror.  Is it worthy of this title?  Yes, it was a very daring, slick movie that was overlooked when it came out, but it has now quickly become a classic.  People are finally recognizing it for what it was.  It isn't fair to compare this movie to Halloween.  Halloween had a much bigger budget, and more polished shooting.  The guys that made Black Christmas didn't have very much to work with, but they still pulled something tremendous off.  The gore is basically non-existant in this film, but there is a fair amount of suspense to it which is a plus to most people. Now what really makes this movie shine is the atmosphere, it is really straight to the point and very dark.  The movie begins immediately, there is no beating around the bush!  And the movie also ends very abruptly leaving you in question at times.  That is another plus.  Basically, all appreciators of the slasher genre should check this movie out, if they haven't done so already.  I don't know if others will enjoy this though, as it doesn't have much else to offer.

Review title: A sorority house is terrorized by obscene phone calls, while one by one the girls are stalked from within the house.
Review_body: It's the night before Christmas Eve at a campus sorority house when the phone rings. The muffled breaths of the caller can be heard on the other end. Soon, heavy breathing turns into lascivious outbursts, cries that egg on Barb (Margot Kidder) while unsettling the rest. Soon, nobody can find Clare (Lynne Griffin), which leads her father (James Edmond) to contact the police, lead by Lt. Fuller (John Saxon). With the disturbing calls continuing into Christmas Eve, and Jess' (Olivia Hussey) boyfriend upset, it soon becomes evident that there's more to the night than just carol's and Christmas lights.When an unsuspecting world received Black Christmas, the term and sub-genre slasher wouldn't insert itself into the mainstream canon for another 4 years. Pre-dating John Carpenter's Halloween, the aforementioned cannonball to the eyes of American cinema, our film aptly embraces the first person perspective alarmingly introduced with such films as Peeping Tom and Psycho. While the former, Michael Powell's compellingly voyeuristic tale, ultimately ushered in the perspective that would end up widely used in the genre, it wasn't until Bob Clark's holiday slasher that we would see its use popularized in film.What Black Christmas does exceptionally well is assert an uncomfortable gaze over its viewer, one that helps peel backs its grainy, exploitative layer with a razor sharp masculine fixation on the female body. We witness the sorority house from afar, only getting closer as our peeping tom does. Even when we're invited in before he climbs through an upstairs window, it's always through the perceived eyes of our voyeur. The masculine gaze controls much of our perception as he slowly preys on the sorority sisters, a light cascading across a peering eye. When Claire is strangled, her body is propped up by a window with her eyes peering out and mouth agape, echoing the sexually deranged moans of our caller.It's these perverse and sexually driven calls that push our film forward, filling every frame with tension on what we already know. Bob Clark frames the horror with staircases, doorframes and windows, utilizing these as the eyes of our killer. While we don't know who it is, we know where he is; yet this understanding only adds increased value to the terror that presses down on us. It's a pressure that weighs so heavy it rests in our stomach, a feeling Jess carries with her as she tells her boyfriend Peter (Keir Dullea) of her pregnancy and impending abortion. When he tells her what she can and cannot do with her own pregnancy, he stares at her with the same fixation as our killer.Writer Roy Moore plays between the killings and a male-dominated state of mind with a juxtaposition that reverberates even more so today. Peter tells Jess that she can't kill the baby, while she never implies that it's a baby nor uses the word kills. We then shift back to the sorority house, a home that is devoid of male governance, save for the looming eyes of our intruder. The dominating male gaze echoes the dominating male voice that pushes Jess away, further into our place of murder. These transitions spur on the ominous dread that hangs in the air as each kill unfolds, our now final girl clinging to a hope we know doesn't exist.The world that Bob Clark and Roy Moore bring to life is reminiscent of its time, yet mirrors those that we live in today. Its morally strong lead, and similarly dueling views, both literally and symbolically, helped usher in the sub-genre that films like Silent Night, Deadly Night and Night of the Demons would inevitably destroy in the years to come. Black Christmas works as a powerfully affecting, unsettling piece of pre-slasher filmmaking that establishes itself as an important piece in horror cinema.

Review title: the best and scariest slasher movie ever made
Review_body: wow now this is a slasher movie that is actually scary and no annoying teenagers in sight.i saw this movie on TV in the late seventies and it scared the hell out of me.this movie has the scariest killer out of any slasher movie i have ever seen.and i have seen quite a few.forget Jason and Michael myers and Freddy they are smurfs compared to the black Christmas killer.anybody that is a horror fan should go buy this movie right away because it belongs in every horror fans DVD collection no one from destiny's child is in this one like in Freddy vs Jason.no super models or rappers like in Halloween.this movie has the hottest scream queen ever in it.Olivia hussar.so quit reading this and go steal it if you have to

Review title: "WHERE DID YOU PUT THE BABY, BILLY!?"
Review_body: Never has the sound of a ringing phone been used to such great effect than in Black Christmas, a film that I somehow knew absolutely nothing about going in, and one which I will never forget going forward. Rarely do I get my bones chilled or my brow wetted to such an extent while watching horror. Few film's from the genre have gripped me both in entertainment and in suspense like this one did. Not to mention, it boasts some of the better performances from scared women and questionable men that you'll find in the slasher arena. The blocking is tremendous and so is the cinematography. The sound design is tops, though, as the voice on the other end of that miserable phone will haunt me for some time.

This movie truly scared me. The killer in the house concept always scares me but this takes it to a whole new level. The killer makes weird phone calls and hides out in the attic. The ending was probably the scariest part of the movie. The twist was great. The kills were disturbing and intense. The movie is dark and has a sinister feel to it. It never reveals who the killer is. It is some random guy that gets into the house. There are a few bloody scenes. It is one of the best slasher movies ever made. The movie was realistic and clever. This is the scariest movie ever made. The whole movie had a creepy feel to it. I really liked this movie.

Review title: If it doesn't frighten you, you should seek help.
Review_body: I don't know how many times I have seen this film, but I usually try to see it once a year. I would say it is a unique film in its tastefulness. It has the "real life" (I would say) black humour and pulls it off like no other horror film I've seen, fully believable dialogue, perfect acting - and probably the most disturbing antagonist in any film made to this day. Still it has no gore, and doesn't rely on jump scares which is a blessing - because its real power is feeling real, inviting the viewer to almost be inside the film. I am not surprised John Saxon in an interview ranked Black Christmas as the favorite of all the movies he was in (and he did a great number of good films). So if you still haven't seen it, you are missing out on a film that made history, and deserves to be remembered as one of the best (if not the best) horror movies ever made. Make sure to see it in the dark, and preferably during christmas time.

Really scary film with one scene near the end (hair is a clue for those who have seen this movie) that when I saw it in the theater had almost everyone jump out of their seats screaming. Well crafted claustophobic mood as one by one the college coeds are murdered on Christmas Eve in their soriorty house. The voice of the killer on the phone once heard can never be forgotten. Ending is really very different and disturbing. Recommended.

I'm not sure why people keep saying 'Black Christmas' is the first slasher movie. Clearly, the films 'Bay of Blood' and 'Texas Chainsaw Massacre' we're both released first. Not to mention the fact that all slasher films owe a great deal to Hitchcock's 'Psycho'.That being said, Bob Clark is a skilled director, and this film is one of the better films in the slasher genre. Minimal gore, strong acting, and Andrea Martin help separate this film from the million other slashers that would be released in the late 70s and 80s.

Review title: "If this movie doesn't make your skin crawl... then it's on too tight!"
Review_body: Released and ignored in 1973, "Black Christmas" became a forgotten classic. The Canadian shocker was eventually re-released as "Silent Night, Evil Sight" in order to avoid confusion with the blaxploitation films of the time, but it bombed once again. In the early 80s, it was broadcast on cable as "Stranger in the House" in order to snatch up some rantings. Right when the movie seemed dead, NBC decided to cancel a prime-time airing of it because it was deemed "too scary" for network television. This was all film-buffs needed to go back and discover the wonderful "cool movie that you never heard of" that is "Black Christmas".Before I go on, here it goes: "Black Christmas" is one of the scariest (and finest) horror films ever made. Major credit must go to director Bob Clark (who went on to direct the epic "Citizen Kane" remake and because of legal reasons had to change it's title to "Porky's") who like John Carpenter in "Halloween", is able to create a current and simplistic creepy atmosphere. "Black Christmas" is indeed very similar to "Halloween": Both movies are themed with a particular time of year, both movies feature a killer with breathing problems who loves POV shots, and both movies have a long and slow build-up that makes the audience care for the characters that are about to get slashed. The difference is that "Black Christmas" does it much better, in fact, I think it is a superior film.The movie begins with a shaky POV shot of a stranger who decides to sneak inside a sorority house in order to get some fresh meat. That's it! Plain and simple. There is no "your father killed my cousin's cat" motive, the killer wants to kill because he simply wants to. Isn't it much scarier like that? No motive at all?The cast is not your usual teen slasher stereotypes: There is the not-so-virginal sweet leading lady Jess (Olivia Hussey) who is having trouble because she wants to have an abortion. Her boyfriend Peter (Keir Duella) eventually disagrees. In the sorority house there are many other odd characters, including chain-smoking, foul-mouthed, heavy-drinking Barb (ironically played by Margot Kidder) who steals the show with the much-needed humor. Unlike the countless other slashers out there, "Black Christmas" takes time for the audience to get used to these characters and actually care for them. Unlike in "Halloween", the entire top-notch cast in "Black Christmas" give excellent performances. Olivia Hussey is perfect as not-so-innocent Jess, Keir Duella is scary and misleading as her deranged boyfriend. And of course, Margot Kidder steals the show with an excellent and amusing take playing herself. Also noticeable is cult star John Saxon as Lt. Fuller who many years later started showing his personal love for "Black Christmas" on interviews.The well-balanced doses of drama and comedy connects the audience to the characters on screen so strongly that they sometimes we forget it is a horror movie. And when something scary eventually happens, it comes as a total shock. Bob Clark eventually became famous for his comedies, and you can sense his upbeat sense of humor though the entire film. Recent movie audiences lost their patience, so movies like that can't be made anymore. And there is a good reason "Black Christmas" is currently labeled as a comedy at the IMDb, it is really funny. So many memorable quotes here: "These broads could hump the Leaning Tower of Pisa if they could get to top of it!" or "I'm a drunk? Here we have the queen of vodka herself!" and of course, the whole Fellatio address.But isn't this a horror film? It really lives up to it's tagline. To begin with, the killer is not a silent invincible maniac on a Santa Claus costume. Instead, he is never seen. Most of his moments come from POV shots and dark takes. He is confined to the sorority house's attic for most of the time. How is that scary? Sound comes to play. The killer calls the sorority girls though the phone many times (early shades of "Scream" and "When a Stranger Calls") and uses some of the most disturbing voices you will ever hear. He imitates pigs squeaking, perverted dirty talk, animal noises, screaming, heavy breathing, and many other weird sounds. Does it work? Of course. This guy makes Norman Bates look like Richard Simmons.These disturbing elements are all put together though the brilliant cinematography by Reg Morris, who is able to capture the silent Christmas atmosphere perfectly with the wonderful use of silent snow-covered streets and decoration. Let's face it, Christmas is a bit creepy, isn't it? It certainly will be after watching this flick. The piano score by Carl Zittrer is simplistic and effective as well. The repetitive use of Christmas carols also add up to the tension.Ignored over the years and unknown outside the cult horror fans, this is an underrated classic that deserves much more attention that it ever got. Everything is perfect in this Canadian chiller: The atmosphere, the music, the overall spooky look, and one of the scariest villains in history. No gore (although the killings are so disturbingly shot they don't really need any) no sex, no nudity, just plain old-fashioned horror. This is "Black Christmas": Snow-covered silent streets, creepy Christmas carols, spooky use of lightening and color, scary atmosphere and the overall look of the plastic bag suffocated victim in a rocking chair staring from the attic window. Trust me, you will never go to your attic the same way again."Twas the night before Christmas, and all through the house, a creature was staring..."

Review title: I appreciate it for what it was
Review_body: Black Christmas was just boring and not atmospheric enough for my taste.
