Who i thought might be killer i was wrong, and i like the ending even at the end you don't know who he or she is? If the main character survives the night, and who else will he/she kill, before they are caught or killed? Richard

Even though I'm a great fan of all forms of horror flicks "Black Christmas" had, until recently, passed me by. Don't know why but boy was I in for a surprise. I don't know how many thousands of horror films I have seen...but one thing is for sure and that is I am not easily impressed these days but Black Christmas did the job! Yes, we've seen the story before; a group of teenagers stalked by a crazed killer but have this in mind; Black Christmas came BEFORE all Halloweens, Friday The 13th's and Screams and therefore is somewhat of a groundbreaking movie in that sense even though it wasn't first with the hack-and-slash body count formula (check out Mario Bava's Twitch of the Death Nerve from 1971. THAT was early!) Anyway; Black Christmas is a near flawless treat of pure terror with some genuinely creepy and scary scenes including the phone calls from the psycho to his soon-to-be victims. That voice of his...and his crazy psychotic screaming on the phone is maybe the most effective sounds in any horror film ever! This gem is not to be missed!

Review title: One of the greatest slashers films ever.
Review_body: Let me just say that I am a huge horror movie fan.  I thought I had seen just about everything when I heard about this little film from the early 70's.  I will say I went into it with big expectations after reading so many positive reviews from the internet, and I wasn't disappointed.I won't dive into a description of the plot, you just need to see it if you haven't already.  I will say that this film is not only a great film, but one that possesses many of the slasher standards that are so predominant in those movies today, and it pre-dates almost all of them.  While I won't say this film is the first horror movie to the killer P.O.V. shot, it is, along with Dario Argento's "Deep Red" (made the same year), one of the first to do it very, very effectively.  And you'll see where countless others like, "When A Stranger Calls" and "House on Sorroity Row" lift many ideas, just to name a few.The director, Bob Clark, who is better known for his comedies of the 80's (Porky's, A Christmas Story) more than his horror movies of the 70's, is excellent in creating very human characters, a creepy atmosphere, and a very good story line, without generating terrible dialogue.  And let's not forget the very scary killer.  If you can find it on Ebay, I recommend one of his first horror films, "Deathdream" (a.k.a. "The Night Andy Came Home"). Very rare and very small budget, it is another example of why I wish Clark would have directed other horror films throughout his career.  Also look for collaborations with writer/director Alan Ormsby on "Deranged" (1974) and "Children Shouldn't Play With Dead Things" (1972).See this movie.  It is available on DVD.  And thankfully, "Black Christmas 2" is finally in production.   Grade A

Review title: Best horror film of all time.
Review_body: Not only is this movie scary as hell but it's very funny too. Hands down the scariest movie I have ever seen. Scarier than Exorcist or Halloween. Makes Hannibal look like Mr. Rogers(Although Mr. Rogers may be a little off his rocker too). Saw this movie when I was 7 years old and still think about it at 30.

I'm starting to think I saw a totally different movie than almost everyone else who has posted a comment here. I keep reading "best horror movie of all time, and scared the hell out of me". While this movie had it's moments, most of them humorous ones, it will never be on my Top 10 list of scary movies. I'm sure that when Black Christmas first came out it was terrifying, but there are much scarier horror films out there now. The scariest moment in this fairly slow movie was the creepy eye of the killer peering out from the crack of the door. I'll admit that gave me the willies! The gore factor was at zero, and there where some great chances for some good body part shots! The "creepy" psycho voice on the phone only made me giggle like a sorority girl. The scariest thing about Black Christmas was that good actors and performances where wasted on this movie.

I watched this movie 30 years ago. We rented it for our Co-Ed Dorm and watched it together, just before Christmas break. It scared us all.Now, some 30 years later, my 16 year old daughter likes and wants to rent scary movies for Halloween with her friends. She asked me if I knew of any really good scary movies. This movie instantly came to mind. It was the only movie I could think of. It obviously left an impression.This is a good movie that can really scare you without using lots of special effects and gore. Sometimes, the simple, possible, and every day things can be the scariest.

First off, Black Christmas is not in my mind a "great horror classic", as some other people have said. Why? Because it's all violence and a non-exsistent story.The story (warning, spoilers): The film opens at night with a small party occurring in a sorority house for a private school. We are introduced to all of the girls in the sorority house, the main ones being Jess, the heroine of the film, Barb, a drunken loud mouth, and Phyllis, Jess' friend and the peace keeper of the group. The girls have been receiving mysterious phonecalls from someone they call "The Moaner". The calls start out sexual in nature, but they gradually grow more macabre, with the man on the other end saying strange things in different voices. The shyest sorority girl, Claire, goes upstairs to pack, and when she goes into the closet, the killer dives out and wraps a plastic bag around her head. He then drags her into the attic, and puts her in a rocking chair. The next day, Claire's father comes to pick her up, but nobody knows where she is. It becomes a mystery as the police search for the missing Claire. Meanwhile, Mrs. Mac, the house mother, stumbles upon the killer and gets a crane hook in the face. Meanwhile, Jess admits to her boyfriend Peter that she is pregnant, but she's having an abortion. He begins to act strange, and shows off some anger problems. As Barb and Phyl are murdered by the killer, Jess gets another call. The police trace the call and realize that the calls are coming from in the house. Instead of going out, Jess goes upstairs and is attacked by the killer. She manages to escape and heads to the basement. There she runs into Peter, who she now falsely believes is the killer. He approaches her to talk, but Jess hits him over the head and kills him. The police feel the case is closed, and leave the house, leaving Jess alone to sleep off the excitement. As the credits begin to roll, we hear the phone ring once again.Now, this film has major plot spoilers, such as(warning, more spoilers): Police arrive at the home but make no effort to search it, despite two bodies having been undiscovered. (Also noteworthy is that an officer notes "The local morgue cannot handle this many bodies.") The deranged killer is able to repeat lines of dialogue from other characters on the phone, though it seems almost impossible he could have heard them despite being in the house. Despite the parent of one victim being around for the entire movie, no one suggests searching for his daughter when the mystery appears to be solved and she has not been found. Police leave the final potential victim alone in the house sleeping. (Sploliers end now)Basiclyy, this film is all blood and no story. Even though Halloween, (1978) is a rip-off of it, (in my opinion), it's all far better movie.

It's hard to believe the same man directed both the self-deprecatingly nostalgic A Christmas Story and Black Christmas, a twisted little shocker (based loosely on an urban legend) about an anonymous killer who infiltrates a sparsely inhabited sorority house at Yuletide. The two films could hardly be farther apart on the Christmas-spirit spectrum. But then Bob Clark was a dedicated craftsman who preferred to adapt his style to the subject matter at hand.

As a shocker it is 100% original, it pre dates both Halloween and Friday the 13th yet hardly anyone seems to have heard of it and even fewer people seem to be aware the effects it had on its far more illustrious and in my opinion slightly inferior shocker relatives. The cast are excellent John "B movie king" Saxon, Margot Kidder and Olivia Hussey are all standouts. Black Christmas will make you laugh, shudder and jump in equal measures. If you are a fan of ground breaking, CGI free original and pure horror this is the perfect film for you. After being at the upper end pricewise it has come down significantly in price. So buy now to avoid disappointment but only if you enjoy being scared.

I saw this film when it first came out in 1974. It scared the hell out of me. The worst thing was that my parents knew the owners of the house that the movie was filmed in and I had been there many times before and had many enjoyable visits. We had even spent the night there with no problems. I couldn't believe when I saw the film that it was the same house but my mom's friend told me they moved all of their furniture out and completely remodeled the sections that were used in the movie. After filming was completed the film company put the house back to normal, but the house felt different somehow. It's hard to explain but the atmosphere in the house had changed even my mother noticed it. I went back once and never went again. Even though they had never intended to do this the couple sold the house soon after. My mom's friend always blamed the movie for making her move from the house she loved.

Review title: One of the worst films ive ever seen
Review_body: Im gobsmacked at the the other reviews. Terrible acting and the ending was non existent. Persevered with the full movie based on its imdb score but that was a mistake. Do not waste your time watching this movie.

Black Christmas is a movie to watch not for entertainment, but for its influence on modern horror. Most haven't seen this film when compared to Friday the 13th or Nightmare on Elm Street, much less heard of it, aside from the poor 2006 remake. There isn't much about this movie that screams brilliance. Despite a relatively low-budget, it isn't filmed too well, and even though you may care about the protagonists, the acting isn't note-worthy (although John Saxon never hurts); but how the villain is portrayed; through first-person view and his M.O. of making phone calls to his victims; paved a way for modern slasher films. His tactics have been done in previous movies from the 40s through 60s, but was brought together in Black Christmas.John Carpenter, or someone involved with the original Halloween, stated that without Black Christmas, Halloween, a better and more influential horror film, would never have been made. When you watch both films, it's easy to see why; the influence this film had on Halloween is almost immediately recognized.Even without taking influence into account, this is still a film worth watching, but knowing what it did for great horror films that came after it makes it even better. It deserves a lot more recognition than it has.

Can't understand some of the tremendous reviews this film garnered. Okay on its plus side its beautifully shot, the score is genuinely chilling and the acting is excellent throughout particularly Olivier Hussey and John Saxon - the film also exudes a sense of menace and it ends without having resolved the plot which I like but can imagine putting off some viewers. But the bad points are very bad. Firstly the ridiculous noises coming from the phone were more humorous than scary with everything but the kitchen sink coming down the line. For scary sounds watch the Exorcist. But the worse thing about this movie for me were the murders where the camera breaks away from the scene as soon as the murderer attacks someone. Indeed some murders (such as that of the bespectacled female) were not shown at all. This is poor in the extreme and as a viewer I feel short changed. Its not that I want to see acts of violence - indeed one of the scariest films was 7 where no violence was actually seen being committed - it was only the aftermath that was shown on screen but it worked beautifully and warranted an adult rating but this film could quiet easily have been given a PG certificate. It was that spineless and certainly wasn't adult entertainment.

First of all, a warning: Turn on the lights, get the dog, and try to populate the viewing room with as many sane people as possible. The movie starts and you think, s***. Sorority girls? Lois from Superman? An SCTV girl with an afro? WHY OH WHY DID I RENT THIS? But don't worry, you'll be surprised. This is one of the first true "slashers" and it lives up to it's place in that genre. To start the scariness at a minimum, we're introduced to a stranger through creepy creepy phonecalls. We then see through the eyes of some guy with bad asthma climbing the house. He hides in the attic, which in its self is scary! The interesting thing about this movie is that the killings are minimal, and there's no chase scene that I recall, making it unique. There are small problems in it, like while tracing a call from the killer, we see the telephone worker running to manually track the right box by running through hundreds of shelves, and he fails. We see how crazy this killer is, just by how ruthless he is. Then the ending, THE ENDING! That will give you a shudder or two.I know I didn't say much about the plot, but it's basically this: Sorority house, missing girls, creepy boyfriend, suspicious cop, drunken "house mother", missing cat too, and one sonofagun creepy killer hiding in the attic!

Review title: A genuinely creepy and well-written slasher film
Review_body: I had previously written about the film The Blair Witch Project, dubbing it "the best horror movie of all time". Well, it's 2010; I admit that my review was a poorly-written and biased opinion on a film that is, yes, creepy--but calling it "the best horror movie of all time" is a bit of an overstatement. I had not seen Black Christmas.Onward...This film is very ominous, realistic and even funny. Black Christmas has a plot that was later used in a lot of slasher films as well: a group of girls living in a sorority house are stalked by a-- well in this case it's hard to define the character of Billy, disturbing and morbid? The comedic parts are just as great as the scary scenes too. Like when Barb (Margot Kidder) is describing to a cop the address of the sorority house as "Fellatio 20880". The ending, in my opinion made the movie even better. (Spoiler alert) Jess (Olivia Hussey) kills her boyfriend, thinking he's the killer. The cops arrive and let her rest. As she rests, the camera pans away and moves into the attic, where Billy whispers "Agnes, it's me Billy." *shiver* You must see this classic, don't bother for the remake.

Review title: A little neat story of the Black Christmas House
Review_body: I got to say, Black Christmas is a very creepy film. I love it. It scares you so badly, but unlike most horror films it stays classy by not showing gore (this film doesn't need it anyway). Whats really cool though is I actually went right to the house where it was filmed at. Believe it or not its located right in downtown Toronto. My uncle was at one point friends with the owners of the house, and went right up in the infamous attic. He said some of the things from the movie had been left behind, such as the horse (Mind you this was over twenty years ago). He also said the the killer would had to have been pretty tanked to climb up the wall (He tried and failed I guess. And he was a Canadian champion boxer!). I think its cool because unlike a lot of film locations you can just go there, that is, if you can find it (It really blends in). If i can get the address, I will share it with you, but please remember that it is someone's home and private property, so don't intrude. Also, on Halloween if you look up in the window you might see a dummy with a clear plastic bag on its head.

Review title: One of the most frightening movies ever made
Review_body: I am 38 years old and I remember when this first came out on HBO back in the early 80's. I believe I was either ten or eleven when I first saw it. My parents went to sleep right before it came on and I stayed up to watch it (which they wouldn't have let me in any way if they knew this movie!). This was the movie that put a deep dread AND fascination in me for horror movies and suspense/thrillers. It terrified me beyond words, yet as good horror movies do they take you for a ride that thrills you to your core. Man, I remember the unbelievable dread at the end of the movie and after it was over I remember saying to myself "That was the most scared I've ever been".There have been times as an adult that took me back to the horror that this movie implanted in me as a child....One night, sleeping in my apartment alone, I was suddenly awoken by my door opening. I slept in almost complete darkness at the time. I jumped into the "fight or flight" mode and the flight took control...I screamed and screamed like a little girl throwing my pillow at the unseen attacker! I was able to turn on the lights and I came to find out that the wind (during the summer with windows open) was responsible for pushing my door open when it wasn't shut all the way. I woke up my neighbors with the screams and commotion I made and they called the cops thinking I was being murdered! LOL Man was I embarrassed! But after it was over I remembered that that fear I felt was so similar to the fear I first felt when I watched Black Christmas all those years before.Another instance when, I was a teen, I remember watching a news broadcast which told of a stranger living in the basement of a family's house for several months before the family found out. I believe the man was insane and would come upstairs in the dead of night to sneak food and use the bathroom. Apparently he would go upstairs while everyone slept and watch them. He didn't hurt them, but MAN! That gave me the same creeps that this movie did. It made me search every square inch of my house, during the day with a shotgun! I guess it just goes to show that a truly good scary movie like this one can really get under your skin! Some folks give this movie a four, three and even two star rating, which amazes me. There really is no film that compares with this one for the creepiness and dread. I think that the younger folks who are more used to the modern horror movies just can't appreciate, I believe, the genius of the suspense, dread and insane-ness of this movie.If you are twenty five and younger, try watching this movie by yourself, alone in the dark of night. You'll then understand that feeling of deep dread and "creepiness" that will make you stop the movie, turn on all the lights and re-check the windows and doors and the closets and under the bed...and maybe even the attic if you have the strength to do so!

Review title: One of the top ten horror films of all time.
Review_body: I personally feel that this film is heads and shoulders more frightening than either Halloween/ Friday the 13th. This is a must rent if you can find it! I own the DVD and have lent it out uncountable times and have always met with a favorable response upon it's return. Knowing that this film predates Halloween, Friday the 13th and When a Stranger Calls you will see that it laid a great foundation upon which great horror films are still built upon today. The scariest aspect of this film is that there is no closure at the end.

For a slasher film (this is more like a predecessor to the genre)the film is pretty boring, and the kills are for the most part bloodless and uncreative. The killer, makes prank phones calls to a sorority then kills them off one by one. John Saxon is in there as a cop for some reason but the cops don't seem to exist for any other reason than to pad out the more than ample run time. The end is the slasher genre equivalent to "it was all just a dream". Basically, YOU NEVER KNOW WHO IS DOING THE KILLING AND WHY! WTF!? HOW UNSATISFYING CAN YOU GET? Most, at least the entertaining, slasher films have a twist, or a reason, an impetus for the killer's motivations, that's 90% of the story, and why you want to watch. the production values were pretty decent, and the actors all did their parts decently, but with no central thread holding what they're trying to pass off as a story this is a big pass, and only for those who are horror film buff completeists. The viewer has no idea what is motivating the killings, and the characters are so thin, you don't care.When the credits rolled I caught myself thinking, "BOOOOOOOO!, BOOOOOOO!"

Review title: A Brilliantly Well Crafted Horror Film
Review_body: All I can say is I am breathless after watching such a well made suspenseful horror film. To think that Bob Clark, the director of Baby Geniuses, could compose such a terrifying thriller is astounding. It's sad that everyone gives Halloween the credit as the best slasher film, but this film really is the best, and everyone says that Halloween is genius because of its P.O.V shots, but this film beat by about four years by doing some creepy P.O.V shots and editing. The fact that you always know the killer is in the house plays off well like Hitchcock's theory stated, so I strongly recommend this film to those who really want to watch a classic horror film.

Review title: One of the scariest movies ever, ever, ever.
Review_body: I saw this movie when I was just old enough to see movies of this type and it scared the daylights out of me.I think it's the way the killer sounds, not just the words but the sounds, in his calls to the sorority house made the hair on my neck stand up and make it worth seeing.And the ending is really scary. I've only seen this movie once and always hope to see it playing somewhere, a must see. I thought I remembered Karen Black as the star and am surprised to find out that it was Margot Kidder.I think it really went a long way in defining some good, new rules for horror films. It's on my top movies list for sure.

The movie is an outstanding work of art that started it all. Black Christmas spawned Halloween, Friday the thirteenth, Nightmare on elm street, and many more. It has some comedy in it to lighten the load a little bit, and then there are LOTS of dark moments in this film. Overall a dark/comedic masterpiece that should be a landmark in cinema history forever.

The original ending for Black Christmas had the cops leaving the girl with Chris, Claire's boyfriend, in the end, with him saying "Agnes, don't tell them what we've done..." and then he kills her!!... Anyone like this ending better? The director didn't. There is something very creepy about the killer still being there, identity unknown, in the film's ending. It's a shame a re-make is coming. Could this plot actually work in today's high tech atmosphere? Can Hollywood find an original idea? Obviously, NO. So sad. This is what's funny... The 1974 version pre-dates another movie with a similar theme called WHEN A STRANGER CALLS, which of course has it's own teen ready re-make coming out soon. When the new BLACK Christmas comes out people will say they ripped off STRANGER, never realizing that both were 70's films, with Christmas coming 3 years first. I hate that "tweens" get to dictate horror films. It's abysmal. Good googily moogily though, Olivia Hussey was one beautiful woman.
